HEADLINE: E.P.A. Relaxes Restrictions On Sale of Contaminated Land 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency has relaxed restrictions on selling some land contaminated with PCB's for redevelopment, reversing a 25-year-old policy. 
 According to an internal memorandum issued in mid-August, the agency will no longer prohibit the sale of PCB-contaminated land unless the property is severely poisoned. The memorandum was first reported in today's USA Today. 
 Robert E. Fabricant, whose resignation as general counsel of the environmental agency is effective on Wednesday, wrote that the old policy was "an unnecessary barrier to economic redevelopment" and that it might "actually delay the cleanup of contaminated properties as well." 
Lisa Harrison, an agency spokeswoman, said: "Right now, PCB sites may be sitting unused and undeveloped because this prohibition on the sale or transfer of PCB's was a disincentive to property transfers."
Ms. Harrison added, "By reducing the obstacle, we can increase the number of properties cleaned up and reused."
But environmental groups and some agency employees say smaller abandoned sites contaminated by PCB's could fall through the cracks more easily under the new policy. 
"There is a pattern developing where E.P.A. is making it easier to redevelop contaminated sites at the expense of public health," said Julie Wolk, an environmental health advocate from the U.S. Public Interest Research Group.
PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, are toxic substances that take a long time to break down in the environment. They are known to cause neurological and immunodeficiency development disorders in children.
Environmental agency employees say that the 500 or so most severely PCB-contaminated sites, like land along the Hudson River that was contaminated by the General Electric Company, fall under the federal Superfund law and will not be affected by the change in agency policy.
But the agency does not know how many other contaminated sites there are, in part because there is no uniform requirement for property owners to notify the agency of the PCB contamination. 
Ms. Wolk said the agency's online database listed only eight PCB-contaminated sites in New York that are not Superfund sites.
Environmental groups and some environmental agency employees estimate, however, that several thousand contaminated sites around the country are not under the purview of the Superfund law.
Some agency employees say the longstanding restriction on the sale of PCB-contaminated land served as an incentive for owners to notify the agency of the contamination and clean up their property. Notifying the agency before the sale of contaminated property and getting the agency's approval of a cleanup plan helped protect sellers from liability after the sale. About 100 sites a year came up for agency approval, employees say. 
"You take away the incentive to make it happen now, there is a big difference in what gets cleaned up and how quickly," Ms. Wolk said. "You use an extra layer of protection which says that unless E.P.A. approves a good cleanup plan for it, it doesn't get sold."
Some employees say that the only way for the agency to force the cleanup of these smaller contaminated sites now will be through more cumbersome enforcement actions and settlement negotiations. 
The production of PCB's was banned in 1977, and their distribution was banned the following year.

HEADLINE: China Resisting Pressure From U.S. Treasury Chief to Ease Its Currency Policy 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Wednesday, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said today that he was encouraged by "interim steps" China is taking to modernize its financial system, but acknowledged that Beijing had not committed itself to liberalize trading in its currency anytime soon. 
 Mr. Snow is under heavy political pressure at home to talk tough to China about the way it pegs its currency, the yuan, to the dollar, a system that some critics in the United States argue has kept the Chinese currency artificially undervalued and helped China amass the largest bilateral trade surplus with the United States. 
 In meetings with China's top financial officials Tuesday and today, Mr. Snow said he pressed them to establish a flexible exchange rate system, which some analysts believe would lead to an appreciation of the yuan and potentially reduce the advantage China's exports have in many overseas markets. 
He said Chinese leaders reaffirmed that they had a longstanding goal to move toward more flexibility, but did not provide a timetable. Chinese officials have said that they do not intend to overhaul their currency system immediately, especially at a time when international pressure is intense and currency speculators are seeking to force their hand. 
"I was encouraged to hear a reaffirmation of China's longstanding goal to move toward greater flexibility," Mr. Snow told reporters this morning. "I was assured that interim policy steps are now being taken and progress in this area will continue."
Among the policy steps he said he had discussed with Chinese officials were relaxation of capital controls that restrict the amount of foreign currency Chinese companies and individuals can take out of the country. He said Chinese officials also told him they were moving to loosen regulations on companies and individuals who want to invest abroad, a step he said could lead to an increase in the flow of Chinese money into American stocks and bonds. 
He said he hoped that China would also move to create more opportunities for American financial firms to own asset management companies, and for American insurance companies to open branch offices around the country. 
"These are interim measures that prepare an economy for a more flexible exchange rate system," Mr. Snow said. "It is to China's advantage to encourage flows both in and out." 
Mr. Snow did not make much headway, however, on pressing China to change its currency system. 
Chinese officials, in fact, appear determined to resist any outside pressure. They are also cautious about tampering with a currency system that has been a source of stability for the country's still backward banks since the yuan was pegged at 8.28 to the dollar in 1994.

HEADLINE: Personal Debt Surges in Britain 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
Throughout this balmy summer, when temperatures hit their highs and people shopped for flimsy clothing and cooling drinks, Britons set records of their own -- mainly of red ink in soaring personal debt that could spell an imminent end to a feel-good era.
 The signs of the boom years are easy to see -- late-model cars bought on credit, restaurants and pubs bulging with diners and drinkers, housing prices higher than ever and crowds of shoppers invading the clothing, music and shoe stores of Oxford Street in London. 
 Britons, once dismissed as a nation of shopkeepers, now seem to be a nation of shoppers: so intense has been their spree that consumer spending accounts for virtually all of the country's economic growth.
 But there is a more ominous side to the spending boom. In the month of June alone, consumer borrowing surged by $15 billion from May, the highest monthly increase on record, taking total household debt to the equivalent of $1.4 trillion -- meaning that the mortgages, credit card debt, loans and overdrafts of the average British resident total at least 120 percent and possibly 130 percent of annual disposable income. 
 That proportion of debt to income is similar to personal debt levels in the United States, said John Butler, an economist at HSBC Bank, but British debt is growing much faster than its American counterpart. During Britain's last big economic boom, in the late 1980's, the proportion of debt to disposable income was around 80 percent, showing just how much Britons have come to rely on easy credit.
 "Many people have a habit of describing the U.K. as a mini-version of the U.S." in its readiness to borrow, Mr. Butler said. "In fact, it's a maxi-version." The sudden acceleration of borrowing in the last 18 months has been driven largely by people spending money from extra mortgage loans they have acquired at the lowest interest rates in more than 40 years.
 And the borrowing has not stopped at mortgages. "The key is that all forms of debt have been rising, so it's not just about shifting the kinds of borrowing," Mr. Butler said. "It's all rising," setting Britain apart from the Continent, where he described many people as "savers rather than spenders."
 Over the summer, figures released by Datamonitor, a private research group, said the average Briton's unsecured debt on credit cards and other borrowings had risen by about 40 percent in the last five years, to the equivalent of $5,400. 
 The government-run National Association of Citizens Advice Bureau said the number of people seeking advice on debt problems had risen by almost half over the last five years, with the average debtor confronted by repayment demands of about $17,000, equivalent to 13 months' income.
 "The U.K. is one of the most unbalanced economies in the world," said Holger Schmieding, a European economist at Bank of America. Its growth is based on consumption, he said, while investment is weak and the level of personal debt is "like a sword hanging over the economy."
 The debt free-for-all seems sharply at odds with the financial ethic advanced by Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, who insists that his economic watchword is prudence, even as the nation earns tax income from the increased spending.
 The story of British borrowing, thus, has little to do with caution and everything to do with lopsided growth that sets this country apart from the slowing European economies of France, Germany or Italy. Britain is still forecasting growth of 2.25 percent this year, though it may not reach that target, while important Continental economies have ground to a halt.
 And it is a story that highlights the distinction between the British and Continental economies that may obstruct British membership in the eurozone.
 For the last five years, housing prices here have been skyrocketing, and even with a recent slowdown, the annual increase is still 17.9 percent, compared with 25 percent a year ago, according to the Nationwide Building Society, a leading mortgage lender.
 At the same time, unemployment, which has risen in some other major European economies to around 10 percent, has fallen to its lowest level in more than four decades, to slightly more than 3 percent, providing more people with earnings to spend. The government itself has overseen the hiring of an additional 340,000 employees in the last six years.
 The increase in real estate prices enabled many people to simply expand their mortgage loans to obtain extra cash, secure in the knowledge that the value of their property more than offset the extra loans. And, with interest rates down -- they are currently pegged by the Bank of England at 3.5 percent, the lowest since the 1950's -- mortgage repayment costs also fell.
 Financial institutions that once discouraged debt, moreover, now encourage it with fierce competition among mortgage lenders, banks, loan consolidation companies and credit card issuers to lure customers with offers of low interest rates.
 Television commercials offer people in financial trouble a chance to group all their loans into one, sometimes with their homes as collateral. Credit card companies vie with one another in introductory offers of zero interest for six months followed by repayments at an annualized rate of 14 percent.
 Over the last year, though, there has been a shift. Increases in compulsory National Insurance withholdings to finance government pensions and increases in local residential taxes have offset wage increases running at 3 to 4 percent. So real income has begun to shrink, just as the dinner table chatter turns to the gradual easing of real estate prices. But despite the alarm signals, people have continued to borrow.
 The latest official figures suggest that consumer spending is growing by 1.3 percent a quarter, while lending is increasing by 14 percent a year, the fastest rate since 1990, at the end of another renowned boom that led to a painful retreat. In July, said the Confederation of British Industry, a leading employers' organization, sales at Main Street stores were "unexpectedly good."
 At the same time, though, many mortgage lenders are expecting interest rates to rise next year, so all those extra loans will cost more to repay. "We would urge all borrowers to ensure that they are building in enough flexibility to their household finances to be able to cope with higher mortgage repayments," said Michael Coogan of the Council of Mortgage Lenders, an industry group.
 The concern among economists is that while British growth continues to be pushed along by consumer spending, the debt-fueled boom cannot last forever, creating a quandary for the Bank of England's policy makers: a further drop in interest rates could spur growth from other sectors of the economy, but it would also increase consumer spending and personal debt.
 As ever, though, economists are looking at the housing market as the herald of a downturn. "Prices are now so high that it's starting to become unaffordable for first-time buyers," Mr. Schmieding at Bank of America said. "We will see the peak of the credit boom in the next few months."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A customer in a Marks & Spencer store in London. Consumer spending is driving the British economy. (Photo by Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Deal Said to Be Reached In Inquiry on Failed Insurer
Credit Lyonnais and a corporation run by the French government have agreed to plead guilty and pay hundreds of millions of dollars to settle a federal investigation into the takeover of a failed California insurance company, people close to the situation said.
 The matter stems from the collapse of Executive Life, a California insurance company, in 1991 after its extensive portfolio of junk bonds lost much of their value. Credit Lyonnais acquired the junk bond portfolio for about $3 billion, and other French investors acquired the insurance business. Page C4. 

Stocks Start a September Rally
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 13.98 points, to 1,021.99. The last time the S.& P. closed higher was June 18, 2002, when it was at 1,037.14. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 107.45 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,523.27, and the Nasdaq composite index jumped 31.03 points, to 1,841.48. C8.

Caremark Rx to Buy AdvancePCS
Caremark Rx agreed to acquire rival AdvancePCS for $5.6 billion, mainly in stock, combining two of the nation's largest pharmacy-benefits managers. C8.

Deal Reached With a Verizon Union
Verizon's largest union announced a tentative agreement with the company for a bargaining unit of 51 workers at Verizon Wireless. C2.

AT&T Files Suit Against WorldCom
AT&T filed a federal racketeering lawsuit against WorldCom, accusing it of fraudulently routing calls and mail and wire fraud. C12.

HEADLINE: Latin Grammy Show Puts Miami to the Test 

BYLINE:  By MIRTA OJITO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
The Latin Grammy Awards will be broadcast from downtown Miami on Wednesday night in an internationally televised ceremony, more than three years after Latin music producers and civic leaders here first tried to transcend local politics over Cuba to lure the event from Los Angeles.
 "It's a victory for the city," said Emilio Estefan, the music producer, who lives here with his wife, Gloria Estefan. "We will show that we have matured as a community." 
 For years the Latin Grammys have been mired in a debate centering on whether arts and politics associated with Cuba can ever be separated. If the event succeeds, it could greatly bolster Miami's position as the Latin entertainment capital, organizers say. If it doesn't, it would be another strike against a city that for years has struggled with an image of intractable politicalstrife over Cuba. 
Two groups representing wildly different views on Fidel Castro and Cuba have obtained city permits to demonstrate in front of the American Airlines Arena, where the show will take place and be broadcast on CBS at 9 p.m., Eastern and Pacific times; 8, Central time. One group opposes the presence of Cuban artists in Miami; the other supports their presence.
Ten of the 41 Latin Grammy nominees either live in Cuba or have not openly cut their ties to Mr. Castro's government. Because several of the nominees are musical groups, the Cuban delegation, if granted visas, could have more than 70 people, said Gabriel Abaroa, executive director of the Latin Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which sponsors the awards.
It is unclear who among them will be able to come to Miami because some of the artists who live in Cuba need visas to travel to the United States while others, who live in Europe, may not.
For many Cuban-Americans who grew up on the island and witnessed some of these artists singing the praises of Mr. Castro, an event that rewards them is a slap in the face, said Francisco Garcia, a spokesman for a group of exiles, many of them former political prisoners, who plan to protest.
"In any other country in the world perhaps arts and politics are truly separate, but not in Cuba," said Mr. Garcia, 54, who spent five years in a Cuban prison and three in a labor camp. "Castro has said many times, he said it from the beginning, that within the revolution, all was allowed; outside, nothing."
For others, like Mr. Estefan and Mayor Manny Diaz, the actions of Mr. Castro and his apologists must be exposed and criticized, they said, but not at the expense of robbing the city of the opportunity to shine with the Latin Grammys.
The event, with the Brazilian singer Caetano Veloso and the Panamanian salsero Ruben Blades among the nominees, is expected to attract 12,000 people. Artists like Marc Anthony, Ricky Martin and Thalia will perform; George Lopez, star of his own ABC sitcom, will be the host. Through an arrangement with CBS, the show will be seen in 110 countries, 40 of them through a live broadcast. 
"My heart is always divided in two," said Mr. Estefan, who left Cuba in 1967, when he was 13. "One part feels the pain of my country and my people and the other half refuses to do what Castro does. I have to support freedom of expression in all of its manifestations."
Mr. Estefan is not alone in his views. In a poll conducted three years ago by researchers at Florida International University, the local state university, more than 50 percent of Cuban-Americans were opposed to banning Cuban musical groups from performing in Miami. In fact, for the last few years, many Cuban artists, from singers to painters to actors, have come to this city to exhibit their work and perform without provoking the public ire of Mr. Castro's critics.
But this year the event comes after a wave of repression in Cuba that provoked immediate and widespread international repudiation: Three young men were executed in April for attempting to steal a government boat to leave the country, and 75 dissidents and human rights activists were jailed for terms ranging from 6 to 28 years. At least two dozen prominent Cuban artists signed a letter asking other artists around the world to stop their condemnation of the Cuban government. The jazz pianist Chucho Valdes, who reportedly signed the letter, is one of the nominees.
Right after the nominations were announced about six weeks ago, Mr. Estefan, who is co-producing the show but says he has no control over who goes onstage, said that if any of the Cuban nominees were to perform, he would walk out. His statement underscored the balancing act that elected officials and civic leaders must conduct here, pitting the interests of the city against the feelings of some of its most vocal and politically active citizens.
"This is about an industry that the city hopes to keep and expand," said Mr. Diaz, the Cuban-born mayor of Miami. "We are always hoping to diversify our economy, and not be so tourist-dependent. This is one way to do it."
Miami is already home to a number of Latin stars, like Julio Iglesias, Enrique Iglesias, Ms. Estefan and Mr. Martin. The two largest Spanish-language television networks in the country and one of the largest Hispanic radio groups are based here, as are most of the labels that record Latin artists.
Since the Latin Grammys were begun four years ago, many in the music industry thought that this was the ideal place to hold the awards show. But back then Miami-Dade County, in a bow to local animosity toward Mr. Castro, had an ordinance that, among other things, prevented the county from doing business with organizations or people with ties to Cuba, including artists.
When the ordinance was struck down by a court three years ago, the Latin Recording Academy decided to hold the show in Miami in 2001. Several groups of Cuban exiles announced that they wanted to protest the presence of Cuban artists from the island. After failing to agree on where the protesters would be allowed to stand on the night of the event, organizers decided three weeks before the show to return it to Los Angeles, where it remained until now.
Earlier this year, the academy moved its headquarters to Miami, and brought the show back. Soon after, City of Miami commissioners urged the academy to refuse to recognize or invite any Cuban artists to the Grammys and passed a resolution forbidding the city from spending any funds on the event, except those necessary to cover police and fire rescue.
Once again, the protesters demanded a space to vent their feelings. With the help of lawyers from the American Civil Liberties Union, they were granted a permit to stand 168 feet from the entrance to the arena.
A group that supports the presence of Cuban artists in the Grammys has also been granted a city permit to demonstrate, about three blocks from their opponents. 
Despite the hurdles, the planned protests and the slight from city commissioners, Miami proved to be the best choice this year, Mr. Abaroa said, but there are no promises for the future.
"The show must go on," he said, "wherever that might be."

HEADLINE: Lieberman Proposes Insurance To Cover Everyone to Age 25 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut said today that as president he would create a federal program to provide affordable health care coverage for 31 million people who do not have it, a group that includes the 9 million children who now lack health care benefits.
 The cost of the program would be about $54 billion a year in new federal spending, making it one of the least expensive plans being proposed by the Democrats who are running for president. Mr. Lieberman said his plan was the only one among those of the major candidates that would cover all children who have no benefits and would keep them eligible for benefits until age 25. 
 The senator did not explain how he intended to pay for his program. Aides said that would be covered when Mr. Lieberman unveiled his economic policy in a few weeks.
"When I'm president," he said, "newborn babies won't go home with just a name and a birth certificate. All American children, rich or poor, will have health insurance that stays with them from the moment they're born, all the way to age 25."
In announcing his proposal at the health center at Broad Acres Elementary School in Silver Spring, Md., Mr. Lieberman took special aim at the three Democrats who appear to be running ahead of the field -- Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont; Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts; and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri -- insisting that his plan would cover more people and cost less than their proposals. He also criticized President Bush as not doing enough to bring health care coverage to those who need it most.
"It's an outrage today that nine million American children are uninsured," Mr. Lieberman said. "I'll provide coverage to every child."
Mr. Lieberman tried to distinguished his plan from those of other candidates by focusing it on children. In addition to the new coverage, which he called MediKids and said would protect those in state programs when state budgets were strapped, he said the plan would create federal grants to help elementary schools across the country open health care centers based in schools.
Among the other Democratic candidates, Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio, Carol Moseley Braun and the Rev. Al Sharpton have taken the most expensive approach to health care, proposing government-run, single-payer plans. Mr. Gephardt has outlined another ambitious approach, a $214 billion plan that would require employers to provide private health care insurance in return for tax credits.
Mr. Kerry, Senator Bob Graham of Florida and Dr. Dean have outlined plans more modest in cost. Only Senator John Edwards of North Carolina has proposed anything close to Mr. Lieberman's in cost, but it would cover about a third fewer people.
Mr. Lieberman said the lower cost of his plan reflected the state of the economy, calling his proposal the first in a step-by-step approach that would expand as the economy improved. Mr. Kerry, Mr. Gephardt and Dr. Dean have said they would pay for their plans by repealing tax cuts.

HEADLINE: Fuzzy Economic Thinking; 
Job Czar for the Jobless

 BODY:
Considering that over 80,000 jobs have been shed for each month of his incumbency, President Bush's announcement that he is creating a new undersecretary of commerce post devoted to job creation is notable for its feebleness. The only detail yet clear is that the post is to be devoted to the "needs of manufacturers," and that is hardly a confidence builder for the 9 million trying to find work plus the millions more who have given up. 
 The 2.7 million jobs lost in the private sector in less than three years is one of the worst slides in decades. "There are better days ahead," Mr. Bush told union workers on Labor Day, in a choice of language that eerily echoes Herbert Hoover. The nation should not forget the president's earlier insistent prescription: in selling his tax cuts in the Republican Congress, Mr. Bush proclaimed them as just the economic "jobs and growth" package workers needed. But the unemployment problem remains rock-hard in resisting the administration's trickle-down fantasy that cuts for the affluent will generate new jobs for the working class. 
 The tax cuts have failed to do the trick, and the recovery has so far not been of a size sufficient to create jobs. Ominously, a new study by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says this recession's job losses have been far more structural and permanent than in the past. Now, a new job czar has emerged like the Wizard of Oz to signal that the presidential election cycle is upon us. The agony of the jobless deserves the fullest attention of the president and his eager rivals, and federal action more ambitious than the addition of employment for one happy undersecretary in the Commerce Department. 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 6, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An editorial on Wednesday about President Bush's plan for a new jobs creation post misstated the level of the post in the Commerce Department. It will be given to an assistant secretary, not an undersecretary.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
The chief executive decides that G.E. can stand the risks of Hollywood's ups and downs.

BYLINE:  By Claudia H. Deutsch 

 BODY:
ON the surface, the merging of NBC with Vivendi Universal's entertainment assets would appear to be the last type of deal John F. Welch Jr. would have made for General Electric. 
 After all, Mr. Welch spent 20 years turning G.E. into a company that could be relied on for consistent earnings growth and high returns on capital. And Hollywood's volatility, with its unpredictable mix of flops and hits, would seem to represent the antithesis of that goal. 
 "Jack might have bought some cable distribution systems as bolt-on acquisitions, but I just don't think he would have done this," said Robert Friedman, an analyst with S&P Equity Research.
But Mr. Welch did not face the challenges that Jeffrey R. Immelt, G.E.'s current chief executive, does. And the merger with Vivendi Universal may not be as risky now as it would have been during the Welch era.
When Mr. Immelt became G.E.'s chief on Sept. 7, 2001, the company's profits were growing at a double-digit pace. Less than a week later, the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center knocked the economy into a tailspin -- and, saddled G.E.'s insurance unit with huge claims.
Just a few months earlier, G.E.'s planned acquisition of Honeywell International came apart, leaving the company's revenues top heavy with financial services. And the stocks of financial services companies historically trade at lower multiples than those of industrials. 
Mr. Immelt needed to find new ways to bolster G.E.'s nonfinancial businesses, but that has gotten only harder in this sluggish economy. Sales of plastics and other chemicals are down even as feedstock costs continue to soar. Few airlines are buying planes, and even fewer utilities are buying power systems. 
Indeed, when Mr. Welch retired, GE Capital and GE Power Systems were the company's two largest and most profitable businesses. NBC was sixth in revenue, fifth in profit. Today, GE Capital has been broken into four businesses, and only two of them -- consumer and commercial credit -- are robust. Power Systems, which sells turbines and the like to utility companies, is still biggest in revenue -- $22.9 billion in 2002 -- but its sales and profits are plummeting. NBC is now one of the fastest-growing units in profits, and its revenue jumped 24 percent from 2001 to 2002, to $7.1 billion. 
But Mr. Immelt clearly sees industrial bright spots. In G.E.'s last annual report, he named five businesses that he wanted to stress: consumer finance in the United States, security, water processing, wind energy and oil and gas exploration. And, his emphasis on health care information technology remains strong.
Like Mr. Welch, he has stressed services as G.E.'s best route to profits. But unlike Mr. Welch, he has stressed technology as the best route to those services. 
He has revamped G.E.'s corporate research laboratories to focus on breakthroughs, pushing the quest for incremental improvements back onto divisional budgets. He has discarded G.E.'s longtime advertising slogan, "We bring good things to life," in favor of "Imagination at work," which is less associated with mundane items like light bulbs. 
When G.E.'s industrial systems division first began making switching gear for electric networks 100 years ago, it was one of the highest-tech businesses G.E. had. Switches are now a commodity, so Mr. Immelt is turning the division toward industrial security, a thriving market in the post-Sept. 11 world. 
He bought BetzDearborn, a huge water treatment company, not so much for its stable of water treatment chemicals, but for its thousands of water treatment engineers, who help customers develop systems for purifying water.
He has been stressing the technology and services aspects of all the areas in which G.E. has a huge installed base. Even if Power Systems never sells another turbine, it can make money retrofitting existing ones with a new ceramic that enables fuel to burn hotter. The transportation division can make money helping railroads reconfigure trains and track them, while aircraft engines can help airlines figure out better routings. 
Mr. Immelt is not ignoring the finance business, of course. He has moved much of its debt from short to long term, and reorganized it into a series of discrete businesses like commercial loans and leasing. Many of those businesses, though, are in pruning mode. He has sold many of G.E.'s insurance businesses, and is reducing its investment in trucks, tractors -- pretty much any form of transportation equipment but aircraft -- that once underpinned a thriving leasing business. 
Slower-growth industrial businesses are ripe for the ax, too -- just not yet. Mr. Immelt consolidated lighting and appliances into a combined consumer products division, is cutting costs, and most analysts expect he will probably sell them when they can command a decent price. It is a lot of upheaval, but analysts say G.E. has little choice. Its stock, which traded around $60 three years ago, trades at half that now. "If Jeff wants to jump-start earnings, he simply has to move up the risk curve," Mr. Friedman of S&P said.
And to Mr. Immelt, the risk in the Vivendi deal is manageable. When he looks at Vivendi, he does not see a risky creator of content. He sees a valuable library of films that can run on Bravo and other G.E.-owned networks, that can be sold on DVD and through pay per view, and that can run on Bravo and other G.E.-owned outlets, as well as on the cable networks that Vivendi brings. 
Still, Mr. Immelt's tolerance for risk seems higher than that of his mentor and predecessor. "Jack was obsessed with smooth consistent earnings growth, but Jeff will sacrifice smooth earnings over the short term for higher returns in the long run," Mr. Friedman said. And that, Mr. Friedman suggests, is a much wiser course. "Investors who look solely for consistent earnings at the expense of higher returns over time are missing the point," he said. "Plenty of investors, including Warren Buffett, would take lumpy 15 percent growth over a smooth 10 percent."

SUBJECT: NATURAL GAS & ELECTRIC UTILITIES (90%); EXECUTIVES (90%); FINANCIAL RESULTS (89%); COMPANY PROFITS (89%); OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (78%); MERGERS (78%); COMPANY EARNINGS (78%); ANNUAL REPORTS (78%); BROADCASTING INDUSTRY (78%); TELEVISION INDUSTRY (78%); UTILITIES INDUSTRY (77%); ELECTRICITY TRANSMISSION & DISTRIBUTION (77%); COMPANY REVENUES (76%); MINING & EXTRACTION SECTOR PERFORMANCE (76%); BANKING & FINANCE (76%); WATER & WASTEWATER MANAGEMENT (75%); EQUITY RESEARCH (74%); WIND ENERGY (72%); INDUSTRY ANALYSTS (71%); SEPTEMBER 11 ATTACK (71%); PERSONAL FINANCE (70%); MANUFACTURING OUTPUT (69%); AIRLINES (67%); CONSUMER LENDING (65%); HEALTH CARE INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY (50%); OIL EXPLORATION (50%); OIL & GAS EXPLORATION (50%) MERGERS, ACQUISITIONS AND DIVESTITURES

HEADLINE: Vivendi Agrees to Talks to Combine U.S.Assets With NBC 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE with ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 2 

 BODY:
Vivendi Universal picked a merger partner today for its entertainment assets, agreeing to enter exclusive negotiations with General Electric to unite them with NBC.
 If completed, the deal would result in the creation of NBC Universal, which would be the nation's sixth-largest media company. It would include NBC's assets -- the broadcast network, local stations, the cable channels CNBC and MSNBC and the Spanish-language network Telemundo -- and Vivendi's movie and television studios; its cable networks like USA, Bravo, and Sci-Fi; and the Universal Studios theme parks. 
 The transaction would represent a marked departure for General Electric. The company has long loathed the risky and finicky business of Hollywood; historically, it has dismissed the need to venture beyond television even as its rivals have completed mergers, with CBS joining Viacom and ABC linking up with Walt Disney. 
For Vivendi, the proposed deal represents the most definitive step yet in its effort to unwind the media empire assembled by its former chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier. The preliminary agreement also appears to dash the hopes of Edgar Bronfman Jr., the Seagram heir who had mounted his own bid to regain control of the assets his family sold Vivendi just three years ago.
Under the terms of the Vivendi-NBC preliminary accord, Vivendi would own a 20 percent stake in NBC Universal and immediately receive $3.8 billion in cash through a complex transaction involving a G.E. commitment to buy part of Vivendi's stake in the future. G.E. will also assume $1.6 billion of Vivendi's debt.
The new company would be run by G.E.'s vice chairman, Robert C. Wright, who is chairman of NBC. As a minority partner, Vivendi would have three seats on the NBC Universal board.
Despite the preliminary agreement, which ends a months-long auction that included more than half a dozen bidders, details of a final pact remain to be worked out over the next month and the deal could still collapse.
In addition to completing their own pact, Vivendi and NBC will probably have to negotiate a deal with Barry Diller, the chairman of InterActiveCorp, who owns a 7 percent stake in Vivendi's entertainment assets.
Vivendi and NBC are entering uncertain territory. The rush by media companies to consolidate -- believing that it is essential to operate on a large scale -- has had mixed results.
The America Online-Time Warner merger, for example, has been widely criticized as a failure so far. And the promised synergies from owning both television networks and television production and movie studios have not always materialized. Disney acknowledged last year that the lackluster results at ABC were in part a result of an overdependence on homegrown television shows, from its Touchstone Television arm.
Mr. Wright, who has been one of the biggest proponents of the deal within G.E., said during an interview today, "There is no reason this shouldn't succeed." 
While he acknowledged that the company had little experience making movies, he scoffed at the perceived risks of the business. "The studio is not such a frightening issue," he said, pointing out that Universal Studios "is on a bit of a roll." (Its hits this summer include "Seabiscuit" and "2 Fast 2 Furious.") 
He seemed slightly more concerned about the prospect of owning Universal's theme parks. "We don't purport to have any experience managing theme parks," he said, acknowledging that an industry slump has made owning the parks "like being in the airline business."
Asked about the chances the talks could collapse, given a prominent disclaimer in the companies' news release that said as much and G.E.'s reputation as a tough negotiator, he deadpanned, "It's 50-50." Then he interjected, "No, no no."
Jean-Rene Fourtou, Vivendi's chairman, welcomed the deal in Paris, calling it the "beginning of a new era." He said it would transform the company into one "with stronger assets and a healthier financial base."
Mr. Fourtou succeeded Mr. Messier 14 months ago when Vivendi ran out of cash after a series of costly acquisitions and share buybacks. After unexpectedly large losses at the company, Mr. Fourtou pledged to begin unwinding the media empire assembled by Mr. Messier, promising to sell assets worth $16 billion by the end of 2004. 
Vivendi's decision to accept preliminarily a deal that leaves it with a major stake in the business is a reversal of the company's stated intention to sell the entire company for cash.
"Initially, Vivendi is not getting anywhere close to what they think the assets are worth," said Harold Vogel, an independent analyst who follows media companies. "This is a play on how the stock market and the world economy will grow over the next three to five years."
A number of other media giants, including Liberty Media, Viacom, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Comcast, expressed varying degrees of interest in acquiring the properties. But all of them eventually dropped out because they thought the price Vivendi was seeking -- $14 billion -- was too high.
In France, reaction to the drawn-out negotiation has been muted. But SophieL'Helias, an adviser to investor groups here, praised Mr. Fourtou both for his efforts to "make sure Vivendi investors get a better deal" and for the choice of G.E. "They're getting paper, but paper with a company with a reputable track record," she said.
If the outcry in France has been less than might be expected, it is because of the remoteness of Vivendi's American assets, and because Mr. Fourtou has succeeded in placing most of the assets he has sold, like the Houghton Mifflin publishing business, in safe hands.
The greatest outcry came when Vivendi tampered with Canal Plus, which plays a crucial role in French cultural policy by financing many film and television productions.
If Mr. Fourtou has been criticized in France for one thing, it is his supposed lack of a vision for what comes afterward. Elie Cohen, a leading economist and director of research at the National Center for Scientific Research, said the original idea of Mr. Fourtou appeared to have been the reconstruction of the old Compagnie Generale des Eaux, the water and waste group that Mr. Messier transformed in the 1990's through his acquisitions and then renamed Vivendi.
Mr. Fourtou was backed in this by Claude Bebear, the powerful chairman of the AXA insurance group, Mr. Cohen said.
Generale des Eaux was involved mainly in water and waste, telephones and cable television, but a shortage of cash forced Mr. Fourtou to shed Vivendi's holdings in its waste and water business, now known as Veolia Environnement. Moreover, last year he was forced to spend 4 billion euros unexpectedly after the Vodafone group made a hostile takeover bid for Cegetel.
Mr. Fourtou has said that Cegetel and its lucrative cellphone unit, SFR, as well as Canal Plus, the French pay television business that Vivendi owns, would form the core of any future Vivendi. But Mr. Cohen said Vivendi might be facing total liquidation. "The great role of Messier," he said, "was in exploding the group into its constituent parts. And Fourtou is the man who is finishing the job."
Mr. Fourtou, at a news conference after the board meeting, said Vivendi was considering splitting the company in two, one company for its telephone activities and another for the remaining entertainment assets, like music, video games and Canal Plus.
"We have two groups, telecoms and entertainment," he said at the news conference. "Should they remain together? I will allow myself a few months to answer that crucial question."
News of the agreement was met with enthusiasm by investors. Shares of G.E. rose 87 cents, to $30.44. Vivendi's shares closed in Paris at 16.6 euros, up 0.66 euro.
Citigroup and Goldman, Sachs are serving as financial advisers to Vivendi. Weil, Gotshal & Manges is serving as legal counsel to Vivendi Universal. Credit Suisse First Boston and AGM Partners are serving as financial advisers to General Electric and NBC. Debevoise & Plimpton is serving as legal counsel to NBC.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 4, 2003

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Vivendi Universal's agreement to enter exclusive negotiations with General Electric on a merger of their entertainment assets misidentified the parent of the Bravo cable channel. It is NBC, not Vivendi.

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE FOR IRAQ: THE HOME FRONT; 
Backing the Mission in Iraq, But Pondering Its Outcome

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: HUDSON, Fla., Aug. 29 

 BODY:
Not long after President Bush declared an end to the major fighting in Iraq, Jessica Porter hatched an ambitious plan: She would make a quilt for every family of an American soldier who had died in the war. There were about 150 back then, and Jessica, a resolute 19-year-old, had no doubt that she and a few friends could get thejob done.
 Miss Porter has been sewing until her hands ache, but she is not nearly fast enough to keep up with the death toll. Troop fatalities have climbed all summer, and this week the number of soldier deaths after May 1, when Mr. Bush said the significant combat was over, surpassed the 138 who were killed fighting the war. Yet Miss Porter has not given up, just as she has not soured on the dangerous, indefinite occupation of Iraq. 
 "We have to stay there as long as it takes and take care of it once and for all," said Miss Porter, who shares a house in this town north of Tampa with her parents and small mountains of fabric. "No one wants another Sept. 11." 
In and around Tampa -- home to the United States Central Command headquarters, as well as to hundreds of troops still deployed in the Middle East and thousands of military families -- many people share Miss Porter's views, even as they mourn the deaths of American soldiers, at least five of whom are from the area.
If people in the military community around Tampa are troubled, it is not chiefly about the war effort or the stream of bad news from Iraq. Their main frustration is the economy. Such local sentiments echo recent national polls, which show that while Mr. Bush's approval ratings have slipped over the summer, Americans are generally far more concerned about the economy than the continued involvement in Iraq.
In Florida, which still has 2,000 National Guardsmen in the Middle East, a survey conducted in late July by Mason-Dixon Polling and Research found that 57 percent of residents approved of the Iraq invasion.
James Smith, an instructor for the Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps at Brandon High School, about 15 miles east of Tampa, is solidly among the approving. But while Mr. Smith, a retired Army sergeant, might not admit it to his students, he said he was also a little afraid.
"I'm concerned about the uncertainties," said Sergeant Smith, 48, who has been awaiting word from his cousin, Kenneth Johnson, an Army specialist in Tikrit, Iraq. "You've got to ask yourself: How long can you keep your people spread out so far?"
Sergeant Smith, like several others interviewed here, said he thought that other countries, not the United States, should send reinforcements to Iraq. "We can be the lead -- we are the lead -- but we can't conquer it by ourselves," he said. 
This afternoon on Bayshore Drive, Patty Shriver was having similar thoughts, even as she waved a flag alongside a dozen other Tampa residents who call themselves the Bayshore Patriots. The group has waved flags during the Friday rush hour ever since Sept. 11.
They are an optimistic bunch, but today, Mrs. Shriver looked a bit tired. Her son, who is still in Iraq with the 101st Airborne Division, called two weeks ago to say his unit had been given a new mission; he might not be able to contact her for months. Asked how she felt about the war now, Mrs. Shriver sighed. "Sometimes I get to where I think there's never going to be an end to this," she said, "never a point where it's going to be O.K. for them to come home."
Just then, Peggy Chiasson walked up with her son, Cpl. Michael Chiasson, newly back from Iraq. Corporal Chiasson was on the front lines in March, rolling through the Rumaila oil fields and into Baghdad. Morale was good when he left Baghdad last week, he said, because "people are starting to see what they're working for over there."
Even so, he added, other nations should send reinforcements, because the American and British troops were "spread so thin."
In a quiet neighborhood of Tampa, Maj. Andy Stephan, an Air Force reservist who returned from the war in late April after five months, said that continuing the occupation was the right thing to do. 
Major Stephan, who is looking for work after taking a furlough from a commercial airliner, said he did not understand why some troops in Iraq were complaining.
"I have real heartburn about the people you see on television griping about how they're stuck over there," Major Stephan, 37, said as he watched his daughter, Emma, 2, play in their living room. "They talk about 'Everything bad is happening,' but a tremendous amount of change has already occurred."
"Six months from now it will be very different and safer over there," he added, "because we're making it more stable."
Major Stephan's job with the 301st Rescue Squadron was to pluck downed flight crews or special-operations units from behind enemy lines. His unit flew eight missions.
He acknowledged that he was relieved to be back home, watching after Emma most days while his wife, Diane, a pediatrician, works. Unlike the troops who fought in Vietnam, most of whom were single, many soldiers sent to Iraq -- especially reservists and guardsmen -- are married with children.
That made a big difference, Major Stephan said, because he missed Emma and Diane, and because Diane was worried for him.
"It's definitely an older force now," he said, "and there are some things you want to come back to."
Lance Cpl. Kyle Locke of the Fourth Marine Assault Amphibian Battalion never made it to Iraq. Unlike most of his unit, which shipped out in January and returned in June and July, he was among a handful tapped to stay home.
That meant Corporal Locke had to visit the parents of Lance Cpl. Andrew Aviles, one of the youngest members of his unit, and tell them that their 18-year-old son had been killed by enemy fire on April 7. 
"That was the hardest part," Corporal Locke said, staring hard at a wall while Antonio Morales, his barber, went to work on his crew cut. "But you get used to it."
Mr. Morales said that the only thing he hated about the occupation was how it had slowed business at his shop, just outside a gate at MacDill Air Force Base.
"Terrorism doesn't end in Iraq," he said. "I hope we invade Iran."
"Maybe Pakistan," Corporal Locke added.
Corporal Locke, 23, said he enlisted at 17, adding that he would re-enlist for another four years in October. He likes his job maintaining amphibious assault vehicles, and hopes his chance to fight terrorism up close will come soon. Members of his unit who returned from Iraq this summer did not seem traumatized, he said, though he added that they were not inclined to discuss what happened there. "They saw some things out there they probably don't want to talk about," he said.
Back in Hudson, Jessica Porter showed off a photograph of an uncle she never met, a Green Beret who died in a helicopter crash in Vietnam. Yes, Vietnam turned into a quagmire, she said, but that was because politicians and protests interfered and kept the American military from getting its job done. 
Though Miss Porter's mother, Joanne, knows the devastation of having a brother killed in action, she, too, believes the troops should stay in Iraq. Should her own son, Jared, now 17, get drafted, "I'll say, 'You need to go,' " said Mrs. Porter, who is helping her daughter stitch quilts.
Miss Porter, who makes Civil War-period dresses for women taking part in war re-enactments, probably thinks about the American dead in Iraq more than just about anyone who did not know them. She logs onto the Internet every fewdays to check an updated list of casualties, and reads articles about how they died and who they were.
And while the American casualties over all have been fairly light for a war, she has noticed that more reservists and guardsmen are dying now, members of small, relatively unknown units instead of the front-line soldiers who came from the large bases like Fort Hood and Fort Bragg at the start of the war. 
Fourteen quilts have been completed, with 16 more in the works. Amid all Miss Porter's fabric -- one bolt with the Pledge of Allegiance stamped all over it, another with little blue stars, another with burgundy stripes -- she thinks of the soldier as she starts out on each quilt, designing it with his family in mind.
For the widow of Sgt. Michael Bitz, who has twin infants, a baby quilt with four red stars; for the mother of Specialist Brandon Tobler of the Army Reserve, who lives in Oregon, a double-stuffed quilt because Miss Porter figured it was cold out there.
She is not quite sure how her Uncle Joe -- Joseph John Slivka Jr. is how his name reads on the Vietnam Memorial in Washington -- died. Mrs. Porter was told that the helicopter her brother was flying in malfunctioned and that apparently he drowned. Until last week, she had not even told her daughter that Uncle Joe did covert operations.
"I can't believe you didn't tell me!" Miss Porter exclaimed.
"I block a lot of it out of my mind," Mrs. Porter murmured before they headed back to the sewing room, hoping to catch up with the growing list of the dead.

HEADLINE: Concerto for Orchestra and Hopeful City; 
Renewal Project In Detroit Blends A Concert Hall And a School

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
If one absent-minded real estate developer had not forgotten his Jackson Browne cassettes on a business trip 12 years ago, one of the country's most extraordinary urban and cultural development projects might never have happened. But forget he did, and partly as a result the Detroit Symphony Orchestra will move in October back into a renovated version of the hall it occupied during its glory days in the 1930's. There will also be a large new wing to provide space for student orchestras, jazz concerts, dances and other events. 
 The $60 million restoration of Orchestra Hall, which was built in 1919 and attracted performers from Enrico Caruso to Duke Ellington, is part of an unusual rejuvenation strategy. In the mid-1990's, under the guidance of that developer, Peter D. Cummings, a member of the Detroit Symphony board, the orchestra began buying plots of vacant and underused land around Orchestra Hall, near the city's center. On one plot the orchestra built an office building that produced $1.5 million in rental income last year. 
 In its most inspired step, the board arranged to donate a large chunk of its land to the city on condition that a new Detroit High School for the Fine, Performing and Communication Arts be built there. The $122.5 million high school is under construction, and after it opens in 2005, its 1,200 students will study in closer contact with symphony musicians than almost any students anywhere. Detroit Public Television will open a studio there, and there will also be a 50,000-watt AM radio station.
The new school will officially be a merger of two existing ones, both of which are now struggling. The new school is expected to be so desirable that suburban students will apply, something unknown in Detroit for many years.
Mr. Cummings has been the project's driving force, but by his own admission he did not even like classical music until he had an epiphany during a 1991 vacation in Florence.
"It's a bizarre story," he said. "I'm a runner, and I run with headphones on, so I can listen to what I call aging rockers, like Elton John, the Eagles and Jackson Browne. But on this trip I forgot my running shoes and my cassettes. I found a place to buy new shoes, but no cassettes. Finally I found a kiosk on the Piazza del Duomo that had some, classical music only. I blindly pulled down four of them. They turned out to be Mozart piano concertos, and when I put them on, it was like I had never heard them before. I was absolutely bedazzled. Why and how it happened I'll never know."
Mr. Cummings was then moving to Detroit, his wife's hometown, from Florida, where he ran a development company. Soon after his arrival here, he was named to the symphony's board. In 1999 he became its chairman. Mr. Cummings's business experience and his new passion for classical music made him a logical candidate for the board, but there was also another attraction. His father-in-law is the oil tycoon and philanthropist Max M. Fisher, one of the Detroit area's richest men.
It was probably inevitable that other board members would ask Mr. Cummings to approach his father-in-law to help pay for the reconstruction of Orchestra Hall. But when he did, Mr. Fisher was unimpressed. He professed little interest in culture and said he would prefer to give his money to projects aimed at the city's physical and educational revival.
Prodded by Mr. Fisher and by the mayor at the time, Dennis W. Archer, who told orchestra directors that they were "not thinking on a big enough scale," Mr. Cummings began to develop a grander plan.
"The thesis was that in many ways the challenges and problems the Detroit Symphony was facing were urban challenges, neighborhood challenges," he said. "We've gone from being an arts organization focused inward to a cultural citizen looking outward. We're creating a hive of activity here, and the more we have, the more it will beget."
The prospect of a high school that could become a national model of how to integrate performing arts with communication technology has sent a surge of excitement through the city's long-suffering school system. It also persuaded Mr. Fisher to donate $5 million.
"It's ambitious on a scale that's unparalleled in the world as far as I know," said Robert Francis, the school system's executive director for capital improvement. "We're going to be giving inner-city kids opportunities that very few kinds anywhere have, no matter how wealthy or suburban they may be."
The Detroit Symphony has a fabled history and played for millions on national radio broadcasts during the 1930's and 40's, but like many orchestras it had fallen on hard times. Financial troubles forced it to leave Orchestra Hall in 1939 for a succession of sites, including the cavernous and acoustically dreadful Ford Hall, which was its home from 1956 to 1989. It ran up multimillion-dollar deficits and had trouble attracting audiences.
In 1970 a bassoonist, Paul Ganson, discovered that the boarded-up Orchestra Hall was about to be torn down to make room for an Italian restaurant. He rallied the orchestra and the broader community in a campaign to save it, and that campaign turned out to be the forerunner of the grand scheme that is now unfolding.
In recent years the symphony has made special efforts to immerse itself in the life of the surrounding neighborhood. At one special concert it thrilled an almost entirely black audience while accompanying an 800-voice gospel choir. In October it will play in the lobby of a new software company that is opening its doors here.
Whether even this degree of community involvement can save both the orchestra and the city, however, is still uncertain.
"Conditions in the city of Detroit are pretty poor, and this project isn't by any means a silver bullet," said Robin Boyle, a professor of urban planning at Wayne State University here. "It's a positive sign, because it shows a realization that the city can't keep relying on sports stadiums and casinos for economic sustenance. But when the new Orchestra Hall opens, we'll still be facing population decline, job loss, high levels of vacancy, insufficient tax base and everything else."
Revival of the area around Orchestra Hall has already begun, with cafes, boutiques, loft apartments and even a small hotel springing up where a few years ago there was nothing but vacant land and the burned hulks of buildings. Still, planners are holding their applause.
"Without a long-term commitment, the whole project is in danger of withering," Mr. Boyle said. "Projects like these require a great deal of buttressing and supporting. If other developments come in alongside, and if the city focuses its limited resources on improving the area, then we may one day look back on this as a great success. Otherwise I'm not so sure."
The problems that the Detroit Symphony faced as it began this project were comparable to those that confront many orchestras around the country. Dozens of factors have been cited for their declining appeal, from the disappearance of classical music on the radio to the chasm that divides American youth culture from the courtly European societies that produced Mozart and Beethoven.
While many have taken steps to attract young audiences, none have gone so far as to help build a high school next door to its concert hall. Nor are many so fully convinced that their success depends on revitalizing the entire surrounding neighborhood.
"Every major city in America has a symphony orchestra, a public school system and a public TV station, but no city has put them together in a way that builds the orchestra's future, educates students and contributes to the community the way it's being done here," said Emil J. Kang, the orchestra's president and executive director. "We're trying to be truly the Detroit Symphony, not just a symphony that happens to be in Detroit."

HEADLINE: THE POP LIFE; 
Eclectic Mix of Bands, And Likewise of Fans

BYLINE:  By NEIL STRAUSS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
In a time when music festivals, radio-station concerts and package tours all seem to depend on the same small subset of bands to fill their seats, the lineup of the Unlimited Sunshine Tour seems like a joke at first glance. 
 There is Cheap Trick, the late-70's power-rock band known for its impeccable melodies and atrocious fashion sense. Then there's Charlie Louvin, the country, gospel and bluegrass singer whose best-known songs warned against the dangers of alcohol, Satan and atomic power. And the headliner is Cake, the laconic 90's slow-groove rock band whose members hadn't even been born when Mr. Louvin was singing about atomic power. Finally, the Detroit Cobras, a garage-rock cover band, and the Hackensaw Boys, a punk-tinged Americana-roots band. 
 Individually these are all strong acts, but together they are a concert promoter's nightmare. The audiences for most of these acts hardly overlap. It seems doubtful, for example, that a Cheap Trick fan would want to listen to Mr. Louvin singing, "I like the Christian life."
Yet fans at the tour's first stop were remarkably open-minded, at least according to Mr. Louvin, who spoke by telephone from backstage after the tour's kickoff show on Tuesday at the Tabernacle in Atlanta. 
This tour, Mr. Louvin said, has been one of the few times he has been nervous about performing. "I didn't know how it would be," he said, because most audience members were unfamiliar with his music and his legacy. "But it was absolutely great. The audience reaction was at least 120 percent."
Backstage with Mr. Louvin was John McCrea, the singer, songwriter and guitarist in Cake who organized the tour. (It is scheduled to stop at the Roseland Ballroom in Midtown Manhattan on Saturday night.) 
"I always used to make mix tapes when I was a teenager, and this feels similar," Mr. McCrea said of putting together the acts for the tour. His first Sunshine Unlimited roadshow last year was equally diverse, with a high-quality lineup that included the Flaming Lips, De La Soul and Kinky.
"I don't feel like this particular bill is gratuitously eclectic," Mr. McCrea said of this year's assortment. "There's a through line." All the acts, he continued, share a "geometry of classic-style songwriting." 
This is particularly true of the senior act on the tour, Mr. Louvin, who says he is "as old as Methuselah now." (He is actually a spry 76.) And it is also true of the two youngest bands on the bill, the Detroit Cobras, who perform versions of songs by pioneering blues and R&B singers, and the Hackensaw Boys, who find inspiration in the old-time string music of the same era. 
For a person with such diverse taste, Mr. McCrea's own music is surprisingly focused. Cake works within strict musical parameters. Its arrangements are minimal, its rhythms spacious, its melodies exacting, its singing low and wry. One sometimes wonders if Mr. McCrea ever wants to break free of his sound and just belt out a song like Gloria Gaynor, whose "I Will Survive" became a hit in a new incarnation when Cake performed a downbeat, near-monotone version of it.
"It's not appropriate for me or who I am musically," Mr. McCrea said of the prospect of cutting loose. "Our band is about restraint and economy and downsizing."
Like his music, Mr. McCrea speaks slowly and clearly, measuring each word before he says it. 
Unlike other popular rock bands, which tend to have a busy, portentous sound, Cake's aesthetic was not to reach for the stars but to reach "as far as I can jump," Mr. McCrea said.
In keeping with such modest ambitions, Cake has not released an album in two years. "It doesn't seem like a good environment to release an album in," Mr. McCrea said. "I've sort of been stalling and dragging my feet." 
Nonetheless, he has been writing songs, one of which, "Wheels," he plans to perform on some tour dates. He said that he hoped to have a new album out in the spring.
The case is made to Mr. McCrea that releasing albums consistently, as the Beatles did, can be integral to growing and evolving as an artist. He disagreed.
"My perspective is that there's for some reason a paradigm in which we think of artists' having to evolve over a period of time," he said. "Where are they all evolving to? And what are they going to do when they get there? And is that evolution more important than taking each song and making it what it wants to be in terms of production value and arrangements?"
No wonder, then, that the hero of Cake's song "The Distance" is a driver who is still making his way around a racetrack -- "pacing and plotting the course" -- even though every other driver has long since crossed the finish line, the stands have emptied and day has turned to night.
Musically, this seems to be Cake's goal: to have the longevity of the driver in "The Distance" or of Mr. Louvin, whose first rock-'n'-roll-related bill featured a young Elvis Presley as an opening act.
Music historians have said that the Louvin Brothers -- the seminal country act featuring the close-harmony singing of Mr. Louvin and his younger brother, Ira -- broke up around 1963 because their music was pushed aside by rock 'n' roll. It is fitting to see Mr. Louvin, whose music helped inspire the country-rock boom of the early 70's, capturing the hearts of a modern rock audience once more 40 years later.
But Mr. Louvin had a different explanation for the breakup. 
"It wasn't because of rock 'n' roll; it was because of liquor," he said, referring to his brother, who died in a car crash in 1964. "I didn't know how to handle a drunk. My brother was a professional drunk." 
Mr. Louvin said that he decided to leave the band "before we went down the tubes together."
Mr. Louvin said he was looking forward to the tour's final stop on Sept. 21 in Hollywood, where he has never performed.
After the tour, Mr. McCrea said he wanted to continue pursuing his longtime dream of starting a television show, "Freedom of Speech." In perfect Hollywood-pitch fashion he described the show as " 'Politically Incorrect' meets 'The Gong Show' meets 'American Idol.' "

HEADLINE: Koch and City Workers 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Bloomberg and City Unions Draw the Lines, Far Apart" (news article, Aug. 19):
 You write: "John V. Lindsay's tenure was defined by strikes, the first one hitting only hours after he was sworn in. 
Edward I. Koch and Rudolph W. Giuliani started off talking tough, but ended up awarding hefty raises to municipal workers that left the city in a bind when recessions hit." 
 An analysis of the labor contracts entered into during the 12 years of my administration establishes that over this period, civilian employees received general wage increases of 94.9 percent; uniform force employees, 110.7 percent, for a weighted average of approximately 98.8 percent. 
Over the same period, the Consumer Price Index increased by 104 percent, and private-sector salaries in the Northeast increased by 103 percent.
During the Koch administration, wages and salaries of city employees increased more slowly than wages and salaries in the private sector.

EDWARD I. KOCH
New York, Sept. 2, 2003

HEADLINE: China Agrees to Free Trading in Its Currency, but Not Now 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary John W. Snow and his Chinese counterparts agreed today that China should eventually allow its currency to trade freely on international markets. But Beijing rejected calls to move quickly in that direction, saying it might cause financial instability in China and abroad.
 Mr. Snow faces political pressure to push China to raise the value of its currency, the yuan. Some Democratic presidential candidates and industry groups have argued that China keeps the currency deliberately undervalued to promote exports to America, which they say has caused job losses in the United States. 
 Last year China had the largest trade surplus with the United States of any country, $103 billion, though it runs a modest global trade surplus. 
Mr. Snow left China today after a two-day visit without a specific timetable for addressing the currency issue. But he said Chinese officials assured him that they would take "interim steps" to loosen restrictions on the country's tightly controlled financial system. 
"On the currency issue in particular, I was encouraged to hear a reaffirmation of China's longstanding goal to move toward greater flexibility," Mr. Snow said. "I was assured that interim policy steps are now being taken and progress in this area will continue." 
China's central bank governor, Zhou Xiaochuan, struck a conciliatory tone with Mr. Snow in lengthy comments released by state media. He promised that the value of the yuan would eventually be determined by market forces rather than being fixed at 8.3 to the dollar, as it has been for almost a decade.
Mr. Zhou also outlined a variety of measures that he said would "allow the market to play a bigger role" in China's financial system. Among them are new regulations to allow foreigners to invest in yuan-denominated securities, and corresponding rules that allow some domestic investors to buy securities abroad. Mr. Snow said the discussion also included ways to make it easier for Chinese individuals and companies to buy American stocks and bonds, helping to recycle some of China's export earnings into American investments. 
Mr. Zhou said China planned to encourage companies to invest more overseas. Exporters will also soon be allowed to keep more of the foreign currency they earn, which could prompt them to import more goods. Beijing also announced new rules on the amount of foreign currency Chinese tourists and business executives can takeon trips abroad. 
Finally, Mr. Zhou also said for the first time that China would consider revising the pegged currency system to link the yuan to other currencies as well as the dollar. Because the dollar has declined against many other currencies this year, any such move to link the yuan to a broader basket of currencies could prompt at least a modest rise in the value of the yuan against the dollar. 
Chinese state media have trumpeted the decision to stick by the currency system, at least for now, as a sign that the government can resist what one newspaper called "international browbeating." If implemented fully, the steps Mr. Zhou outlined would amount to a concerted attempt to respond to record inflows of foreign currency to China without remaking the currency system. 
Some measures have been under consideration for weeks or months. But the fact that they were highlighted during Mr. Snow's visit represented a clear effort to address American complaints and channel some of China's recent financial gains into overseas markets, analysts said. 
"China authorities are sensitive to the politics of this issue in the United States and want to be viewed as responding," Andy Xie, chief Asia economist of Morgan Stanley, said.

HEADLINE: Mortgage Index Declines 

BYLINE:  By BloombergNews 

 BODY:
An index of applications for mortgages fell for the fourth consecutive week, to the lowest in more than a year, as rising loan rates discouraged refinancing, an industry report showed. 
 The Mortgage Bankers Association of America's measure of mortgage applications dropped 1.6 percent, to 628.7 last week, the lowest since June 14, 2002. The refinancing index declined 8.6 percent, to 1,981.5. 
 The refinancing gauge has declined 80 percent since reaching a high at the end of May, the biggest three-month drop since record-keeping began in 1990. 
The mortgage group's purchase index increased 5.5 percent, to 396.1 from 375.5. A record of 460.5 was set in the final week of May. 
The association is based in Washington.

HEADLINE: Construction and Business Conditions Picking Up, Reports Say 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 

 BODY:
Business conditions perked up in the summer and construction spending climbed in July to the highest level since the beginning of the year, according to government reports released today. They offered promising signs for the economy's anticipated rebound in the second half.
 Reports from the Federal Reserve's 12 districts "indicate that the economy continued to improve in July and August," according to the Fed's latest snapshot of business activity. "In some districts, improvement occurred in selected sectors, and in others it was broad-based," the Federal Reserve said. 
 The Fed, in its so-called beige book, added that even in the Dallas district, where activity remained generally weak, business contacts were more optimistic.
The effect of the nation's worst blackout was muted thus far, the Fed indicated. Although business contacts said a comprehensive assessment at this point was premature, "the effects were generally small," the Fed survey said. "Even where firms were closed for several days, affected contacts suggest they are not anticipating difficulties in making up for lost production or shipments."
In a second report, the value of construction projects under way came in at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $879.8 billion in July, representing a modest 0.2 percent increase from June's level, the Commerce Department said.
Although the increase in July was not as big as the 0.5 percent rise that economists were predicting, the June performance turned out even better than the government previously estimated. Revised figures show that construction spending was up by a brisk 0.7 percent in June from May, compared with the earlier estimate of 0.3 percent.
The pace of construction spending in July was the highest level since January, when such spending stood at $883.2 billion on an annualized basis.
Recent economic reports have flashed signals that the economy is healing and on track to stage a material recovery in the second half of this year. Consumers are spending, manufacturing appears on the mend and businesses are slowly increasing investment, although they are cautious about hiring.
In the Fed's latest survey, 10 of its 12 districts reported increases in manufacturing activity. The exceptions were Dallas, which showed little change, and Richmond, Va., where factory activity weakened.
The construction spending report showed that spending by private builders on all types of projects rose by a solid 0.5 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $664.2 billion, the highest level since March.
Private builders had gains in residential projects as well as communications and power sites. Those gains were tempered by weakness elsewhere, including declines in spending on hotels and motels and office buildings.
"The long nightmare of double-digit declines in private, nonresidential construction seems to have ended, but it is still a little early to say the upward climb had taken hold," said Ken Simonson, chief economist at Associated General Contractors of America.
Spending by the government on big public works projects, meanwhile, dropped 0.4 percent in July, to a rate of $215.7 billion. The government cut spending on schools, highways and streets. That outweighed increased spending on other projects including public safety sites and hospitals and other health care buildings.

HEADLINE: Big Investors Urged to Unite For Reforms 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
The New York State comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, proposed yesterday that big investors should work together to try to prevent more corporate scandals like those that hurt shareholders and employees of Enron and WorldCom.
 At an annual conference of institutional investors in California, Mr. Hevesi called for the creation of the National Coalition for Corporate Reform, which would try to influence the behavior of companies through proxy voting, litigation and lobbying. He said the supporters of his idea included the treasurers of California and North Carolina and labor leaders like the presidents of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. 
 But Mr. Hevesi, who oversees $90 billion in retirement funds, said in an interview that he had not yet sought or received backing from any large mutual fund companies like Fidelity Investments or the Vanguard Group. Most big fund companies have been reticent to join public battles with corporate executives or directors, blunting the effect of efforts by shareholder activists.
Mr. Hevesi said he hoped they would join after hearing his presentation yesterday to the Council of Institutional Investors.
"The history of scandal in America is that after a few months or half a year, the public turns their attention elsewhere," Mr. Hevesi said. "That's why scandals are repeated."
Investors cannot afford to ignore corporate governance, he said, because the cost of major scandals has been too high. Citing a study by the Brookings Institution as a model, he estimated that recent corporate scandals reduced economic activity in New York in the 2003 fiscal year by $2.9 billion and cost the state $1 billion in tax revenue.
"This was not just injury to companies that went bankrupt, their employees who lost their jobs and their retirees who lost their retirement savings, this hurt every taxpayer in America," Mr. Hevesi said. "The first challenge is to have everybody understand how damaging these scandals were."
The Sarbanes-Oxley Act that Congress enacted to clean up corporations is "very good reform legislation" that is getting a lot of attention now, he said. But the responsibility for enforcing it falls not to a department of the federal government but to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Independent regulatory bodies have a tendency to lose focus, Mr. Hevesi said. "They clean up the problem, then six years later," he added, they move on.
Mr. Hevesi has joined in shareholder lawsuits against big companies, including WorldCom and Cendant. He said his office was seeking to hire as many as a dozen lawyers to represent it in other litigation.
