HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "THE AMERICAN EFFECT: GLOBAL PERSPECTIVES ON THE UNITED STATES, 1990-2003," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Oct. 12). Exploring ways that artists throughout the world react to the United States as a superpower, this show of documentary films, videos, installations, photographs, paintings and objects by 47 artists and filmmakers and 3 collaborative groups runs from sunny side up to deep despair. There are reflections on America's military might, its industrial clout, its treatment of minorities, its consumerism, its justice system, its marketing strategies, its religious evangelism, its celebrity worship and its interference with other governments. On the other hand, there are more positive expressions of admiration for the freedoms, the opportunities and the material achievements of a country unfettered by ancient traditions. A wacky installation by a French artist, Gilles Barbier, in the form of life-size figures, offers a wry take on the United States through its aging comic book heroes, viewed in the setting of a nursing home and in the last stages of decrepitude. In a very different key is a video projection dealing with the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas in 1963; the work, by a Serbian artist, Zoran Naskovski, is accompanied by a poignantly chanted tribute. The show has its weak spots but is provocative and visually compelling over all. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

"ANSEL ADAMS AT 100," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Nov. 3). This exhibition of 113 of Adams's photographs, in celebration of the 100th anniversary of his birth, has been traveling around the world for two years. In these warehouse galleries it has a strangely random and homely feel. The photographs look small and lost. Maybe it's the setting. Maybe it's because the show, organized roughly thematically -- austere peaks, plants, peaks with plants, grand vistas, rocks -- doesn't have a clearly focused concept. Or maybe it's because the curator wanted to tamp down Adams's bombast and replace it with something quieter, smaller and subtler. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays to 7:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Sarah Boxer).

* MAX BECKMANN, Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 29). Like Beckmann, this retrospective of that German genius is dense, frequently revelatory and exhausting: all that heavy-handed symbolism and claustrophobia. Beckmann can seem like a truculent master, glaring balefully at us from his self-portraits, disappointed by our moral turpitude. It is easy to get bogged down in the miasma of his obscure allusions. But he also puts brush to canvas with surprising tenderness. Color is luxurious, not garish. The humor is sly and black. Finally, he is unavoidably compelling. Hours and admission: See above (Michael Kimmelman).

* "BLACK PRESIDENT: THE ART AND LEGACY OF FELA ANIKULAPO-KUTI," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 28). The Nigerian composer, musician and activist Fela Kuti (1938-1997) invented the musical style called Afrobeat, relentlessly assailed political corruption and repression in Africa and beyond through his records and performances and led a scandalous private life very publicly. This taut, vivacious exhibition is less about the man himself than about how 30 contemporary artists, most of them African or African-American, respond to his blazing, goading lodestar presence. Their reactions range from celebratory to critical, and few are simple, but his vision of a rejuvenated Africa still shines bright. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

"LOUISE BOURGEOIS: THE INSOMNIA DRAWINGS," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Sept. 21). In an eight-month run of sleep-short nights, the sculptor Louise Bourgeois turned the draggy hours to productive use, setting down thoughts, visions and memories that rose from the floor of her consciousness. What resulted are 250 drawings, considered one work by the artist, that range from simple to complex images: among them water, mazes, clocks, houses, abstract doodles, personal comments and fragments of texts. In short, a miscellany of clues to her inner and outer worlds, a scrap bag of images that may prompt her work. But while the dense, insistent visual environment they create is a bit of a phenomenon, the viewer does not really come away with a deeper understanding of the work, whose relationship to Ms. Bourgeois's deeply mined psyche is very evident in her realized art and in statements and interviews she has given over the years. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

"SALVADOR DALI: DREAM OF VENUS," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Sept. 21). While images of the 1939 New York World's Fair in Queens remain ingrained in the American collective memory, one attraction, relegated to the "Amusement Zone," was largely forgotten until now: Dali's "Dream of Venus," a tacky Surrealist fun house with live, semi-nude women. This exhibition consists mainly of photographs that document the project from start to finish. Featuring the handsome, charismatic artist; his enigmatic wife, Gala; and lots of voluptuous, unclothed models, this show and its catalog tell a fascinating tale of idealism, opportunism, provocation and censorship. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 55+ (Ken Johnson).

"DRAWN HOME: FRITZ VOGT'S RURAL AMERICA," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through Sept. 21). During the last decade of the 19th century, Vogt, a German immigrant, supported himself by making portraits of homes in upstate New York. A homeless itinerant who preferred to sleep in his patrons' barns, Vogt made wonderfully lucid, formally ingenious drawings of farms with multiple outbuildings and of elaborately decorated Victorian showpieces with manicured grounds. The 26 drawings here tap into an American ethos that elevated domestic prosperity to something like a national religion. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Admission: $9; $7, students and 62+ (Johnson).

* "EGYPT REBORN: ART FOR ETERNITY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (permanent installation). The second and final phase in the museum's reinstallation of its world-renowned holdings of ancient Egyptian art, this dazzling display rounds up more than 600 objects -- from king-and-queen-size monuments to tiny rings and amulets -- from the predynastic period to the 18th dynasty. Viewing it together with the first phase, which opened in 1993 and covers later Egyptian art, visitors will now be able to trace the entire course of this brilliant and complex civilization from its beginnings to its absorption by the Roman Empire in 30 B.C. The heart of the new installation is an introductory gallery that provides a wonderful summation, with a survey of sculptural styles and displays of weapons, pottery, cosmetics, jewelry, furniture and funerary arts. The adjacent galleries are devoted to an extensive chronological survey. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and 62+ (Glueck).

* "FROM EXPRESSIONISM TO THE BAUHAUS: HIGHLIGHTS FROM THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through Sept. 15). Borrowed from the Museum of Modern Art, this economical, powerfully resonant exhibition of German Modernist artworks from the first third of the 20th century includes Expressionist paintings by Ludwig Kirchner, Otto Mueller and Emil Nolde; mordantly satiric New Realist paintings by George Grosz and Otto Dix; and sumptuously elegant utilitarian objects by Marcel Breuer and Marianne Brandt. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+ (Johnson).

"FROM PICASSO TO POLLOCK: CLASSICS OF MODERN ART," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 28). This selective anthology of perennial in-house favorites in a major museum has much to be said for it. The bait is irresistible, the promised classics turn up here and there, and both the young and the not-so-young have a fine time on the ramps. In addition to fine examples by Kandinsky, Picasso, Leger, Chagall, Kokoschka and Malevich, there is an enormous piece in ceramic tiles by Joan Miro. Begun in 1965 and finished in 1967, it is largely in black-and-white, but every touch of color sings out. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $15; $10 for students and 65+ (John Russell).

* "GREAT WAVES: CHINESE THEMES IN THE ARTS OF KOREA AND JAPAN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 21). Basically a collection reinstallation with a novel mix-and-match approach, this show, spread over both the Chinese painting and Japanese galleries, traces the flow of influence from one culture to the other. Most of the action takes place in the Chinese galleries, where the art is arranged by motifs -- seascapes, landscapes, floral images -- that emerged early in China and circulated to Korea and Japan. The model proposed will provide grist for many scholarly mills in the future; the show itself is tremendous fun to look at. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

JOSE ANTONIO HERNANDEZ-DIEZ, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 21). Born in Venezuela in 1964, Mr. Hernandez-Diez is one of several urbane Latin American artists whose work might be described as a kind of vernacular conceptualism, a physically reductive, idea-rich art made from scraps of everyday consumerist life. His New Museum solo incorporates skateboards, household furniture, a stuffed pet dog, fake fingernails, baseball bats and photographs of designer sneakers, all put to unexpected uses. The results can be read in terms of local associations, but the real focus is on commonly shared experiences: appetite, rootlessness, faith and delusion, violence, the collective unconscious of globalized culture. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

ELLSWORTH KELLY, "Red Green Blue," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Nov. 2). Mr. Kelly was the Chet Baker of the new, cool painters of the post-Abstract Expressionist generation. From the late 50's to the mid-60's he produced a series of paintings using the colors red, blue and green. On view in this show, they still sing. With their optically dazzling, high-keyed colors, their catchy, simplified designs and their satiny, brush-free surfaces, the paintings communicate the excitement of a new hedonistic optimism that did so much to make the 60's what it was. Hours and admission: See above (Johnson).

"LEGENDS OF OUR TIMES: NATIVE RANCHING AND RODEO LIFE ON THE PLAINS AND THE PLATEAU," National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through March 7). This lively account of man, woman and horse among the native people in Western reaches of the United States and Canada proves that a cowboy can be an Indian, and vice versa. The show depicts native peoples not as objects of exploitation by the white man but as ranchers, cowboys, entertainers and rodeo performers. It displays more than 700 objects -- saddles, bead and quill works, paintings, photographs, blankets, clothing, horse gear, hunting implements, roundup equipment, headdresses and other ceremonial garb -- from the 18th century to now. At least half of this huge show provides an engaging and comprehensive account of rodeo, but nonrodeo fans will probably have more fun with the bedazzlement of objects depicting the more traditional side of American Indian life. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free (Glueck).

"MATERIAL DIFFERENCES: ART AND IDENTITY IN AFRICA," Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through Oct. 6). Part Art Methods 101, part Advanced Connoisseurship, this handsome, thoughtful show examines the potent connection between matter and meaning in diverse African cultures and shows them to be organically connected. The material is spiritual in these cultures, and the show's 130 mostly ceremonial objects, arranged strictly according to materials and techniques, reflect the power of that belief. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

"NOGUCHI -- THE BOLLINGEN JOURNEY: PHOTOGRAPHS AND DRAWINGS, 1949-1956," Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum (temporary space), 36-01 43rd Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, (718) 204-7088 (through Oct. 13). More than 100 photographs and drawings recreate Noguchi's travels from 1949 to 1956, on a grant from the Bollingen Foundation. The project was for an ambitious book (never completed) on the spaces and structures -- religious, monumental, classical and communal -- of familiar as well as less-documented societies. Besides providing an elegant travelogue, the photographs give some idea of the many sources that Noguchi drew on for his work. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Glueck)

"THE PERFECT GAME: AMERICA LOOKS AT BASEBALL," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through Feb. 1). This sweet and nearly pitch-perfect show is not a documentary of the sport. It is an elaborate illustration of a shared loved affair with a game, expressed, as love often is, through art. Joe DiMaggio and Cy Young do not tip their caps anywhere in it. But George Sosnak does. A retired minor league umpire, he intricately decorated baseballs with India ink, elaborately annotated, in his spare time. John Tracy, a Union soldier in a Confederate prison, carved baseball scenes onto a cane to pass time and save himself from going nuts. Ray Materson sewed pictures of his favorite Yankees while serving a 15-year sentence for armed robbery. And David Mellor, who is in charge of the grounds at Fenway Park in Boston, rolls the grass into fantastic patterns for the folks in the stands to enjoy. Call it folk art for the masses, which is not a bad definition for baseball, by the way. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

"PULP ART: VAMPS, VILLAINS AND VICTORS FROM THE ROBERT LESSER COLLECTION," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Oct. 19). This murky exhibition showcases the small, gaudy, largely unappreciated paintings commissioned for the covers of the pulp magazines that ruled the newsstands between the wars. While ultimately a bit repetitious, their overheated depictions of sharp-jawed heroes, compromised heroines and various human and nonhuman villains highlight talents like George Rozen and Paul R. Frank. They also give vent to the dark, violent, libidinous underbelly of the American psyche, to the same degree that Norman Rockwell's paintings bless its wholesome, repressed, preternaturally sunny side. The show is essential viewing for anyone interested in popular culture past or present. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

"REMEMBERING THE FORGOTTEN ONES: MILTON ROGOVIN," New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (through Oct. 12). Mr. Rogovin, who is 93, has been photographing the residents of Buffalo's Lower West Side, a largely black, Latino and immigrant neighborhood, since the 1950's. Wonderful images have emerged: a benignly smiling elderly man pushing a baby in a carriage; alert kids dressed in cool street styles; a teenage mother standing with her infant in front of a wall bearing the chalk-written words "I love you God." At regular intervals, Mr. Rogovin has rephotographed some of his original subjects, and he displays the updates in four-picture sequences that he calls quartets. In them, couples marry and have families; change homes, partners and eras; gain weight, gain perspective, disappear. Sad, traumatic or sweet, these visual versions of oral history are the highlight of the show. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

"VIETNAM: JOURNEYS OF BODY, MIND AND SPIRIT," American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100 (through Jan. 4). For many Americans who came of age before or during the 1960's, Vietnam was the name of a place you didn't want to go to. Even today the prevailing impression of this part of Southeast Asia seems to be a composite of remembered news clips and scenes from "Apocalypse Now." More than a quarter-century after the war, the image is due for revision, and that is the basic idea behind this show, a lavishly illustrated anthropological field trip through Vietnam today. Using objects, videos and photographs, it examines popular traditions associated with marriage, death and religion, often to vivid effect, in a lively, serpentine installation. And even with many important political and social questions left unasked and unanswered, there is a wealth of information here. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $9, students and 60+ (Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

"BAUHAUS/NEW BAUHAUS," Ubu Gallery, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444 (Thursday through Oct. 4; by appointment through Wednesday). A selection of 79 photographic works by 30 artists who taught or studied at the Bauhaus in Germany (1919 to 1933) and the New Bauhaus in Chicago (founded in 1937), this richly informative show evokes a euphoric excitement about all the new things that could be done with photography. From Laszlo Moholy-Nagy's experiments with the photogram to Aaron Siskind's classically austere picture of industrial silos, it takes us back to one of the more exciting futures of this world-altering medium (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

* HELMUT FEDERLE, "Works on Paper," Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through Sept. 13). From the mid-1970's to the late 1990's, the Swiss-born painter Helmut Federle extended his imagery from geometricized but lush mountain peaks to the freest of signs and markings. The 200 drawings on view here trace his progress. Although the work remains in a highly reductive geometricized mode, it is sometimes quirkily dreamy and sensuous, with more than a touch of whimsy. In these 200 drawings, which gain strength from being grouped together, Mr. Federle's many and varied passes at the paper range from the precise scientific textbook rendering "Constellation" (1983) to more relaxed and painterly grids like "Untitled" (1992), in which eroded bright blue bands are dragged across a white ground. He is a great performer; even his most fragmentary wisps hold the eye (Glueck).

Galleries: Chelsea

* "IN FULL VIEW," Andrea Rosen, 525 West 24th Street, (212) 627-6000 (through Sept. 13). A show that invites visitors on a pluralistic treasure hunt for 18 artworks that tease one's limits of visual perception. Look for Christopher Chiappa's Ford Taurus gas-tank door built into the wall; Maurizio Cattelan's roosting stuffed pigeons; Vincent Shine's tiny, gold Brancusian wasp; Jim Hodges's jewelry-chain spider web; and Charles Ray's classic "Rotating Disc" (Johnson).

ANDREI MOLODKIN, Kashya Hildebrand, 531-539 West 25th Street, (212) 366-5757 (through Sept. 13). This skillful Russian draftsman has a heavy-handed way with popular and political symbols. He draws giant parodies of "I Love N.Y." or "I Love Sex" bumper stickers, replacing the valentine heart with anatomically accurate skulls. Also on view is a double portrait of Lenin and Stalin. What's most interesting is not the imagery but how these enormous drawings are made: entirely with a blue ballpoint pen (Johnson).

"THIS IS LAGOS: YABIS NIGHT, MUSIC AND FELA," Skoto, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-8058 (through Sept. 20). If you crave a second fix of the charismatic Nigerian musician Fela Anikulapo-Kuti after seeing "Black President" at the New Museum, Skoto is the place to go. Much of this gallery's fine summer show is devoted to vivid pictures of Fela by the Nigerian photographer Femi Bankole Osunla, who was part of Fela's inner circle from the early 1970's to the musician's death from AIDS in 1997. This work is complemented by a handsome series of color images of Africa by the American photographer Howard T. Cash, two heads sculptured by Osaretin Ighile and an altarlike installation by the young American artist Sol Sax (Cotter).

* "TODAY'S MAN," John Connelly Presents, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 337-9563 (through Sept. 13). This dandy group show includes some 50 small pieces by as many artists, from senior figures like Alex Katz and A. A. Bronson, to a raft of youthful prodigies. The theme, men making art about men, naturally raises expectations of a "gay" show, which "Today's Man" both is and is not. Explicit homoeroticism is all but absent. Most of the artists who are gay are too young to have experienced AIDS and the identity politics of the 1990's first hand, and have scant interest in we're-here-we're-queer declarations. A result is an unassuming, shorthand new-talent survey of some of the masculinities currently operating between the presumed opposites of gay and straight (Cotter).

"VACATION," Spike, 547 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4100 (through Sept. 20). Innocence and experience collide in the works of Norm Magnusson, who outlines juvenile, coloring-book-style images over gridded fields of pages from pointedly selected books. Jesus offering guidance to a little boy is drawn over pages from Bulfinch's "Mythology," for example, and paper-doll clothes over "Lolita." Also on view: Buck Henri's engaging photographs of exotic dancers, old cars, mannequins, small-town parades and other subjects; Alan Schmer's illustrative paintings of farm animals; and Melissa Stern's pedestal-size figurative sculptures that blend Surrealism and primitivism (Johnson).

Other Galleries

"MIRACLE IN THE SCRAP HEAP: THE SCULPTURE OF RICHARD STANKIEWICZ," AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, (212) 554-4818 (through Sept. 25). Welded together from scrap metal, Mr. Stankiewicz's slyly figurative semi-abstract sculptures from the mid-1950's were early warning signs that Abstract Expressionism was losing traction, and more worldly subjects, materials and ideas were bubbling up all around. His ingeniously composed works lived up to titles like "Kabuki Dancer," "Urchin," "Marionette," "Middle-Aged Couple" and "Family Portrait" with the spine-tingling accuracy of unusually art-savvy cartoons. They expanded upon Cubism, rebuked the prevailing lugubriousness of postwar sculpture and predicted many aspects of Pop and Minimalism. But they were too respectful of tradition to withstand the double-barreled onslaught of those movements. Organized by the Addision Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., this thoughtful show is the first Stankiewicz retrospective in New York. His penchant for compositional complexity, cartoonish figuration and the two-timing of the abstract and the representational seem pertinent and full of possibility (Smith).

Last Chance

"BOYS OF SUMMER," ClampArt, 531 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (646) 230-0020 (through tomorrow). If you like to look at men, stop in. Standing out among the crowd of pictures by more than two dozen photographers are "Bruce in His Car," a 1981 portrait of a skinny bohemian in his big red convertible by Nan Goldin; a beefy, shirtless young football player celebrating with his team, by Brian Finke; men in leather, by Barbara Nitke; and, by Malerie Marder, a large color image of a mixed-sex group of naked people relaxing in a California bathhouse (Johnson).

* "HENDRICK GOLTZIUS, DUTCH MASTER (1558-1617): DRAWINGS, PRINTS AND PAINTINGS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). Goltzius (1558-1617) was one of the hottest of hotshot Dutch artists. He was particularly celebrated for his engravings, many of them mythological tableaus of pumped-up gods and pinup goddesses, rendered in the Mannerist way with flabbergasting elan. But he was also one of the great draftsmen of his age -- his landscape drawings prefigure Rembrandt and Ruisdael -- and became a virtuosic painter whose primary subject was bare human flesh: its texture, its color, its chemistry. To some eyes he remains strictly a period artist; to others he connects to the present in interesting ways. This Met show offers the raw materials for both reactions. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "LANDSCAPE OF MEMORY: THE ART OF MU XIN," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400 (through Sunday). The artist and writer Mu Xin, born into a wealthy aristocratic family in China, received a classical scholar's education and early exposure to Western culture. Targeted as a dissident during the Cultural Revolution, he was held in solitary confinement for 18 months, and he secretly wrote a series of first-person meditations now called "Prison Notes," which he carried out of jail sewn in his clothes. Under house arrest several years later, he executed a remarkable series of small landscape paintings in which traditional Chinese themes meet Leonardo da Vinci. The paintings and some of "Prison Notes" are brought together in this lean, penumbral exhibition, organized by the Yale University Art Gallery and the David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art at the University of Chicago. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"SPLIT," Sandra Gering, 534 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (646) 336-7183 (through tomorrow). The best thing in this six-person show is Xavier Veilhan's bigger-than-life skeleton woven in wicker; it slouches casually in a corner of the gallery, a marvel of exotic faux-folk art. Note, too, a dense mix of cartoon characters and abstract patterning painted collaboratively in gouache by Christian Schumann and Gary Panter (Johnson).

"WILLEM VAN TETRODE: BRONZE SCULPTURES OF THE RENAISSANCE," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Sunday). This exhibition introduces a neglected Dutch artist who flourished amid the cultural ferment of 16th-century Italy, when the rediscoveries of monumental Classical marbles helped fuel a passion for mythological themes, the rise of private collecting and a new sense of physical and emotional drama in sculpture. Prodigiously talented, he navigated his own path between Classicism and Mannerism with beautifully detailed bronzes, most notably a splendidly muscled and bearded Hercules. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Smith).

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Mask" (1958), by Ellsworth Kelly, at the Whitney Museum. (Photo by David P. Robinson/Ellsworth Kelly); Men making art about men: A partial view of the 50-artist exhibition "Today's Man" at the John Connelly Presents gallery in Chelsea. (Photo by John Connelly Presents)

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 29

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
If the Actual Amazon Is Far Away, Invent One Nearby

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
You probably won't need 98 minutes to get the point of "The Origin of the Night: Amazon Cosmos," a film by the German Conceptualist Lothar Baumgarten. A beautiful, elegiac but largely unsuspenseful meditation on the Brazilian rain forest and the creation stories of the Tupi Indians, this rarely seen movie was made between 1973 and 1977. It is being shown in New York for the first time, in continuous screenings at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
 The film is an evocative and affecting work, even if you're not familiar with its arcane narrative about an ancestral fall from grace that cast the world, until then sunny around the clock, into darkness for half of each day. (Mr. Baumgarten took the story from Claude Levi-Strauss's book "From Honey to Ashes.") 
 Centering exclusively on a damp swamp setting, the film intimates a geographical location with an opening massing of the names of Amazon Indian tribes and indigenous plants and animals. It proceeds to examine the terrain, mostly at close range, as time cycles from darkness to light and back to darkness -- coming noisily to life and then closing down for the night. 
But long before the end of "The Origin of the Night," you'll probably figure out that it was shot not in the Amazon at all, but somewhere in the Northern Hemisphere. At that point you will either walk out or await official confirmation in the closing credits: these specify the Rhein-Walder, forests along the Rhine near the artist's home in Dusseldorf, Germany. (He also has a home in New York.) 
This film offers an important piece of the expanding puzzle of 70's art, but it also tries your patience. After all, it harks back to a time when artists were looking at the natural world with a new directness and taking their time about it. Testing your patience was part of it; the only good time was real time, or something close. 
Mr. Baumgarten, who is nearly 60, is a former student of Joseph Beuys and represented Germany at the 1984 Venice Biennale. He has been known since the late 1970's for scattering the names of vanished or vanishing North and South American Indian tribes across the walls, and occasionally the floors, of museums and galleries. 
His primary subject is the passage of time and the changes it brings: in nature, human knowledge, economics and power. The most basic form of power is the power to name, to separate out and identify parts of the world; or, in the case of colonialism, to claim them by renaming. Thus Mr. Baumgarten selects words that evoke the peoples, places and cultures that have been adversely affected by Western civilization and the march of what is sometimes called progress. His intent is simultaneously to raise social and political consciousness and expand our sense of the world's richness through a spatial and visual experience of language. 
This experience is often moving as well as elegant, even dazzling. It was especially prominent in what is possibly his largest, most widely reproduced work, "America: Invention," created in 1993 for the Guggenheim Museum in New York. Covering the museum's entire interior with large letters spelling out tribal names and turning its spiral rotunda into a dynamic vortex of language, this installation was part memorial, part anthropological index, part advertising and part art. 
There is a selfless, saintly aspect to much of Mr. Baumgarten's work that makes you long for an outburst of ego and temperament. But his generation was in many ways more transfixed by reality and sheer information than by art.
This film reminds us that Mr. Baumgarten is a kindred spirit to a group of artists who, basically, took the painting out of landscape painting, transferring its grandeur to various combinations of language, film, sculpture, photography and the great outdoors itself. The generation included Richard Long and Hamish Fulton, who combined words and photographs, as Mr. Baumgarten also has upon occasion, and Robert Smithson, who was mesmerized by entropy. It also included Nancy Graves, whose lifesize sculptures of camels might almost -- but not quite -- fit into a natural history museum diorama and whose films of flocks of birds sweeping back and forth against the sky have an accumulating power and monotony that relates to Mr. Baumgarten's film. 
In "The Origin of the Night," the camera flits deftly among images of dense undergrowth, tree trunks and leafy tops. Sometimes you sense a structuralist impulse to constantly reiterate the film's surface with close-ups of natural ones. The camera also zooms in on frogs' eyes and a turtle's shell and skin almost to the point of abstractness. The clouds range from pink to stormy and at one point deliver a violent thunderstorm.
No humans are visible, although occasionally you see the tip or side of the artist's red-and-blue inflated canoe; he's a solitary explorer in the wilderness. Mainly there is water, sometimes black and brackish, sometimes sparkling, whether with the light of the moon, the pinkness of dawn or the golden glow of sunset. The water can be dotted with powwowing frogs or squadrons of water spiders and is rife with fish, fallen trees, vines and floating leaves. Some of the most beautiful images silhouette birds on bare branches against the late afternoon sky.
The film's rhythmic scannings are accompanied by the clamor of jungle life -- unseen monkeys, parrots, growling beasts, woodpeckers. But as time passes, you begin to notice the absence of genuinely tropical trees and undergrowth; the drab coloration of the few visible birds and reptiles; the bits of trash underfoot; and the frequency of low-flying jumbo jets overhead. 
Some of the words that periodically appear on the screen -- mimicry, imitation -- may start to raise your suspicions about the assumptions encouraged by those clusters of names that appeared at the film's beginning. As the the fictive power of the camera becomes increasingly evident, we also experience firsthand the primacy of language, one of Mr. Baumgarten's central themes, and its ability to trick the eye. The distance between the "civilized" and "natural" collapses; notions of the exotic and of otherness emerge as necessary fantasies of the mind, especially the Western mind. You may even begin to admire the artist's cleverness and wonder at your own gullibility.
In the end, it is Mr. Baumgarten's fiction and sense of abstract beauty, not his grasp of reality or his reverence for the Tupi, that is most interesting in "The Origin of the Night." And, thankfully, the hint of postmodern irony erodes the prevailing piety of his work. He is a precursor of the set-up photography that emerged in New York in the early 1980's, especially as developed by artists like James Casebere and James Welling. Another good reason for the Whitney to be showing this film. 

Lothar Baumgarten's "Origin of the Night: Amazon Cosmos" is on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, through Nov. 30.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Two images from Lothar Baumgarten's film "The Origin of the Night: Amazon Cosmos" (1973-78), at the Whitney Museum of American Art through November. Shooting near his home in Germany, the artist evoked the Amazon rain forest. (Photographs from the Marian Goodman Gallery)

LENGTH: 1719 words

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Weekender Bellport, N.Y.

BYLINE:  By BETHANY LYTTLE 

 BODY:
INITIALLY, the understated beauty of the place -- the classic white houses with green trim, the shady streets lined with prim picket fences, the quaint main street and the water views -- attracts weekenders to Bellport. But in the end, this Long Island town's proximity to Manhattan and its beach on Fire Island persuade daydreaming city dwellers to become loyal part-time residents.
 Bellport, 60 miles from Manhattan, offers all the beach-and-fresh-air allure of a Long Island getaway without the scene and the traffic associated with the Hamptons. It has an active film society, a first-rate playhouse and numerous programs for children and teenagers. It also has the occasional drawback that comes with popularity: There is an eight year waiting list for a boat slip at the local yacht club. 
 "The village is quiet, and privacy is respected, but most people who come here do so because they value beauty and a sense of a community," said Thomas O'Brien, president of Aero Studios Ltd., a Manhattan design company, who first visited Bellport in 1990 and now owns a house there. 
Jane Wilton, a lawyer from Manhattan who spends weekends in Bellport with her husband, Ron Ridon, and their three children, said: "It's the kind of place where you can drop in on a friend. There's a lot of back and forth between each other's houses. It's like the suburban life I had when I was growing up. The kids can just hop on their bikes and go."
The influx of weekenders begins on Friday night. At the Bellport restaurant (159 South Country Road), tables begin to fill up early in the evening. "You should see them," said Patricia Trainor, who owns the restaurant with her husband and its chef, Taylor Alonso. "They fall in with these exhausted faces, but by the time they're ready to leave, the place is abuzz with lively chatter."
Second home to prominent members of the fashion and design industries, as well as investment bankers and lawyers, journalists and artists, the village has a history of playing host to vacationing Manhattanites. From the mid-1800's until the late 1930's, it was an active summer resort with grand hotels and boarding houses. Though most of these structures were torn down by the 1940's, Bellport retained a consistent, if smaller, summer resident population. The 1980's saw a revived interest in the village, and many of the handsome houses that are now prized by residents were restored at that time.

The Scene
Driving along Station Road on the way to Bellport, you pass through North Bellport, a relatively depressed town characterized by small, run-down homes and the occasional corner market. Once you cross the railroad tracks, however, things change. A left turn onto South Country Road, which divides the village of Bellport in half (geographically and economically), leads to a blocklong shopping area.
A turn onto Bellport Lane reveals a stately drive flanked by large trees and grand houses, many built by sea captains who lived and worked here during the town's whaling days. The lane leads to Bellport Bay, where it loops around the Bellport Bay Yacht Club across from Fire Island. In summer, outdoor film screenings and music events are held beside the water.
Proud of its history and intent on preserving it, the Village of Bellport has an officially designated, and growing, historic district, which includes Bellport Lane. The village also has an architectural review board, which must be approached before structural changes can be made to buildings in the area.
Created in 1969, the Post-Morrow Foundation procures undeveloped land as well as properties and buildings of regional significance. Acres of surrounding wetlands, creeks and other riverine areas have been protected by the foundation.
"There's a strong bias toward keeping things as they were," said Paul Allan, an owner and the producer of the Gateway Playhouse (215 South Country Road), who with his sister, Robin Allan, is overseeing the reconstruction and renovation of a large colonial-style house on the property.

Pros
Ho-Hum Beach (called Bellport Beach by most residents) is the jewel of the village. Situated 2.2 miles away on Fire Island, it can be reached by the village-owned 42-passenger Whalehead Point ferry or by private boat.
A season-long family ferry pass is $348. The beach, which is open to residents, is prized for its privacy. Bordered by national seashore, it is rarely crowded, with 60 visitors considered unusual. Following local custom, residents and weekenders line up their sandals and sneakers at the head of the stairs that lead down to the beach.
The town sponsors a number of programs that are ideal for families. They include sailing, golf and tennis lessons for children. A biweekly film series is offered by the Bellport Film Society.
Bellport has an annual outdoor art fair and a summer concert series at the village band shell. In winter, the bay is transformed into a skating rink for sailboat-size iceboats, or "scooters." The vessels, which are wind-propelled, have been gliding across Bellport Bay since 1874.
The 500-seat Gateway Playhouse is in its 53rd season, currently featuring "The King and I." Its proximity to New York City allows the theater to attract a high caliber of talent.
Bellport has a wide range of shops, among them the old-style Variety Mart, the Donna Waters boutique and the whimsical Pippers America. Wallen's IGA and Bellport Paint & Wallpaper are two of the many stores that appear much as they did 60 years ago.
In addition to the Bellport, restaurants include the dining room at the Bellport Country Club. Painters, a former catering hall that has been updated with downtown decor, offers continental food and the kind of family-friendly atmosphere you might find in TriBeCa.
Bellport's commitment to conserving land, protecting architecture and limiting growth has much to do with what makes it attractive to homeowners.
Travel to Bellport is relatively swift because the exit to Bellport is off the Sunrise Highway before the bottleneck farther east. The Long Island Railroad stops in Bellport.

Cons
Even in economic downturns, Bellport property values have held steady or risen, real estate agents say. As a result, "a lot of people who would be willing to contribute to this community can't afford to live here," said Joseph Varsalona, who lives in East Patchogue, a neighboring village that is considered part of Bellport but is slightly less expensive.
Bellport's desire to preserve its village character is seen by some as too controlling. Business owners in the village must balance their commitment to small-town values with a need for profit, and for homeowners who wish to make changes to their homes or expand their properties, the bureaucracy can be frustrating. Weekenders who want a property that doesn't require a lot of attention may find Bellport too restrictive.
To some, the village is in a state of transition. "Corporate America is beginning to have an impact," said Thomas Schultz, owner of Kitchen and Coffee, a coffee shop in town. CVS, the drugstore chain, has moved in, and residents, both part-time and full-time, "will have to make a decision about the direction the town is going to take," Mr. Schultz said.
Visitors may find the quality and range of the produce at the local supermarkets limited. Unlike the Hamptons, the village lacks farm stands, produce markets or speciality food shops.

The Real Estate Market
Finding a property in Bellport requires persistence. "There are only three or four building sites left in the area, most listed at about $495,000," said Mark Petheram, a broker and owner of Old Purchase Properties (126 South County Road, 631-286-2424; www.oldpurchase.com).
Generally speaking, the closer to the water, the more expensive the houses. It is not atypical for older houses, like the neo-Classicals and Victorians on Bellport Lane, to be priced at more than $2 million.
This week, listings at Old Purchase Properties included an early 1900's cedar-shingle Cape Cod with a 50-foot in-ground pool, four bedrooms and gardens for $1,075,000. A four-bedroom early 1900's colonial-style house with a wraparound porch is listed for $740,000. Less expensive properties are farther from the water, like a 1975 three-bedroom ranch-style house on a half-acre lot for $369,000.
To the south, the average house price is about $750,000. To the north, buyers can expect to pay $350,000 for a midcentury ranch or Cape Cod that needs updating. At Eileen Green Realty (153 South Country Road, 631-286-3366; www.eileengreenrealty.com), listings include a four-bedroom 1920's Dutch Colonial by the bay, with a guest cottage and screened porch on a three-quarter-acre lot for $899,000, and a well-maintained 1950's Cape Cod with four bedrooms for $395,000.
According to Mr. Petheram, property values have risen about 25 percent each year for the last five years. Ms. Green quoted a similar statistic.
Though limited, housing stock in Bellport is in good condition, something brokers and residents attribute to the 20-year-old trend in period restoration.

LAY OF THE LAND
Quieter and Closer Than the Hamptons

POPULATION: 2,800; about 25 percent are weekend homeowners.

SIZE: 1.4 square miles.

NUMBER OF HOUSES: 1,120.

NEIGHBORS: Charlie Rose, Isabella Rossellini, the artist Malcolm Morley and the former governor of Massachusetts William Weld.

MEDIAN HOUSE PRICE: $350,000 north of South Country Road; $750,000 south of South Country Road.

HEADLINE: Paris Journal; 
The End of Chocolate (as a Chocolatier Knows It)

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
First, Christian Constant created a towering sculpture in solid chocolate, dozens of stylized chocolate bars soaring in a turbulent column skyward, out of an immense cracked chocolate egg. The Renaissance of Chocolate, he called it.
 Next, he draped the doorposts of his store, along Rue d'Assas in Paris, in black as a sign of mourning. 
 The symbols reflected the mix of emotions these days among French lovers of chocolate who know their criollo from their gianduja, and relish the difference. The symbolism became ever more complex after the monument to rebirth, softened by Paris's withering heat, slowly leaned, like some Hershey's Tower of Pisa. 
In August, French connoisseurs of chocolate definitively lost a battle against the bureaucrats of the European Union. Up to 5 percent of the cocoa butter in chocolate may be replaced by other vegetable fats -- Mr. Constant refers to them as "bad margarine" -- and still be called chocolate.
"Chocolate is no longer chocolate," said Mr. Constant, perched in the tiny coffee bar next to his store.
The struggle began in the 1970's, after Britain sought entry into the European Union and set as a condition the acceptance by the rest of Europe of a law that would permit the addition of vegetable fat, a customary practice in British chocolate. 
For the French, it was an assault on the world's finest cocoa-based products, which for them meant French chocolate.
Indeed, the French love of chocolate is such that it has even become an affair of state. This week, the State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, referred disparagingly to four European countries, including France, that met earlier this year for what he described as a little bitty summit to discuss defense policies more independent of the United States. Mr. Boucher dismissed them as "the chocolate makers."
In France, that is a proud thing to be. Chocolatiers like Mr. Constant picketed European institutions in Brussels and Strasbourg. They argued from taste; they argued from global economics. If less chocolate were used, the economies of cocoa-producing countries like Ivory Coast would be ruined. Their efforts, helas, were ultimately undermined by a fifth column: France's own industrial chocolate makers. 
Pure chocolate, Mr. Constant explained, consists essentially of cocoa, sugar and cocoa butter, which is extracted from cocoa beans and is very expensive. "Vegetable fats are 10 time cheaper," he said. The big chocolate industrialists, he complained, like Nestle, Kraft Foods, the maker of Toblerone, and Suchard, "employ only one argument: price. You have to make it less expensive."
For their part, the industrialists are treading cautiously. A spokesman for Kraft Foods in France acknowledged it was a bit like genetically modified crops, which the French also detest. "Even if they're authorized," he told the daily Le Monde, "the public reaction is such that for the moment no one is going to use them."
According to a survey this summer by the Sofres polling group, fully 30 percent of the French acknowledge a "faithful and passionate relationship with chocolate."
One of the faithful, and passionate, is Jean Colaneri, the secretary general of the Club des Croqueurs de Chocolat -- roughly, the Club of Chocolate Munchers -- an exclusive band of French chocolate connoisseurs who meet four times a year, taste new creations from famous chocolatiers, and vote approval or disapproval with a show of hands.
"In Europe, in any case, habits of consumption are very different," Mr. Colaneri said. "In Scandinavia, Denmark, England, it's a product of daily consumption. In others, France above all, there's a sort of tradition among the producers, it is part of a grand crafts tradition. There are certain specificities, pleasure, conviviality. Who does not like chocolate?"
Before retiring, Mr. Colaneri, 77, headed the association of chocolate producers, so he knows both sides of the fence. The Croqueurs, who publish a Zagat-like guide to French chocolatiers (they rank Mr. Constant with three of five possible chocolate bars), opposed the new directive, though he offered a compromise: distinguishing chocolate from chocolate products, thus maintaining chocolate's purity while allowing vegetable fats in such chocolate products as the chips in tollhouse cookies.
He wonders aloud whether unscrupulous manufacturers might not stop at 5 percent, but add even more vegetable fats. After all, testing methods for fat content are highly unreliable. "It's like the petroleum industry," he said. "It's complex chemistry."
What he fears most, he suggested, are cheap imports, say, from eastern European nations about to enter the European Union.
Mr. Constant's faithful clients, of course, scoff at the idea of vegetable fats. "I don't agree at all," said Jean-Marc Godard, 50, cradling a large chocolate cake he had just bought in the shadow of Mr. Constant's leaning monument. "Everyone would pay a little more to get real chocolate."
For Mr. Constant, it is the start of a slope as slippery perhaps as cocoa butter. "Now we have evoked the problem of creating a precedent," he said, sadly. "If chocolate, why not 5 percent vegetable fat in butter? Or wine? You could add water, or colorant, and still call it wine."
"The poor European chocolate law," he said. "It's sad, because we're assuring a move toward a more synthetic world, in all domains."

HEADLINE: Worker Productivity Grows at a Fast Clip 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Companies are supplying an expanding economy with more cars, computers, machinery and services while cutting jobs and getting more out of remaining workers, reports released yesterday showed.
 Productivity, a measure of how much work an employee performs, grew at a 6.8 percent annual rate in the April-June period, triple the first-quarter pace, the Labor Department said. 
Initial jobless claims rose last week to 413,000, the highest in more than a month, the department also reported. 
 Factory orders rose 1.6 percent in July, the third consecutive increase, the Commerce Department said. Services, which account for more than 80 percent of the economy, grew in August for a fifth consecutive month, a private report said. 
"The silver lining is that as companies become more profitable from these efficiencies, they'll be more willing to invest, and that will help to create jobs," said Jade Zelnik, chief economist at RBS Greenwich Capital in Connecticut.
The second-quarter rise in productivity came after a 2.1 percent rate of increase in first three months and was the fastest since 9.3 percent in the first quarter of 2002.
First-time claims for state unemployment benefits rose 15,000 last week, to 413,000. The four-week moving average, a less volatile indicator, rose to 401,500. Some economists consider 400,000 the dividing line between job market expansion and contraction.
The 1.6 percent increase in factory orders for July to $329.4 billion came after a revised 1.9 percent gain in June, the Commerce Department said. Economists had expected factory orders to rise 0.8 percent. Excluding transportation equipment, orders rose 2.1 percent.

HEADLINE: Crops in Plains Wither In Scorching Drought 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: EVEREST, Kan. 

 BODY:
Kevin Compton, a 48-year-old grain farmer, recently walked into his corn field to inspect the damage from a summer-long drought. He tore open an ear of corn and grimaced.
 "Look at this little bitty ear," he said, revealing a stunted, partly rotted corn cob. "This won't amount to nothing. Everything's gone." 
 Mr. Compton then hopped in his Ford Explorer and drove a mile east to inspect some soybean acreage. It was even worse.
"You see these spots?" he said, fingering a withering, pale-green soybean pod. "These are dying. When you look at these pods, you see about 8 or 10. Normally, you'd have 30 or 40."
Farmers all over the state are making similar assessments because of what state officials say is one of the worst droughts in the Plains states in decades. This community in northeastern Kansas is one of the areas hit hardest.
For the second straight year, Kansas and parts of Missouri and Nebraska have suffered through an extremely dry summer that has brought back memories of the 1930's Dust Bowl. A shortage of rainfall and a series of 100-degree days have destroyed crops on millions of acres and dried up streams, creeks and rivers, state officials said.
All over Kansas there have been scenes of loss and despair. Farmers have been harvesting corn that matured too early and turning it into animal feed. Ranchers have been hauling water to cattle grazing on shriveled pastures. Even grain sorghum, which is considered more drought-resistant than other crops, is dying in the fields. 
Recent downpours that flooded the eastern part of the state came too late to save many crops, state and agriculture officials said.
"The rains were beneficial, but they didn't save anything," said Mary Knapp, the Kansas state climatologist. "We need continuing rains to end this."
Some farmers have had to take drastic steps. "Farmers are cutting their corn for silage because it's not good enough to grow," said Lisa Taylor, a spokeswoman for the Kansas Department of Agriculture. 
Farmers had hoped this year would be better than last, when they lost more than $1 billion worth of crops to drought. The losses could be as high this year. Congress offered about $200 million in drought aid in 2002. This year, state officials are planning to ask the federal government for more relief.
Indeed, the United States Agriculture Department's weather crop report recently showed that about 55 percent of the state's corn crop and 61 percent of its soybean crop were "poor to very poor."
One of the few bright spots for Kansas farmers was last winter's wheat crop, which resulted in an unusually good harvest. Many farmers who expect huge losses from this summer's corn and soybean crops are hoping for another strong winter wheat crop, which is planted in October and harvested in June.
There is already a rush to buy seed for winter wheat, agricultural officials here say.
Kansas ranchers are also faring well by selling their cattle early to take advantage of a strong demand for beef. 
"Market prices are extremely good," said Todd Domer, a spokesman for the Kansas Livestock Association. "They're near all-time highs." 
The pessimistic report from the Department of Agriculture came at the end of August, when parts of Kansas were suffering through 11 consecutive days of 100 degree heat; on Day 12, the temperature was 99.
Parts of Kansas were so dry that restrictions on water use and rules against trash burning were put into effect to conserve water and prevent wildfires. Some reservoirs were 14 to 20 feet below normal levels.
Along Interstate 70, which stretches in this state from Kanorado, near the Colorado border, east to Kansas City, there are dying trees, acres of stunted soybeans and fields of deformed, earless corn. Corn fields that typically average 150 bushels an acre are now yielding just 30 or 40, local farmers say. The harvest began weeks ahead of schedule because farmers wanted to salvage part of the corn.
Here in the northeastern part of the state, the remaining corn is so brittle that a recent wind storm knocked over huge fields of it.
Soybean farmers are not much better off. Many soybean crops look as though they have stopped growing altogether. The dark greens have gone pale, like some tree tops.
"This is the second year in a row," said Kenlon Johannes, a spokesman for the Kansas Soybean Association. "It was bad in 2000; 2001 was O.K., 2002 was bad, and this year is bad. Three out of the last four years have been tough."
After going nearly two months with little or no precipitation, people in Kansas were joking that they would not know rain if it hit them smack on the head.
"Rain, what's rain?" said Stanley McCauley, a farmer driving a pickup truck on Main Street in nearby Highland, just before the downpours.
At Ernie's restaurant and pool hall in downtown Highland, everyone had something to say about the weather.
"People are driving trucks up and down the Nemaha River," said Artie Lucas, an insurance agent who was eating chicken strips and potatoes. "That's a tributary of the Missouri River."
Someone in the crowded hall called on Wilbur Winter, 87, to comment on the drought. Mr. Winter, a retired farmer, sought to put things in historical perspective.
"I remember '36," he said. "That was the Dust Bowl. We had 36 days over 100 degree temperatures. This isn't as bad as then, but this is bad."
In a state dominated by farmers and the business of farming, the drought has rippled through the economy.
"Everyone's tightening up,' said Emmett Cole, who operates a grain and fertilizer business in Highland. "They've quit spending money, and they're cutting back on their farm inputs."
While the rains came too late for the summer crop, they could help the winter wheat. 
In Everest, the first rains came late in the afternoon. People all over town ran outside, as though they had never seen rain.
Lanette McKee, the postmaster, went out and stood in front of the post office to marvel at the sight of raindrops pounding the sidewalks.
"I can't believe this is rain," Ms. McKee said. "Boy, is it coming."

 BODY:
Future Network Expanding Into Consumer Magazines
No publishing company flew higher than Future Network USA in the late 1990's, propelled by the booming new economy magazine Business 2.0, and few fell harder in the bust. But two years after a restructuring, a chastened Future is poised for another growth spurt in the United States, this time with a twist.
 Future is expected to announce today that it is buying Guitar World magazine and three other publications from Harris Publications for $16 million. The purchase of the Guitar World properties is an effort by the publisher to broaden its base into the less cyclical consumer-enthusiast field. Page C6. 

CD Industry Responds to Price Cut
Universal Music's decision to lower the prices of its CD's and its promotional subsidies to stores left the rest of the music industry scrambling to respond, and debating whether the effects would help or hurt struggling music stores. C2.

Drug Makers Influence Medicare Bill
A lobbying campaign is paying off for the pharmaceutical industry as Congress reconciles differences in two versions of a Medicare drug benefit. The main provision of the benefit -- the use of private health plans to deliver Medicare prescription drug benefits -- is tailor-made to the industry's specifications. A1.

Senator Seeks to Trim Tanker Lease
Senator John W. Warner, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, called on the Pentagon to scale back a $21 billion Air Force plan to lease 100 Boeing 767 tankers. C2.

U.S. May Bar a Tenet Hospital
The government has notified Tenet Healthcare that it will hold proceedings to bar its Redding Medical Center from federal health care programs because of accusations that potentially hundreds of patients received unnecessary heart tests and surgery at the hospital. C3.

Signs of Growth in Advertising
There are signs that ad spending is picking up. The chief economist at Standard & Poor's estimated spending will increase 4.8 percent this year. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

PeopleSoft Raises Profit Estimate
PeopleSoft increased its estimate of 2004 profits before some costs to 90 to 95 cents a share. In June, PeopleSoft had predicted earnings of 84 to 92 cents. Net income will be 57 to 62 cents a share, the company said. Peoplesoft, which is trying to fend off a $7.25 billion hostile bid from Oracle, said Oracle's bid was no longer scaring away customers. C5.

The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose to a 14-month high for the third consecutive day, closing up 1.70 points, at 1,027.97. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 19.44 points, to 9,587.90, and the Nasdaq composite index increased 16.07 points, to 1,868.97. C6.

Productivity Growth Picks Up Speed
Productivity grew at a 6.8 percent annual rate in the second quarter, triple the first-quarter pace, the Labor Department said. C3.

Stock Firm Accuses Paper of Libel
The Financial Times, the newspaper owned by the conglomerate Pearson, is battling legal action by a brokerage firm that contends the newspaper hurt its reputation by making public accusations made by a former employee. World Business, Section W.

Some Ahold Investors Object to Pay
Shareholders of Royal Ahold voted to appoint Anders C. Moberg chief executive, but some of them objected to his pay. Mr. Moberg, who was appointed in May, will earn more than 6 million euros ($6.5 million) for his first two years on the job. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: 100,000 Could Lose Housing Subsidies, Advocates Warn 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 

 BODY:
More than 100,000 low-income families could lose their rent subsidies next year under a spending bill passed today by a Senate committee and recently approved by the House, housing advocates said.
 The advocates cited a new study by the Congressional Budget Office. 
 If the nonpartisan budget office's forecast of housing costs next year proves accurate, it could be the first time in the 30-year history of the federal housing voucher program that Congress has failed to renew all existing vouchers. Under the program, known as Section 8, the vouchers pay the difference between the market rent of an apartment and 30 percent of a household's income. 
The program subsidizes more than two million families who generally earn less than $20,000 a year.
The House appropriated $11.7 billion for the vouchers this year. That would be enough to provide for 1.78 million vouchers under the House estimate of the average cost of a voucher, $6,575. But the budget office last week set a higher figure, $7,068, taking into account housing costs around the country. At that rate, the same sum of money would mean 114,000 fewer vouchers in the coming year. Because the law sets the voucher formula, any shortfall would result in fewer vouchers rather than small reductions in each voucher.
The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to spend $150 million less on Section 8 than the House. But the panel included instructions to the administration to return to Congress with a supplementary spending request if the amount is inadequate to renew all vouchers.
Republican appropriators in the House say they provided a 7 percent increase in spending for the vouchers this year, considerably more than the 4 percent that the Bush administration recommended. Representative James T. Walsh, the New York Republican who is chairman of the subcommittee that controls spending on housing, said he believed that amount would be adequate to renew all vouchers, though he had not seen the new figures from the budget office.
An assistant housing secretary Michael Liu, whose office administers Section 8, said the administration believed that no one would lose a voucher based on the appropriation and questioned the forecast by the budget office.
"At the present time," Mr. Liu said, "we believe what has been allocated will be sufficient to take care of the number of vouchers we have. Frankly, we're not sure what C.B.O. based its estimates on."
Housing advocates said rapidly rising costs combined with high unemployment had pushed up the costs of subsidies beyond the increase approved by the House. The cost of a voucher increases when rents go up and income levels decrease.
"The appropriations committees are operating under extremely narrow confines of what they can do," said Sheila Crowley, president of the National Low Income Housing Coalition in Washington. "Now they're not even spending enough money to sustain the number of people who currently pay for housing through the voucher program. It's an unprecedented break in the commitment made when the program was founded in 1974."
To ensure that all vouchers were paid for, Congress has in previous years often appropriated more money than necessary. This year, Congress changed the financing to focus on the target of vouchers more closely. The new formula requires an extremely accurate prediction of costs to keep all vouchers renewed.
Barbara Sard, director of housing policy at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group in Washington that has studied Section 8 appropriations, said Congressional estimates for low-income housing had not kept pace with rents and other costs.
"The House relied on old data to predict what vouchers would cost," Ms. Sard said. "But this funding is for the future, and there are a lot of reasons why costs have dramatically increased recently." 
The Congressional Budget Office predicted that the cost of a voucher would increase by more than 5 percent, and that there would be less turnover of families who use the vouchers than the Congressional committees had assumed. In difficult economic times, families tend to rely more heavily on subsidies, and there are fewer instances of families earning too much to qualify for vouchers. Overall, the office said, the cost of renewing all vouchers will be $900 million more than the House allocated.
Some large urban housing authorities like the one in New York City have long waiting lists for Section 8 vouchers. Others have far more turnover. New York issues more than 110,000 vouchers a year, with nearly 150,000 families on the waiting list.
Mr. Walsh said the tax cuts were not linked to the housing bill.
"We provided a 7 percent increase, which is more than the president requested," he said. "I don't know how anyone can say that's related to the tax cuts."

HEADLINE: France and Free Trade 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 As a third-generation steel worker who after 39 years of service has found himself unemployed, I read with some interest the account of France's protection of its "agri-culture" ("A French Roadblock to Free Trade," editorial, "Harvesting Poverty" series, Aug. 31). 
 I haven't figured out whether the French are deserving of admiration or ridicule. Personally, I like going to my grocery store and having the opportunity to buy virtually anything there is to eat or drink, including French wine. 
The French and their European neighbors have done everything in their power to tear down trade barriers in the United States in an effort to gain market share with their steel products at the expense of the domestic steel industry and our Midwest manufacturing "culture." It seems to me you can't have it both ways.
Free trade has become like Christianity and capitalism, embraced by many but practiced by relatively few. 

JOHN HYNES
Poland, Ohio, Aug. 31, 2003

HEADLINE: France and Free Trade 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "A French Roadblock to Free Trade" (editorial, "Harvesting Poverty" series, Aug. 31) scapegoats France as the major roadblock to agricultural free trade, but does not mention a farm bill, passed last year, which increases American agricultural subsidies by 80 percent (almost $82 billion over the next decade) and is negatively viewed by Latin American and African nations as having the same "dumping" effect that France's policy produces. 
 A deeper analysis would reveal that the United States and the European Union are not the only nations to use agricultural subsidies, but that in fact many of the world's richest nations subsidize their farmers to the detriment of the developing world. Before agricultural free trade becomes a reality, the economic heavyweights must relinquish their subsidies and allow comparative advantage to take hold.

MAINA TILTON
New York, Sept. 2, 2003

HEADLINE: AROUND THE LEAGUE; 
For 42 Years, Modell Has Watched, and Helped, the N.F.L. Grow

BYLINE:  By Thomas George

 BODY:
Long before pro football became America's favorite sport, it was Art Modell's passion. 
 Modell, the majority owner of the Baltimore Ravens, who turned 78 on July 23, will watch on television Sunday from his home when the Ravens open the season at divisional rival Pittsburgh. 
 He lives near the Ravens' complex in Owings Mills, Md., attends most practices in a golf cart and walks well with a little assistance. He recalls National Football League events of the past four decades and beyond with ease and retains his trademark humor. That despite quadruple bypass surgery in 1983 that left him in intensive care for 17 days. Last year he had a heart attack in April and a stroke in July. 
"As far as the hospital was concerned last year," quipped Modell at practice one day earlier this week, "I was on the monthly plan."
This will be Modell's 43rd and final season as a majority owner in the N.F.L. But that number alone, he said, is not magical.
What moves Modell are the friends he has gained and lost, the players, coaches and workers in his organization who over so many years became extended family and, finally, watching the N.F.L. grow into a powerful and model business entity.
He won a championship in Cleveland in 1964 but moved his team to Baltimore for the 1996 season. His team would lose in the championship game in 1965, '68 and '69 and in the American Football Conference title game in 1986, '87 and '89. It would win the Super Bowl capping the 2000 season. 
For 31 years Modell was the leader in the N.F.L.'s television negotiations and helped pave the way for the current $18 billion TV deal the league enjoys.
His father died when he was 15 and Modell dropped out of high school to work and help support his family. He later completed high school by attending night classes. Modell joined the Air Force and fought in World War II.
After the war, Modell built a successful career in advertising and television producing. In 1961, he bought the Browns for $4 million, combining his assets with money raised from bankers and other financiers. Some people said at the time that he had overpaid.
He sold the Ravens to Baltimore businessman Steve Bisciotti for $600 million in 2000 with the agreement that this season would be Modell's last as majority owner.
Giving up a nearly half-century love affair required at least that much time to digest.
"The principal reason I sold my team is to put my estate in order and provide for my children and grandchildren so they won't have to worry a day like I did growing up," Modell said. "During my father's time, the Depression was brutal and it wiped out his business, a chain of radio stores. During my time as owner, I've done many deals and made millions and lost millions, but this is the first time in my life I've been economically free. I'm out of the debt and out of that pressure. It's something every man works for and I worked 43 years for it, to build that for my family."
It was the reason, Modell said, that he had to move his team to Baltimore, an act that still riles people in Cleveland even though the Browns name was left behind and an expansion team has been back in business for four complete seasons.
"I understand there is anger at me that remains in Cleveland," Modell said. "I understand that when the Ravens won the Super Bowl, there was tremendous hostility toward me and my family." 
But Modell insists he had no choice.
"I could not go bankrupt," he said. "We built up so much debt in that old stadium. I had to do something to salvage my franchise and my family. I was not trying to hurt them; I love those people in Cleveland, but not the politicians and not the business community."
The controversy has prevented Modell from being voted into pro football's Hall of Fame. There is no doubt, considering his expansive career, that he belongs, his players say.
"Oh man, this is one of the greats of the game, someone who loves the game and loves his players and is genuine about it; his heart is pure," said Ray Lewis, the Ravens linebacker. "Our entire team feels this way, especially the guys who have been around awhile. He just loves pro football and every player here is like one of his kids. It's just a beautiful thing."
Even after his retirement, Modell plans to remain with the Ravens. Bisciotti has insisted that Modell keep an office next door to his, and Modell said he would act as a consultant though he wants "no title and no salary and will speak when asked to speak and just play the whole thing by ear."
After 43 years, who knows the perfect blueprint for what follows?
"The magic comes in winning, and even though we're young, we've got a chance to get back and win that Super Bowl," Modell said. "This is going to be an exciting and rewarding year for the league. We've stabilized our league and we've got a great game that can still grow. 
"I used to say there is nothing like 1 o'clock on Sunday afternoons," Modell said. "But now you can say, with the growth of this league, that there is nothing like Monday nights, Thursday nights, Saturday afternoons. That's the magic, too."

Two Are Enough
Traditionalists in the N.F.L. have long preferred to keep three quarterbacks on their rosters. This season, however, seven teams will enter the season with only two quarterbacks.
Those teams are Indianapolis, Washington, San Diego, Denver, Buffalo, Atlanta and Miami. The final two on that list will add a third in a month or two when injured quarterbacks return. But the other five have decided that two are enough.
Some are leaning that way because of salary-cap issues. Others are doing so to create more depth at particular positions, especially at defensive back.
But it is a risky trend. Seven teams started three different quarterbacks last year, primarily because of injuries. 
A few teams may look for another player to fill in as a third quarterback. In Denver, for example, the third-string quarterback is receiver Rod Smith.
If the gamble pays off, those teams with two will have saved money while strengthening themselves at other critical positions. It is a high-risk-high-reward decision that will be closely monitored by other teams.

Defending a Streak
Indianapolis holds the league record for defensive touchdowns scored in consecutive opening-day games with four. When the Colts travel to Cleveland on Sunday, they will look to extend the streak.
All four games ended in victories for the Colts by an average margin of 13.5 points. Since 1970 only three teams have managed three straight years of defensive scores in opening-day victories: Washington (1973-75), the Houston Oilers (1991-93) and the Giants (1997-99).
The team with the current best opening-game winning streak is Miami with 11.

From Arena League to N.F.L.
Proving once again that players come from many different places and that hidden gems exist, the Arena Football League has produced five players who earned a spot on N.F.L. rosters: Dwaine Carpenter, a defensive back in San Francisco who played for the A.F.L.'s Buffalo Destroyers; Antonio Chatman, a kick returner/receiver in Green Bay who played for the Chicago Rush; Chris Horn, a receiver in Kansas City who played for the Arizona Rattlers; Mike Furrey, a receiver in St. Louis who played for the New York Dragons; and Kevin McLeod, a fullback in Cleveland who played for the Orlando Predators.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Art Modell, entering his last season as the majority owner of the Baltimore Ravens, still defends moving the team from Cleveland. (Photo by Associated Press); Green Bay receiver/returner Antonio Chatman played in the Arena League. (Photo by Associated Press)
