HEADLINE: A Tax Increase? $1.2 Billion? Alabamians, It Seems, Say No 

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 4 

 BODY:
Bob Riley, the governor of Alabama, was shouting himself hoarse at a packed rally at Troy State University, promoting the largest tax hike in state history.
 Mr. Riley, trying to connect to an important Alabama tradition, yelled out, "If we don't accept mediocrity in a football team, why do we accept it in everything else?" 
 The band thumped its drums. Cheerleaders smashed pompoms together and did flips. And the crowd on this recent day shouted back, "Vote yes!" embracing Governor Riley's ambitious vision for a new Alabama built on $1.2 billion in new taxes. 
Despite the fervor of his campaign, though, all polls indicate that most voters are going to say no to Mr. Riley's plan on Tuesday, when the state votes on it in a referendum. 
"The thing is doomed," said Keith Nicholls, a pollster at the University of South Alabama. "The masses are against it."
It has all been an extraordinary campaign and an extraordinary conversion for Mr. Riley, a conservative Republican governor and former congressman who rose to power on a strict tax-cut platform.
Yet now, at football games and universities across the state, Mr. Riley, a first-year governor facing a $675 million deficit, is fighting to persuade Alabama to raise taxes and revamp one of the nation's most regressive income tax systems.
"There's nothing else Alabama can do but raise taxes," Mr. Riley said in an interview. "We're last in all the things that are good, first in all the things that are bad."
He cited statistics that show the state at the bottom of per capita spending on education, $6,025 compared to a national average of $8,411. Alabama's fourth-grade writing scores are tied for last among the 50 states. Alabama also collects the least tax dollars per person.
He is not the only one campaigning. So are the constituent groups that once would have been Mr. Riley's most fervent supporters but now oppose him: timber interests, bankers, small-business owners and conservative organizations.
The antitax coalition has raised millions of dollars for a full-blown campaign: yard signs, mailers, television commercials and shrewdly marketed radio spots.
One radio advertisement, run on black stations and intended to appeal to the state's black voters, says in a rural dialect, "Our property taxes could go up as much as 400 percent."
Deserted by his own party, coolly received by Democrats and with polls showing him distrusted by many black voters, Governor Riley may feel awfully alone. At least in Alabama. 
But with a fitful national economy, Mr. Riley is part of a growing group of Republican governors from South Carolina to Nevada turning to tax increases to stay afloat.
Indeed, national conservative groups are crossing their fingers that the Alabama measure goes down in flames to teach a lesson: Jettison a core element of Republican orthodoxy -- tax cuts -- and you are history.
"I want the whole Republican Party to watch this guy fall on his face," said Grover Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform in Washington. "He lied to his voters. He's been a disaster. He'll never be elected to anything again in his life."
Mr. Riley fights on. In a last-ditch effort, the onetime door-to-door egg salesman is campaigning around the clock, hitting every college campus, town hall and Kiwanis club that will listen, from the state capital to the Gulf of Mexico. 
The 58-year-old governor is even strutting the stage with the "American Idol" winner Ruben Studdard, an Alabama native, at free "Just Say Yes" concerts.
As he campaigns to change the state tax system which now requires a family of four to pay taxes once its income reaches $4,600 -- the lowest threshold of any state -- Mr. Riley has also turned to religion.
"According to our Christian ethics, we're supposed to love God, love each other and help take care of the poor," said Mr. Riley, a born-again Baptist. "It is immoral to charge somebody making $5,000 an income tax."
Mr. Riley's plan would raise that income threshold for taxes to $17,000 immediately and to $20,000 in three years, while raising the tax rate to 6 percent from 5 percent.
It would also eliminate Alabama's full deduction for federal taxes paid, a provision that now disproportionately benefits the rich.
Mr. Riley's key supporters are college professors, newspaper editorial boards, some big businesses and the all-powerful Alabama teachers' union. Many say that, in making their case, they have been outfoxed.
"The other side did a better job with strategy," said Bill Hanebuth, a spokesman for the Alabama Education Association.
Mr. Riley concedes that "we haven't done a good job of articulating of how this will help the average working man."
The latest poll, taken by the University of South Alabama, shows 26 percent in favor of the referendum, 57 percent against.
The state Democratic Party is officially supporting the measure, though not doing much about it. The Republican Party -- Governor Riley's party -- is mobilizing to defeat it.
"It's been incredibly awkward," said the state Republican chairman, Marty Connors. "I admire Bob Riley. But what am I supposed to do? Throw away 20 years of Republican ideology for something like this?"
Even the political potent Christian Coalition is split. The Alabama chapter campaigning against Mr. Riley, while the national Christian Coalition supports the referendum, saying, "It helps the very least among us."
The state's fiscal problems are not exactly Mr. Riley's fault. Alabama has been decimated by globalization, with its steel mills and textile plants wiped out by imports.
Its budget is also more hogtied than any other state, with 87 percent of public money designated by law for specific programs, compared to a nationwide average of 22 percent. Thus, when times get tight, the legislature has little room to shift funds around. 
Some of Mr. Riley's critics contend that the governor would have gotten what he wanted had he sought just the $675 million needed to cover the deficit.
"It's a huge cash grab," said Bob Gambacurta, spokesman for the main opposition group, the Tax Accountability Coalition. "It's way too much pork and people realize that."
Just in case they did not, the Tax Accountability Coalition is blitzing the airwaves with prime-time television commercials that caricature lawmakers as cigar-smoking old men cutting back-room deals.
Mr. Riley says that the size of the tax plan does not matter: "The same people would be against the referendum no matter how much we asked for. And if we only raise taxes to meet the shortfall, all we've done is maintain the status quo."
The governor says the tax increase is $1.2 billion though independent analysts have predicted that over the years it will cost closer to $1.3 billion.
The tax package actually cuts some taxes for low-income residents, while raising the state income tax for higher earners to 6 percent, from 5 percent.
Yet some of the people who might benefit are not standing with him. Earlier this year, political officials say, Mr. Riley alienated black voters, who might have strongly supported the referendum, by opposing a bill in the Legislature that would have restored voting rights to felons. Hank Sanders, a state senator and member of the black caucus, supports the package but says many blacks do not trust Mr. Riley.
"Some of it is specific to Riley because he's a rich white Republican," Mr. Sanders said. "You can't overcome distrust with a 30-second ad."
William Stewart, a University of Alabama political scientist, said Mr. Riley had gone out on a limb in a way that could haunt him in the next election.
"If this thing fails, like everyone is saying it will, there will definitely be primary opposition," Professor Stewart said. "You'll see. Riley's own party will go after him."
On the other hand, Mr. Riley's stand may have won the support of moderates. That could serve him well, Mr. Stewart added, if he makes it to a general election.
It is not clear exactly what will happen if the referendum fails. But it could get ugly.
Alabama prisons are already at double their capacity. To save money, the governor's aides say, the state may have to release 5,000 felons.
"We might just have to say, 'Hey, fellows, you're free, thanks for staying with us,' " said David Azbell, the governor's press secretary.
Alabama's highways are already underpatrolled, with mannequins sitting in squad cars. Expect more state trooper cuts, Governor Riley said. Other budget items that could be cut include textbooks, teachers' supplies and money for prescription drugs.
After the rally at Troy State, Lucy Skellett, a sophomore cheerleader, explained how the budget woes affected her. Last year, the cheerleading squad got to travel with the football team. This year, there is no money for away games.
"Four games," Ms. Skellett said. "That's all we get to cheer now, is four games. You know how hard we work out for that?"

HEADLINE: Jobs Report Leads Bush to Defend Reliance on Tax Cuts 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
Today's unexpectedly bad employment report dashed the White House's hopes of going into the heat of the presidential campaign with clear evidence of an economic turnaround and forced President Bush to defend his reliance on tax cuts as a remedy.
 In a speech here hours after the government announced that the economy had lost 93,000 more jobs in August, Mr. Bush remained upbeat. He said that if Congress wanted to help, it should make the recent tax cuts permanent and enact other parts of his agenda, from limiting lawsuit awards against doctors and companies to allowing more domestic oil and gas drilling and easing regulations on businesses. 
 "We've taken steps to get our economy growing again, and there are some very hopeful signs that progress is being made," Mr. Bush told a cheering crowd of supporters at an industrial warehouse here. "Yet, today's unemployment report shows we've got more to do. And I'm not going to be satisfied until every American who's looking for a job can find a job."
But he offered no new initiatives, and with the budget deficit surging, a trend that is accelerating as the costs of occupying and rebuilding Iraq continue to grow, his ability to offer any expensive new proposals will remain limited.
Mr. Bush has already pushed three tax cuts through Congress in three years and sold them as the best solution to the economy's short-term problems. Now, having wedded himself to that policy, his political fortunes in 2004 depend to a large extent on whether a rebound in economic growth will reverse -- by the time voters start making up their minds -- the steady slide in employment that has plagued the United States through the first two and a half years of his presidency.
The Democratic presidential candidates seized on the jobs report as further evidence of what they see as Mr. Bush's economic mismanagement. Since he took office, the economy has lost nearly 2.7 million nonfarm jobs, and last month's job losses were the worst since March, according to the Labor Department.
"For seven straight months, businesses have had to cut the number of jobs available in this bleak Bush economy," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut. "At this rate, there will be only one job left to cut by November 2004: George Bush's."
Mr. Bush shot back at his critics, defending his tax cuts in particular as the right medicine at the right time.
"Tax relief means new jobs for Americans," the president said.
But the economic news provided evidence to those economists who say the economy will be slow to add new jobs and it put new pressure on a White House that is already struggling to keep Mr. Bush's standing as commander in chief from being diminished by the continued bloodshed in Iraq.
Clearly hoping that the latest round of tax cuts would diminish the role of the economy in the presidential race, Mr. Bush had spent much of the summer, including portions of what the White House called his "working vacation" on his ranch in August, serving up a message of cautious optimism.
But many economists are doubtful that the economy, while increasingly robust in many ways, will begin generating large-scale employment gains anytime soon. If their assessment is correct, it raises the prospect of a jobless recovery in the 14 months left until Election Day.
On Thursday, Ben S. Bernanke, a Federal Reserve governor, said "the decline in the unemployment rate, though steady, is likely to be slow." He said the Fed expected the unemployment rate to be 5.5 percent to 6 percent by the fourth quarter of next year, when the election is held.
In his speech, Mr. Bush repeated his standard line that he remained unsatisfied with the extent of the economy's rebound, even in light of the one piece of good news in today's jobs data, the decline in the unemployment rate to 6.1 percent from 6.2 percent, the second consecutive monthly drop.
He did not mention the new elements he has added to his defense of his economic record in recent weeks. They include his suggestion that China is hurting American workers by keeping its currency deliberately undervalued and his announcement on Monday that he would appoint an official in the Commerce Department to help manufacturers, who have been hardest hit by the recession and the sluggish recovery. His critics have called those steps window-dressing.
By some measures, Mr. Bush can point to progress on the economy. Growth is picking up, the stock market has rebounded somewhat and one of the most important measures of the economy's long-term prospects, productivity growth, or the increase in how much of a product or service each worker can produce, is surging.
But as far as employment goes, the economy is to some degree a victim of its own success. Because companies are able to produce more goods and services with fewer or the same number of people, they have less reason to start hiring even as demand for their products increases.
"We're having a good recovery, with growth through productivity, which is good for corporate profits," said Paul McCulley, chief economist at Pimco, a bond trading firm. "But corporate profits don't vote."
While productivity is hardly a household term -- and not one conducive to bumper-sticker-slogan political discourse -- Mr. Bush made an effort today to explain to voters the good news-bad news aspect of the latest economic developments.
"Long term, it's good that we're more productive," Mr. Bush said. "It means higher wages for the American worker. It means we're more competitive overseas. Short term, this economy needs to crank up faster than productivity increases in order for somebody to find a job."
But the effect of the economy on Mr. Bush's political positioning is beginning to show. In the face of arguments from many Democratic candidates that the administration's trade policies are subjecting American workers to unfair competition from abroad, Mr. Bush continued today to suggest that his support for unfettered commerce had its limits, even as his trade team prepares for a new round of talks to reduce impediments to trade worldwide.
The pressure he has put on China over its currency, like his earlier decision to give American steel makers some protection from foreign competition, was intended in part to bolster his prospects in electorally vital industrial states like Pennsylvania, Michigan, West Virginia and Ohio. And today he adopted the language of many critics of free trade, saying American workers deserve "a level playing field" with foreign competitors.

HEADLINE: Unheavenly Days 

BYLINE:  By R. Scott Appleby; R. Scott Appleby, a professor of history at the University of Notre Dame, addressed the Roman Catholic bishops of the United States at their national conference in Dallas in June 2002.

 BODY:
 A PEOPLE ADRIFT
The Crisis of the
Roman Catholic Church in America.
By Peter Steinfels.
392 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $26.

The COMING
CATHOLIC CHURCH
How the Faithful Are Shaping
a New American Catholicism.
By David Gibson.
350 pp. San Francisco:
HarperSanFrancisco. $23.95.
 The first sentence on Page 1 of "A People Adrift" sets forth the stakes. "Today the Roman Catholic Church in the United States is on the verge of either an irreversible decline," Peter Steinfels writes, "or a thoroughgoing transformation."
Hyperbole? Not if two reliable witnesses are to be believed. Steinfels, who writes the Beliefs column for The New York Times (and was once the paper's senior religion correspondent) enjoys a well-deserved reputation for equable and exacting reporting and analysis; sensationalism is not his metier. He is also a seriously committed Catholic intellectual, for whom the late Cardinal Joseph Bernardin, Archbishop of Chicago, stands as a model of consensus-building, moderately liberal episcopal leadership. 
David Gibson, a religion writer for a variety of publications and a former correspondent for Vatican Radio, is a convert whose zeal for his new faith is expressed not by intemperate judgments but by incisive observations, a playful wit and a passion for what the author Rosemary Haughton once called "The Catholic Thing" -- the capacious, sacramental religious imagination that operates by analogy rather than linear logic and perceives virtually everything human (including the body and sexual love) as occasion for a graced encounter with the divine mystery. "To some it would seem hypocritical for Catholics to stay in the church at this point, or at best an indicator of unjustifiable passivity," Gibson admits. "Then again, maybe it's the sign of a first-rate intelligence." 
"At this point" things do indeed look bleak. The revelations of a pattern of sexual abuse of children and young people by a small but significant percentage of priests over the course of 40 years, and the even more damaging disclosure of systematic shielding and reassignment of such priests by their bishops, both authors agree, have placed American Catholicism at risk. Legally and financially, it is open season on the church; across the nation, dioceses face hundreds of millions of dollars in payments to victims (and their attorneys). The laity, especially the most vulnerable in society, will be footing the bill. Despite the best intentions of church leaders, services to the poor and needy will continue to be cut, schools and churches closed and essential ministries jeopardized as funds are diverted to cover the costs of the scandal. 
Morale may be at an all-time low. Since 2002, five Catholic bishops, including the cardinal archbishop of Boston, have resigned; two others barely escaped indictment. A dozen bishops have been subpoenaed to testify at grand jury investigations. 
So much for the good news. However debilitating the current scandal, both Steinfels and Gibson contend that it is symptomatic of a deeper crisis roiling the American church, a malaise that has been building since Vatican II (1962-65) transformed the face of modern Catholicism -- or, depending on one's point of view, since Pope Paul VI dashed the hopes for genuine, abiding transformation by repudiating the recommendation of his own committee and reaffirming the traditional ban on artificial birth control in 1968. The church faced the stark alternatives of decline or reform before the sexual abuse revelations, Steinfels asserts, "and would do so today even if this shocking sexual misconduct had never occurred." 
The signs of decline are indeed grim: in church attendance rates, the number of priests per lay Catholic, knowledge of the faith and the participation of women, Latinos and young Catholics. Accompanying the dispiriting data are constant, mutually demoralizing skirmishes between American Catholics of left and right -- professional ideologues who seem to agree only that the American bishops are feckless leaders. (Progressives blame episcopal timidity on the decidedly noncollaborative, nonconsultative style of the strong-willed Pope John Paul II, while conservatives castigate the bishops for indulging the left's supposed love affair with decadent American culture.)
Countering these dismal trends is the stunning fact of postconciliar lay initiative in the church and the world. Thirty thousand "called and gifted" lay Catholics, 80 percent of whom are women, have entered pastoral ministry and are now working in over 60 percent of the nation's 19,000 Catholic parishes. Gibson notes that nearly that many are in training, making the number of lay and potential lay ministers higher than the number of active priests. These women and men are now indispensable to the vitality of local Catholicism -- they conduct religious education and social justice programs, oversee preparation for marriage and other sacraments, and serve as administrators in the nearly one-fifth of the parishes that do not have a resident priest. 
Meanwhile, the laity are inheriting the mantle of institutional leadership of a vast network of Catholic universities and colleges, parochial schools, health care facilities and hospitals, and charitable and social service agencies. Facing all of these institutions is the pressing question of Catholic identity -- defining what it might mean in our day to be a "Catholic" relief agency, university or hospital. With typical rigor and thoughtfulness, Steinfels probes: "What is the church accomplishing with its considerable investment of resources in these institutions? Are they continuing to be fed spiritually, intellectually and financially by the American Catholic community -- and to feed it in turn? Or are they spinning off into a kind of separate planetary system, where they will support themselves on the basis of government funding, medical insurance payments, tuition and fees for services, where they will continue to do good work, but where their relationship to the religious life of the nation's largest church would be minimal and peripheral?" 
The transition to lay leadership is both inevitable and uncertain. How will lay Catholics, committed to supporting their own careers and families, replicate the low-cost, labor-intensive service of generations of celibate nuns and priests? Is lay ministry, on the scale it is needed, even viable? The current generation of lay ministers operates in the absence of an officially approved ecclesiology (theory of the church) that would make theological sense of their role alongside that of the priests.
And after the boomer generation passes into history, who will assume responsibility? To chillingeffect Gibson quotes the 30-something Boston College theologian Tom Beaudoin, who describes the perceptions of some of his fellow young Catholics: "The post-Vatican-II church is often a place of self-deception, abusive silence and double talk, especially about sexuality and about power. . . . We know now that our church can cover up its spiritual deficits as well as WorldCom or Enron can cover up their economic losses." Not exactly the sensibility of a generation ready to step up to the plate. 
As they fill in the contours of the crisis in Catholicism, Steinfels and Gibson occasionally speak in the first person, with insight and concern, and each offers reasonable proposals for reform that are distinguished by mature consideration of what is and is not possible to achieve within the framework of a 2,000-year-old global and truly multicultural institution. Indeed the proposals are quite modest, perhaps to a fault, given the goal of "a thoroughgoing transformation" of the Catholic Church in the United States (Steinfels), to be produced by a lay-led "revolution from below" (Gibson).
Such a transformation, they acknowledge, will require the hierarchy to engage in frank and uncensored discussion of grievances and differences with the laity. It will require cooperation with, not humiliation of, responsible lay reform groups like Voice of the Faithful. It will also require lay Catholics to address the moral, spiritual and institutional dimensions of the crisis with an honesty and moral courage born of deep conviction that the church is still worth profound personal sacrifice. 
The greatest triumphs of Christian societies were forged in the church's darkest hours. This is a dark hour. Shedding light on it, as these fine journalists have done, is no doubt the sign of first-rate intelligence.

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/ART; 
Art by Numbers: A 1,000-Foot Halo, and Jasper Johns

BYLINE:  By KEN JOHNSON

 BODY:
 All dates subject to change.

September

'FRENCH ARTISTS IN ROME: INGRES TO DEGAS, 1803-1873' -- One of New York's most intriguingly idiosyncratic art museums, the Dahesh was founded to preserve and promote 19th-century European academic art, a category now in recovery from its steep devaluation by 20th-century Modernism. Last Wednesday the museum reopened in expansive new quarters at 580 Madison Avenue -- the former site of the IBM galleries -- with an exhibition of 130 paintings focusing on winners of the coveted Prix de Rome who lived and worked at the Villa Medici, home of the French Academy in Rome. Dahesh Museum. Through Nov. 2. (212) 759-0606. www.daheshmuseum.org

CAI GUO-QIANG, 'LIGHT CYCLE' -- Mr. Cai, who is known for his literally combustive artworks, will produce an "explosion event" to celebrate the 150th anniversary of Central Park. The centerpiece of the high-tech fireworks display will be a 1,000-foot-high halo of fire and light. Organized by Creative Time, the show is scheduled for 7:45 p.m. on Sept. 15 and is supposed to last just four or five minutes, so don't be late. Check Creative Time's Web site for a hot-line phone number for information updates. www.creativetime.org. Meanwhile, the Asia Society will present an exhibition of Mr. Cai's gunpowder drawings and studies for the project from Tuesday to Dec. 14. (212) 288-6400. www.asiasociety.org

'MARC CHAGALL' -- Always popular but not always highly respected, the great Russian Modernist painter and poetic storyteller was revived for a while by Neo-Expressionists in the 1980's. It should be interesting to see how he looks now. The seven-decade retrospective will include about 65 paintings and 88 works on paper. San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. Through Nov. 4. (415) 357-4000. www.sfmoma.org

'ST. PETER AND THE VATICAN: THE LEGACY OF THE POPES' -- Drawn from the Vatican's collections, this exhibition presents some 350 paintings, sculptures and ceremonial objects. Highlights include works by Giotto, Michelangelo and Bernini. Representing 2,000 years of Roman Catholic Church history, the show promises to be a blockbuster of staggering visual plenitude. Fort Lauderdale Museum of Art, in Florida. Through Nov. 23. (954) 525-5500. www.museumofart.org. Traveling to the Cincinnati Museum Center in December and the San Diego Museum of Art in May.

'GILLIAN WEARING: MASS OBSERVATION' -- The 1997 winner of the British Turner Prize makes eccentrically inventive films about social problems like alcoholism, domestic abuse and neglected children. People speak through masks and children lip sync the words of adults, prompting not only the usual sociological questions but philosophical thoughts about how we know what we think we know. Philadelphia Institute of Contemporary Art. Through Dec. 14. (215) 763-8100. www.icaphila.org

'STRANGE MESSENGER: THE WORK OF PATTI SMITH' -- One of the original punk rockers has also been making visual art since the 1960's. Organized by the Andy Warhol Museum, this show surveys works on paper from five decades. Philadelphia Institute of Contemporary Art. Through Dec. 7. (215) 763-8100. www
.icaphila.org

'THE PHOTOGRAPHS OF REAGAN LOUIE: SEX WORK IN ASIA' -- Mr. Louie spent six years documenting the Asian sex industry, and the results are more bleak than sexy. Along with 70 of his pictures, this show will include works by artists like Balthus, Bellocq, Nan Goldin and Cindy Sherman who have in various ways explored the seamier sides of sexuality. San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. Through Dec. 7. (415) 357-4000. www.sfmoma.org

'LO FEO DE ESTE MUNDO: IMAGES OF THE GROTESQUE' -- Whether for edification or entertainment, artists have been making images of monstrous ugliness for centuries. Modern and contemporary Latin American art abounds in grotesquerie. This 20-artist show samples the tradition, including works by Jose Luis Cuevas, Antonio Segui, Jorge de la Vega and Liliana Porter. Jack S. Blanton Museum of Art, Austin. Through Jan. 4. (512) 471-7324. www.blantonmuseum.org

'FRIDA KAHLO'S INTIMATE FAMILY PICTURE' -- This show revolves around "My Grandparents, My Parents, and I," a painting by the glamorous Mexican magic realist, which is said to reveal aspects of Kahlo's European Jewish and Mexican Catholic ancestry. The show will document biographical and artistic sources for the painting and include Kahlo's photographs of her father. Jewish Museum, New York. Through Jan. 4. (212) 423-3271. www.thejewishmuseum.org

'PLAYING WITH A LOADED GUN: CONTEMPORARY ART IN PAKISTAN' -- In a range of styles, from traditional miniature painting to avant-gardist appropriation, Pakistani artists respond to domestic violence, nuclear war and other issues. Apexart, New York. Through Oct. 4. (212) 431-5270. www.apexart.org

MARIA ELENA GONZALEZ 'UN REAL ESTATES' -- This Cuban-born artist creates environmental sculptures that operate at the intersection of fantasy, politics and architecture. Her solo exhibition was previously seen in Houston and Memphis. Art in General, New York. Through Dec. 20. (212) 219-0473. www.artingeneral.org

'WOSENE KOSROF' -- Paintings by this contemporary Ethiopian artist combine traditional calligraphy, literary symbolism and abstraction to comment on history, culture and memory. Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase, N.Y. Through Dec. 28. (914) 251-6100. www
.purchase.edu. Traveling to the Newark Museum, Feb. 1-Aug. 29.

'EVERYTHING MATTERS: PAUL KOS, A RETROSPECTIVE' -- Installations by an influential Bay Area conceptualist will include "The Sound of Ice Melting" (1970), which has electronic equipment amplifying melting blocks of ice; "Sand Piece" (1971), which has a ton of sand sifting through a hole in the floor; and "Tower of Babel" (1989), a spiraling ramp of video monitors showing people talking in different languages. Grey Art Gallery, New York, Tuesday through Dec. 6. (212) 998-6780. www.nyu.edu/greyart

TAKASHI MURAKAMI -- Mr. Murakami is known as the Japanese Warhol, but he's on his way to doing what Warhol never quite managed: achieving a total collapse of the boundary between art and commerce. His big outdoor installation, "Reverse Double Helix," centering on a cartoon Buddha-like figure 30 feet tall, promises to be spectacularly entertaining, whether or not it is admirable as art. Organized by the Public Art Fund. Rockefeller Center, New York. Tuesday through Oct. 12. (212) 980-4575.
www.publicartfund.org

'THE RESPONSIVE EYE: RALPH T. COE AND THE COLLECTING OF AMERICAN INDIAN ART' -- 200 objects from 2000 B.C. to the present comprehensively represent most, if not all, of the periods and places of Native-American Art. Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tuesday through Dec. 14. (212) 535-7710. www.metmuseum.org

'REMEMBRANCE: RUSSIAN POSTMODERN NOSTALGIA' -- This potentially fascinating show presents works by more than two dozen artists who grew up in the Soviet Union but now live elsewhere. The Soviet experience inspired deeply ironic relations to questions of truth and long-lasting emotional conflicts in artists like Komar and Melamid, Ilya Kabakov and Eric Bulatov, among others. Yeshiva University Museum, New York. Wednesday through Feb. 1. (212) 294-8330. www.yumuseum.org

'STRANGERS' -- Considering the degree to which photography has infiltrated, colonized and otherwise altered the landscape of contemporary art, the First Triennial of Photography and Video, a survey of contemporary photography and related media from all over the world, is surely an idea whose time has come. International Center of Photography, New York. Saturday through Nov. 30. (212) 857-0000. www.icp.org

'PARROT TALK: A RETROSPECTIVE OF WORKS BY KIM MacCONNEL' -- This retrospective will trace the three-decade career of one of the founders of the Pattern & Decoration Movement, whose enormous influence has yet to be fully appreciated. Santa Monica Museum of Art, in California. Saturday through Nov. 15. (310) 586-6487. www.smmoa.org

J. SEWARD JOHNSON Jr., 'BEYOND THE FRAME: IMPRESSIONISM REVISITED' -- This sounds like the worst idea of the year, but who knows, it might make for an entertaining show. Mr. Johnson, who is known for tacky bronze figures populating public spaces all over America, has created 15, life-size, walk-in versions of famous Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, including Manet's "Olympia" and van Gogh's "Bedroom." Corcoran Gallery of Art, Washington. Saturday through Jan. 5. (212) 639-1703. www.corcoran.org

'GIRLS' NIGHT OUT' -- Photography and videos about female identity by some of the brighter female stars of the international contemporary-art firmament, including Eija-Liisa Ahtila, Rineke Dijkstra, Katy Grannan and Daniela Rossell. Orange County Museum of Art, Newport Beach, Calif. Next Sunday through Jan. 25. (714) 662-3366. www.ocma.net

'MANNY FARBER: ABOUT FACE' -- From early abstractions to later still-lifes related to the movies, 70 works reflect 50 years of moonlighting as a painter by an eminent film critic. Mr. Farber's artwork deserves to be better known and maybe this exhibition, which will also focus on his writing about film and art, will do the trick. Museum of Contemporary Art, San Diego. Next Sunday through Nov. 30. (619) 234-1001. www.mcasd.org

'ROMARE BEARDEN' -- Perhaps the most celebrated of all African-American artists, Bearden is known for his lively and poetic Cubist collages that meditate on experiences of the rural South, the tropics, New York and jazz. This five-decade retrospective will also include paintings, watercolors, fabric works, stage designs, costumes, photographs and book illustrations. National Gallery of Art, Washington. Next Sunday through Jan. 4 (202) 737-4215. www.nga.gov

'GEORGE INNESS' -- One of the very best 19th-century American painters, Inness emerged in the 1870's as a Hudson River School latecomer but moved toward a less fussily detailed and more poetically evocative kind of landscape painting. Somehow it's always a surprise to come across one of his paintings and see how good they are. This retrospective will present 40 works. National Academy of Design, New York. Sept. 17-Dec. 28 (212) 369-4880. www
.nationalacademy.org

'SPLAT BOOM POW! THE INFLUENCE OF CARTOONS IN CONTEMPORARY ART' -- A hundred years from now people wondering why cartoons so pervasively influenced late 20th-century art might look back to this show for some answers. It will feature works by Jean-Michel Basquiat, Keith Haring, Arturo Herrera, Kerry James Marshall, Elizabeth Murray, Takashi Murakami, Andy Warhol and others. Boston Institute of Contemporary Art. Sept. 17-Jan. 4, (617) 266-5152. www.icaboston.com

'PASSION FOR THE MOUNTAINS' -- The Western world never really came close to what the East did with landscape painting. This 60-piece show of 17th-century masterpieces of Chinese landscape painting ranging in format from immense scrolls to small fans from the Nanjing Museum in China promises to be transcendental. China Institute, New York. Sept. 18-Dec. 20. (212) 744-8181.
www.chinainstitute.org

'AMERICAN SHORT STORIES: SAUL STEINBERG/RAYMOND PETTIBON' -- Bonnie Clearwater, director of the Museum of Contemporary Art in North Miami, has come up with an inspired idea for a show: a meeting between Steinberg, an urbane New Yorker whose cartoons made hilariously visible the frantic, surrealistic life of his city, and Mr. Pettibon, a Southern Californian whose sketchy, stream-of-consciousness images emerge from a mongrel mix of punk, surfing, art and literary cultures. Museum of Contemporary Art, North Miami. Sept. 19-Nov. 16. (305) 893-6211.
www.mocanomi.org

'A FICTION OF AUTHENTICITY: CONTEMPORARY AFRICA ABROAD' -- The architect Brad Cloepfil designed the building that holds this inaugural exhibition, an exploration of cultural prejudices by 11 African artists who live in Europe and the United States. Contemporary Art Museum, St. Louis. Sept. 20-Jan. 3. (314) 535-4660. www.contemporarystl.org

'JAPAN: RISING' -- Japanese artists are as strong a presence as ever on the American and international scenes and that trend promises to continue. This timely show will survey some of today's more notable players. Palm Beach Institute of Contemporary Art. Sept. 20-Nov. 9. (561) 582-0006. www.palmbeachica.org

'THE LANGUAGE OF NATIVE AMERICAN BASKETS' -- More than 200 choice examples of basketry from the museum's collection, with an emphasis on weaving techniques, symbolism and economics of the contemporary basket business. Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian, New York. Sept. 20-Jan. 9, 2005. (212) 514-3700.
www.americanindian.si.edu

'RONA PONDICK' -- Few contemporary artists have made sculpture of such Freudian ferocity as Rona Pondick. This exhibition surveys her work since 1992, from the raw, darkly comic images of infantile rage and hunger to the sleek, stainless-steel human/animal hybrids of recent years. Cranbrook Art Museum, Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Sept. 20-Nov. 30. (248) 645-3323. www.cranbrook.edu

'THE DAWN OF PHOTOGRAPHY: FRENCH DAGUERREOTYPES, 1839-1855' -- Whatever their status as art, daguerreotypes are almost always amazing. This exhibition will feature 175 examples of early ones. Among the magically lucid pictures fixed to mirror-bright surfaces will be scientific and documentary images, portraits, landscapes and nudes. Metropolitan Museum. Sept. 23-Jan. 4. (212) 535-7710. www.metmuseum.org

'SOME KIND OF LOVE: NAYLAND BLAKE PERFORMANCE VIDEO 1989-2002' -- The mercurial Mr. Blake has avoided being trapped by one style but has consistently used quirky symbolic devices like rabbits and gingerbread houses to illuminate issues of cultural and sexual identity. Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery, Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Sept. 27-Dec. 31. (518) 580-8080. www.skidmore.edu/tang

'SHOCKING! THE ART AND FASHION OF ELSA SCHIAPARELLI' -- The convergence of art and fashion was not invented by the 90's. In the 20's and 30's, one of fashion's hottest designers, Elsa Schiaparelli, was collaborating with the Surrealists in Paris, and she continued to be intimately involved with art throughout her career. "Shocking" will present her garments along with artworks by Salvador Dali, Jean Cocteau, Alberto Giacometti and other Modernist luminaries. Philadelphia Museum of Art. Sept. 28-Jan. 4. (215) 763-8100. www.philamuseum.org

'TREASURES OF A LOST ART: ITALIAN MANUSCRIPT PAINTING OF THE MIDDLE AGES AND THE RENAISSANCE' -- Medieval manuscript illumination turns out to be some of the most formally exciting and wildly imaginative painting of all time. This exhibition will present more than 100 examples from a collection formed by Robert Lehman. Metropolitan Museum. Sept. 30-Feb. 1. (212) 535-7710. www.metmuseum.org

'THE INVISIBLE THREAD: BUDDHIST SPIRIT IN CONTEMPORARY ART' -- Buddhism, in its low-key way, has thoroughly penetrated American culture and you don't have to look far to find Western artists inspired by its precepts. Part of a larger, multivenue enterprise called "The Buddhism Project," this show explores the
--Buddhist effect on artists from John Cage and Agnes Martin to Bill Viola and Tom Friedman. Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, Staten Island, N.Y.Sept. 28-Feb. 29. (718) 448-2500. www.snug
-harbor.org

October

'PICASSO: THE CUBIST PORTRAITS OF FERNANDE OLIVIER' -- In 1909 when he was plunging into Cubism, Picasso made many paintings and drawings of his then companion Fernande Olivier. This exhibition gathers together 60 of these works and a bronze head. National Gallery, Washington. Oct. 1-Jan 18 (202-737-4215). www.nga.gov. Traveling to the Nasher Sculpture Center, Dallas, Feb. 15-May 9.

'GLOBAL VILLAGE: THE 60'S' -- Creative imagination flourished on so many fronts and to such exhilarating, revolutionary and bewildering effect during the 60's that we are still wondering what happened. This cross-disciplinary show of more than 250 items representing the fields of art (including Pop, Minimalism and Conceptualism), design, photography, fashion and architecture should contribute substantially to the ongoing process of sorting, remembering and interpreting. Montreal Museum of Fine Arts. Oct. 2-Jan. 18. (514) 285-1600. www.mbam.qc.ca

'BESIDE THE ROSE: SELECTED WORKS BY JAY DeFEO' -- DeFeo (1929-89) is famous for one extraordinary painting, "The Rose," a massive, radiating mandala that looks as if it were cast in concrete, and which took seven years to finish. This exhibition surrounds "The Rose" with 25 of Defeo's other paintings, drawings and photomontages. Whitney Museum of American Art. Oct. 2- Feb. 29. (800) 944-8639. www.whitney.org

'THE JEWISH JOURNEY: FREDERIC BRENNER'S PHOTOGRAPHIC ODYSSEY' -- The photographer and anthropologist Frederic Brenner spent a quarter century documenting the lives of Jews on five continents. Subjects in this 150-picture show range from Ethiopian villagers to leather-clad motorcyclists in Florida. Brooklyn Museum of Art. Oct. 3-Jan. 11. (718) 638-5000. www.brooklynart.org

'RUSSIA ENGAGES THE WORLD, 1453-1825' -- This major study of Russia's emerging interaction with Europe, Asia and the Americas over the course of almost four centuries will consist of some 230 works on paper from New York Public Library collections, including illuminated manuscripts, printed books, woodcuts, engravings, watercolors and maps. New York Public Library. Oct. 3-Jan. 31. (212) 869-8089. www.nypl.org

SHIRIN NESHAT -- Appearing in the late 1990's, Ms. Neshat's cinematically lush, multiscreen video installations, in which Middle Eastern women and men engaged in curious, symbolically suggestive group actions, were a revelation and prompted extraordinarily high praise from some critics. This midcareer survey was organized by the Musee d'Art Contemporain de Montreal. Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston. Oct. 4-Nov. 20. (713) 284-8250. www.camh.org

'EL GRECO TO PICASSO: PAINTINGS FROM THE PHILLIPS COLLECTION' -- While undergoing renovation, the Phillips Collection in Washington, a great repository of European art, is sending 53 of its most prized possessions out into the world, including major works by Cezanne, van Gogh, Renoir and Picasso. Denver Art Museum. Oct. 4-Jan. 4. (720) 865-5000. www.denverartmuseum.org.

'LEE BONTECOU' -- In the 1960's Lee Bontecou made a big splash with relief sculptures, made of metal rods and drably-colored canvas, that looked like abstracted monsters. Then she abruptly dropped out of the art world. She didn't stop making art, though. This retrospective presents 50 sculptures and 75 drawings produced since 1958. U.C.L.A. Hammer Museum, Los Angeles. Oct. 4-Jan 12 (310-443-7000). www.hammer.ucla.edu. Traveling to the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago, Feb. 23-May 24, and the Museum of Modern Art, Queens, July 28-Sept. 27.

'SAMUEL MOCKBEE' -- A MacArthur Fellowship winner, Mockbee, who died in 2001, founded the Rural Studio, a program at Auburn University in Alabama that had young architecture students designing and building livable and aesthetically interesting houses from found and recycled materials for poor people in the area. This exhibition includes prototypes and models generated by the Rural Studio, paintings by Mockbee and photographs of projects finished since 1992. Birmingham Museum of Art. Oct. 5-Jan. 4. (205) 254-2566. www.artsbma.org

'EL GRECO' -- One of the strangest and most compelling painters of a time that abounded in strange and compelling painters was Domenikos Theotocopoulos (1541-1614), better known as El Greco. This major retrospective will present some 80 works whose weirdly sinuous figures and dreamy landscapes exude a visionary expressionist mood that appeals greatly to today's viewers. Metropolitan Museum. Oct. 7-Jan. 11. (212) 535-7710. www.metmuseum.org

'THE DRAWINGS OF FRANCOIS BOUCHER' -- An exhibition of 75 drawings celebrates the 300th birthday of the skillful and sweetly lubricious French Rococo master. Frick Collection, New York. Oct. 8-Dec. 14 (212-288-0700). www.frick.org. Traveling to the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, Jan. 17- April 18.

'HUDSON RIVER SCHOOL VISIONS: THE LANDSCAPES OF SANFORD R. GIFFORD' -- This Hudson River School painter didn't go in for theatrical pyrotechnics like those of Albert Bierstadt and Frederic Church. But he certainly had a way with sunlight and air, and his paintings, 70 of which will be featured in this exhibition, are irradiated with Emersonian soulfulness. Metropolitan Museum. Oct. 8-Feb. 8. (212) 535-7710. www.metmuseum.org

'FROM BAJA TO VANCOUVER' -- Twenty-five contemporary West Coast artists, including the conceptualist filmmaker Stan Douglas, the slacker cartoonist Chris Johanson and the collaborative team Torolab, observe their regional landscape from a wide-ranging variety of perspectives. Seattle Art Museum. Oct. 9-Jan. 4. (206) 654-3100. www.seattleartmuseum
.org.

'WHITE: WHITENESS AND RACE IN CONTEMPORARY ART' -- Organized by the writer and curator Maurice Berger, this exhibition will explore perceptions of people not usually defined in racial terms -- Caucasians. Works by Nayland Blake, William Kentridge, Mike Kelley, Cindy Sherman and others will contribute what could be an intellectually and sociologically provocative event. UMBC Center for Art and Visual Culture, Baltimore. Oct. 9-Jan. 10. (410) 455-2787.
www.umbc.edu/arts

'ISAMU NOGUCHI AND MODERN JAPANESE CERAMICS' -- Noguchi was one of the most restlessly inventive of all 20th-century American sculptors and a designer of extraordinary elegance. During three midcentury trips to Japan (1931, 1950 and 1952) he produced a body of ceramic sculpture that has not been seen in the United States since 1954. This show will present a selection of those works along with ceramic sculptures by Japanese artists with whom he worked and exchanged ideas. Japan Society, New York. Oct. 9-Jan. 11. (212) 715-1255. www
.japansociety.org

'TRISHA BROWN: DANCE AND ART IN DIALOGUE' -- The 1960's was fertile decade for all kinds of experimental, interdisciplinary activities and the choreographer Trisha Brown was at its center. Under the auspices of the legendary Judson Dance Theater, she collaborated with the artists Robert Rauschenberg and Robert Whitman, the musician John Cage and dancers like Yvonne Rainer, Steve Paxton and Simone Forti. In the ensuing years she worked with Donald Judd, Nancy Graves and Terry Winters, among others. This four-decade survey of her career should be a fascinating exercise in cultural history. New Museum of Contemporary Art, New York, Oct. 10-Jan. 25. (212) 219-1222. www.newmuseum.org

'THE LAST PICTURE SHOW: ARTISTS USING PHOTOGRAPHY, 1960-1982' -- The 90's was a boom decade for using photography in art, but, as this exhibition organized by the Walker Art Center associate curator Douglas Fogle will show, artists were toying with photography to diverse conceptual ends decades earlier. More than 50 artists will be represented, including John Baldessari, Bernd and Hilla Becher, Barbara Kruger, Adrian Piper, Richard Prince, Ed Ruscha, Cindy Sherman, Jeff Wall and, of course, the posthumously ubiquitous Andy Warhol. Walker Art Center, Minneapolis. Oct. 11-Jan. 4. (612) 375-7600. www.walkerart.org

'THE CENTAUR'S SMILE: THE HUMAN ANIMAL IN EARLY GREEK ART' -- The animal-man combination captivated the imaginations of early Greek artists, and this exhibition will gather together a whole menagerie of such creatures -- centaurs, satyrs, sphinxes, gorgons -- rendered in bronze, gold, engraved gems and painted pottery between 750 and 450 B.C. Princeton University Art Museum. Oct. 11-Jan. 18 (609-258-3788). www
.princetonartmuseum.org. Traveling to the Houston Museum of Fine Arts, Feb. 22-May 16.

'THE AGE OF WATTEAU, CHARDIN AND FRAGONARD: MASTERPIECES OF FRENCH GENRE PAINTING' -- Once big history paintings got all the respect. Today it's easier to appreciate minor stories of domestic and social life as painted by Watteau, Boucher, Greuze and Chardin, who will be included in this extensive survey of 18th-century French genre painting. National Gallery, Washington. Oct. 12-Jan. 11. (212) 737-4215. www.nga.gov

'WORK ETHIC' -- The curator Helen Molesworth has conceived an exhibition that asks the question: in an age when traditional craft skills are generally underused, what is the nature of artistic work? Nearly 80 objects representing a broad spectrum of approaches to artmaking -- including Pop Art, Conceptual Art, Process Art, Performance Art and much more should afford a fine occasion to ponder the issue. Baltimore Museum of Art. Oct. 12-Jan. 4. (410) 396-7100. www .artbma.org

'PAINTED PRAYERS: MEDIEVAL AND RENAISSANCE BOOKS OF HOURS FROM THE MORGAN LIBRARY' -- More popular than the Bible, illustrated books of hours -- prayer books -- were everywhere in 13th to mid-16th century Europe and their pages bore some of that period's most wonderful painting and printmaking. The selection of 58 books and manuscripts was organized and sent out by the Morgan Library in New York. Kimbell Art Museum. Oct. 12-Jan. 18. (817) 332-8451. www.kimbellart.org

'BLACK BELT' -- It is an article of faith among many art-world thinkers that answers to all kinds of human problems can be found in popular culture. The global phenomenon of Asian martial-arts entertainment is the window through which this cleverly titled, 22-artist show -- organized by the museum's curator Christine Y. Kim -- will explore relations between African-American and Asian-American cultures. Studio Museum in Harlem. Oct. 15-Jan. 4. (212) 864-4500. www.studiomuseum.org

'HUNT FOR PARADISE: COURT ARTS OF IRAN 1501-1576' -- Carpets, ceramics, lacquerware, metal works and books from the Safavid era (1502-1737), a time of great prosperity that saw Iran unified for the first time in a millennium. Asia Society, New York. Oct. 16-Jan. 18. (212) 288-6400. www.asiasociety.org

'GERMAN ART NOW' -- Hard to believe today, but 15 years ago some people thought German art was going to take over the world. This survey of paintings, sculpture and photographs from the last 40 years by artists like Joseph Beuys, Georg Baselitz, Markus Lupertz, Gerhard Richter and others will afford an opportunity to ponder what it was all about. St. Louis Art Museum, Oct. 17-Jan. 11. (314) 721-0072. www.slam.org

JAMES ROSENQUIST -- Though Mr. Rosenquist's Pop Art never had as big a public presence as Warhol's or Lichtenstein's, it has been deeply influential and seriously admired for its richly allusive take on our collective mindscape. His first retrospective since 1972 is one of the contemporary-art world's most anticipated events. Guggenheim Museum, New York. Oct. 17-Jan. 25. (212) 423-3500. www
.guggenheim.org

'PETRA: LOST CITY OF STONE' -- The ancient city of Petra, carved from red sandstone cliffs in a desert area of southern Jordan over 2000 years ago, remains one of the wonders of the ancient world. This major exhibition will include sculpture, architectural elements and documentary photographs as well as works by 19th-century artists like Frederic Church and Edward Lear for whom Petra was a romantic mecca. The show is co-organized by the American Museum of Natural History and the Cincinnati Art Museum, where it will be seen after its debut in New York. American Museum of Natural History. Oct. 18-July 6. (212) 769-5100. www.amnh.org

NASHER SCULPTURE CENTER -- In a new Renzo Piano building that occupies a city block in downtown Dallas, this institution -- said to be the first in the world devoted exclusively to modern sculpture -- will present the Raymond D. and Patsy Nasher collection, which includes works by artists from Rodin and Degas to Serra and Koons. Nasher Sculpture Center, Dallas. Opening on Oct. 19, permanent. (214-242-5100). www
.nashersculpturecenter.org

'MANET AND THE SEA' -- Though nearly extinct now, maritime painting was still alive and well in the years from 1864 to 1881, the focus of this exhibition. The first show devoted to Manet's seascapes will also include paintings by Courbet, Delacroix, Whistler, Monet, Renoir and Morisot. Art Institute of Chicago, Oct. 20-Jan. 19, (312) 443-3600. www.artic.edu. Traveling to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Feb. 8-May 9.

'JULIA MARGARET CAMERON, PHOTOGRAPHER' -- Cameron was an eminent Victorian and one of the most important artists in the history of photography. Her career is surveyed in 110 photographs drawn from European and American collections. J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles. Oct. 21-Jan. 11. (310) 440-7300. www.getty.edu

'A PRIVATE PASSION: 19TH-CENTURY PAINTINGS AND DRAWINGS FROM THE GRENVILLE L. WINTHROP COLLECTION, HARVARD UNIVERSITY' -- This legendary collection includes works by the French painters David, Ingres and Gericault; English symbolists like Blake, Rossetti and Burne-Jones; and the Americans Whistler, Homer and Sargent. Metropolitan Museum. Oct. 23-Jan. 25. (212) 535-7710. www.metmuseum.org

'SCHOENBERG, KANDINSKY AND THE BLUE RIDER' -- The friendship and mutually inspiring intellectual dialogue between Wassily Kandinsky, the abstract painter, and Arnold Schoenberg, the avant-garde composer, is the center of a show designed to illuminate a time of radical transformation in art and music. Among 65 paintings will be major works by Kandinsky, paintings by Schoenberg -- exhibited in the United States for the first time -- and works by German Expressionist members of the Blue Rider group. Jewish Museum, New York. Oct. 24-Feb. 12. (212) 423-3200. www.jewishmuseum.org

'DIANE ARBUS' -- Armed with a magically empathetic ability to reveal the vulnerable human hiding behind masks of freakish eccentricity, Arbus made some of the 20th century's most unforgettable photographs. More than 200 pictures will be presented in this retrospective organized by Sandra Phillips of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and a guest curator, Elisabeth Sussman. San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. Oct. 25-Feb. 8. (415) 357-4000. www.sfmoma.org

KERRY JAMES MARSHAL, 'ONE TRUE THING: MEDITATIONS ON BLACK AESTHETICS' -- With dauntless ambition, Mr. Marshall combines formally and technically inventive painting and unpredictable sociological commentary. This major exhibition will present works from the last five years, including sculpture, photography and video as well as large scale paintings. Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, Oct. 25-Jan. 18. (312) 280-2660. www.mcachicago.org

'JASPER JOHNS: NUMBERS' -- It's hard to believe that until now no one has produced an exhibition devoted to Mr. Johns's play with numbers. Cleveland Museum of Art. Oct. 26-Jan. 11 (888-261-0033). www.clevelandart.org. Traveling to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Feb. 1- April 18.

'REMBRANDT'S JOURNEY: PAINTER, DRAFTSMAN, ETCHER' -- Emphasizing the Dutch master's command of many different mediums and genres, this blockbuster will present more than 200 works, including paintings, drawings and prints. Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Oct. 26-Jan. 18. (617) 267-9300. www.mfa.org

'PHILLIP GUSTON' -- By the time he started producing the visceral, cartoonish narratives that so influenced generations of post-60's painters, Guston could look back on at least three long and distinguished careers: as a social allegorist in the 30's, a lyrical Abstract Expressionist in the 50's and a painter of gray, suavely blunt abstractions in the 60's. His trajectory will be traced in an exhibition of 80 paintings and drawings. Metropolitan Museum. Oct. 28-Jan. 4. (212) 535-7710. www.metmuseum.org

'VALESKA SOARES: FOLLIES' --Time, desire, intoxication and transgression are the themes of an artist whose work in photography, installation, sculpture and video is considered in a 10-year survey. Bronx Museum of Art. Oct. 30-Feb. 22. (718) 681-6000. www.bxma.org

'MARK LOMBARDI' -- When Lombardi died in 2000, he was at the top of his game, producing beautiful, expansive drawings that diagrammed mysterious and insidious global connections among a bewildering array of politicians, military men and business people. Twenty-five large-scale works will be featured in this retrospective. Drawing Center, New York. Oct. 31-Dec. 20. (212) 219-2166. www.drawingcenter.org

November

'GLASS AND GLAMOUR: STEUBEN'S MODERN MOMENT IN NEW YORK, 1930-1960' -- More than just a show of luxurious decorative objects, this exhibition will frame Steuben's famously elegant glassware in the context of a midcentury moment when belief in the possibilities of modernity reached its high-water mark. Organized by Donald Albrecht, the exhibitions curator of the Cooper-Hewitt National Museum of Design , it will include 200 crystal pieces as well as drawings, books and catalogs. Museum of the City of New York. Nov. 7-April 25. (212) 534-1672. www.mcny.org

'PAST THINGS AND PRESENT: JASPER JOHNS SINCE 1983' -- Mr. Johns secured a permanent niche in art history for his proto-Pop works of the 50's and 60's.
--Whether his more recent work is as important has been a matter of continuing debate, for which this exhibition of more than 80 paintings, prints and drawings will provide rich fodder. Organized by the Walker's curator of permanent collections, Joan Rothfuss. Walker Art Center, Minneapolis. Nov. 9-Feb. 14. (612) 375-7600. www.walkerart.org

'UNREPENTANT EGO: THE SELF-PORTRAITS OF LUCAS SAMARAS' -- A perfect title for a retrospective of this maverick painter, sculptor and photographer, who has made himself a continuing subject for his wildly diverse and marvelously inventive work in painting, sculpture, installation, film and photography. The show will include more than 300 works dating from the 1950's to the present. Whitney Museum. Nov. 13-Feb. 8. (800) 944-8639. www.whitney.org

'JOAN JONAS: PERFORMANCE INSTALLATIONS 1976-2003' -- Surprisingly, considering her influence as a performance and video artist, this is Ms. Jonas's first major museum exhibition. It will include photographs, video, drawings and three installations not previously seen in the United States. Queens Museum of Art. Nov. 16-Feb. 1. (718) 592-9700. www.queensmuseu.org

'ARSHILE GORKY DRAWINGS' -- When it came to drawing in the nascent years of Abstract Expressionism, Gorky's only rival was de Kooning. This selection of 140 drawings, from Ingre-esque portraits to dreamy abstractions, should be a do-not-miss show. Whitney Museum. Nov. 20-Feb. 15. (800) 944-8639. www.whitney.org
JOHN CURRIN -- -- Mr. Currin was among the young artists who made the human figure safe for sophisticated painters to deal with. His sexy and grotesque images of women have provoked and antagonized people on a lot of different fronts. This 40-painting survey, organized by the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago and the Serpentine Gallery in London, affords a timely occasion to assess the achievement and influence of a still young and restless career. Whitney Museum. Nov. 20-Feb. 22. (800) 944-8639. www.whitney.org

'VERROCCHIO'S DAVID RESTORED' -- A famous Renaissance sculpture, Andrea del Verrocchio's bronze David, having recently undergone restoration, is coming to the United States for the first time. The David is thought to be a portrait of Leonardo da Vinci, Verrocchio's student. The presentation, which includes much information about technical issues of conservation, was organized by the High Museum of Art in Atlanta and the National Museum of the Bargello in Florence. High Museum. Nov. 15-Feb. 8 (404-733-4400). www.high.org. Traveling to the National Gallery, Washington, Feb. 13-March 21.

'MR. WHISTLER'S GALLERIES' -- Not only a great painter and printmaker, James McNeill Whistler was also an accomplished interior designer. In collaboration with the Virginia Museum of Fine Art, the Freer is organizing an exhibition about Whistler's exhibition and gallery design by recreating "Arrangement in Yellow and White," his design for a show of 51 of his etchings, and "Arrangement in Flesh Color and Grey," a show of 67 paintings, watercolors and pastels. Freer Gallery of Art, Washington. Nov. 20-April 4. (202) 633-4880. www.asia.si.edu

'WORSHIPPING THE ANCESTORS: CHINESE COMMEMORATIVE PORTRAITS --' This is the first major exhibition to study Chinese ancestor portraits as artworks and as objects of worship. Thirty-five of these highly wrought, near-life-size works owned by the Sackler will be featured along with textiles, furniture and other related objects dating from 1451 to 1943. Santa Barbara Museum of Art. Nov. 22-Feb. 15. (805) 963-4364. www
.sbmuseart.org

'CRIMES AND MISDEMEANORS: POLITICS AND U.S. ART OF THE 1980's' -- The 80's were a wildly contentious and, for art, an enormously fertile decade. This 55-artist exhibition will include political activist groups like ABC No Rio and Gran Fury and individual artists ranging from the neo-feminist Barbara Kruger to the neo-Pop artist Jeff Koons. Cincinnati Contemporary Arts Center. Nov. 22-Nov. 21, 2004. (513) 345-8400. www
.contemporaryartscenter.org

DAVID IRELAND -- One of the most intriguingly off-beat sculptors and conceptualists of the last three decades has his first retrospective. His best work is his own house, a live-in environmental sculpture in San Francisco. This 90-piece show will explore his play with homely materials and quirky processes. Oakland Museum of California. Nov. 22-March 14. (510) 238-2200. www.museumca.org

'CHRISTOFFER WILHELM ECKERSBERG, 1783-1853' -- Fans of 19th-century Danish painting -- something that deserves to be better known -- will not want to miss this 50-piece selection of works by one of its most influential figures. National Gallery, Washington. Nov. 23-Feb. 29. (202) 737-4215. www.nga.gov

RICHARD ARTSCHWAGER: 'PAINTING THEN AND NOW --' This exhibition examines the painting of one of the more intriguingly idiosyncratic and influential sculptors of the last four decades. Organized by the museum's director, Bonnie Clearwater, and coinciding with the artist's 80th birthday, it will focus on portraiture, architecture, landscape and current affairs derived from photographs and made on Celotex, a textured commercial building material that evocatively blurs the imagery. Museum of Contemporary Art, North Miami, Fla. Dec. 3-Feb. 15. (305) 893-6211. www
.mocanomi.org

ART BASEL MIAMI BEACH -- A lot of people who attended this huge international art fair last year had a great time. The American sister of the preeminent annual fair Art Basel in Switzerland will have, in addition to a great location, 160 dealers from five continents displaying 20th- and 21st-century art. Miami Beach Convention Center. Dec. 4-7.
www.artbasel.com

'ONLY SKIN DEEP: CHANGING VISIONS OF THE AMERICAN SELF' -- This major survey ofcontemporary and historical pictures explores how photography affects what and who we think we are as individuals and as members of different social groups. International Center for Photography, Dec. 12-Feb. 29. (212) 857-0000. www.icp.org

NEO RAUCH -- The jury may still be out on this East German-born painter, but the introduction of his Surrealistic Social Realism to New York a few years ago revealed a world gone awry, rendered in an illustrational style with muted and nostalgic colors. 'PLAYING WITH FIRE: EUROPEAN TERRA-COTTA MODELS, 1740-1840' -- Terra-cotta clay has been a major sculptural medium for millenniums but perhaps never used to greater artistic effect than in the hands of Neo-Classical sculptors in Europe. SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 38
