HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/FILM; 
Hippies and Orphans, Desperados and Dummies

BYLINE:  By DAVE KEHR; Compiled with the assistance of SUZANNE O'CONNOR

 BODY:
 September

All dates subject to change.

Wednesday

THE SAME RIVER TWICE -- A drug-enhanced trip down the Colorado River during the high-hippie era is recalled by five of its now middle-aged participants in Robb Moss's documentary. At Film Forum, Wednesday through Sept. 23.

Friday

CABIN FEVER -- Eli Roth's indie horror film is a rousing variation on a classic formula: a group of five college kids vacationing in a remote rural area find that one of them has been infected with a mysterious disease, one that turns ordinary human beings into flesh-eating monsters! And it's catching! With James DeBello and Joey Kern.

DUMMY -- From the writer-director Greg Pritikin, a romantic comedy about the friendship between a painfully shy young man (a pre-Oscar Adrien Brody) trying to find a voice through ventriloquism, and his neighbor (Milla Jovovich), a rock singer who performs in Yiddish. Illeana Douglas, Jessica Walter and Ron Leibman fill out the cast.

FORBIDDEN PHOTOGRAPHS: THE LIFE AND WORK OF CHARLES GATEWOOD -- The photographer who specialized in shooting outrageous Americana, from sex parties to self-styled vampires, profiled in a documentary by Bill Macdonald.

LOST IN TRANSLATION -- Sofia Coppola's second feature (after "The Virgin Suicides") casts Bill Murray as Bob Harris, a 70's movie star on the skids who visits Tokyo to shoot a whiskey commercial. Hanging out in his hotel, he meets a bright young woman (Scarlett Johansson) who shares his sense of disillusionment. With Giovanni Ribisi. A related article is on Page 39.

LUSTER -- Love among the blue-haired boys of the Los Angeles gay punk scene, starring Justin Herwick as a record store clerk with a crush on a handsome stranger. Everett Lewis wrote and directed.

MATCHSTICK MEN -- Roy (Nicolas Cage), a neurotic con man, is setting up a big score with his partner (Sam Rockwell), when a new member of the team turns up -- Roy's teenage daughter (Alison Lohman), who's eager to learn the tricks of her father's trade. The prolific Ridley Scott ("Gladiator," "Black Hawk Down") directs; with Bruce McGill and Melora Walters.

MILLENNIUM ACTRESS -- Satoshi Kon, who directed the creative and disturbing Japanese anime "Perfect Blue," returns with a new animated film, this one about a documentary maker whose interview with an elderly actress leads to some amazing revelations. DreamWorks is releasing this Japanese import, apparently hoping for another "Spirited Away."

ONCE UPON A TIME IN MEXICO -- The writer-director Robert Rodriguez shot this continuation of his "El Mariachi" franchise in 2002, before he began filming his hit of this summer, "Spy Kids 3-D: Game Over." Antonio Banderas returns as the guitar-strumming professional killer; this time he's looking for revenge on the drug kingpin (Willem Dafoe) who murdered his wife (Salma Hayek). Johnny Depp plays a C.I.A. agent with a few loose screws. With supporting appearances by Enrique Iglesias, Ruben Blades, Cheech Marin and Mickey Rourke.

PASSIONADA -- The Portuguese fishing community of New Bedford, Me., provides the background for Dan Ireland's study of a mother (Sofia Milos) and daughter (Emmy Rossum) driven apart by Mom's new boyfriend, a charming, continental cad (Jason Isaacs). With Theresa Russell, Seymour Cassel and Lupe Ontiveros.

SO CLOSE -- Two beautiful sisters (Shu Qi and Zhao Wei) operate a high-tech surveillance and assassination service, at least until a Hong Kong cop (Karen Mok) gets on their trail. Directed by the martial arts veteran Corey Yuen ("The Transporter").

WARRIOR OF LIGHT -- The German documentarist Monika Treut turns her attention from sex ("My Father Is Coming") to social work, with a film about a Brazilian woman who finds housing for street kids. At the BAM Rose Cinemas.

Sept. 19

ANYTHING ELSE -- Woody Allen takes a crack at Gen X romantic comedy with this account of a young New York writer (Jason Biggs, of "American Pie") who is having trouble with his neurotic girlfriend (the newly slim Christina Ricci). When she refuses to have sex with him anymore, he turns for help to the older writer who is his mentor in all things, a figure played by Mr. Allen himself.

CASA DE LOS BABYS -- Six American women -- Maggie Gyllenhaal, Daryl Hannah, Marcia Gay Harden, Susan Lynch, Mary Steenburgen and Lili Taylor -- check into a South American motel operated by Rita Moreno as they wait to adopt newborns from the local orphanage. John Sayles wrote and directed this ensemble drama.

COLD CREEK MANOR -- Sharon Stone (in her first major film since "The Muse") and Dennis Quaid as a pair of desperate urban dwellers who find their dream house in the country, only to learn that it has a previous owner (Stephen Dorff) who wants it back. Badly. Directed by Mike Figgis, returning to the studio scene after a long stretch of indies (including "Timecode"). With Juliette Lewis and Christopher Plummer.

DEMONLOVER -- From the French filmmaker Olivier Assayas, a postmodern thriller set in the chilly world of giant media corporations. Connie Nielsen is an acquisitions executive with her eye on a hot new Japanese porn site; Charles Berling plays her sinister colleague and Chloe Sevigny is her apparently naive young assistant, both of whom may or may not be undermining Ms. Nielson's mission. With a guest appearance by Gina Gershon.

EMERALD COWBOY -- How a Japanese businessman named Eishy Hayata made a fortune mining emeralds in Colombia, despite opposition from guerrillas and drug dealers. Mr. Hayata stars in and directs (with Andrew Molina) this blend of documentary and recreated scenes.

THE FIGHTING TEMPTATIONS -- When his rich aunt dies, a New York advertising executive (Cuba Gooding Jr.) is called back to his hometown in Georgia and finds that as a condition of inheriting his aunt's millions, he must form a successful gospel choir. In the course of his endeavors he is reunited with his childhood sweetheart (Beyonce Knowles), who happens to have a terrific voice. With Mike Epps, Faith Evans and Steve Harvey; the director is Jonathan Lynn ("My Cousin Vinny").

IN THIS WORLD -- The journey of two young refugees from Afghanistan to London, filmed as a pseudo-documentary by the fast-working Michael Winterbottom ("24 Hour Party People"). With Jamal Udin Torabi and Enayatullah Jumaudin.

MAMBO ITALIANO -- From Canada, acomedy about a gay television writer (Luke Kirby) plotting to move in with his longtime boyfriend, a cop (Peter Miller), without revealing the secret of his sexuality to his old-fashioned Italian-immigrant parents (Ginette Reno and Paul Sorvino). Does this one come with dinner? Emile Gaudreault directed.

SECONDHAND LIONS -- With puberty rapidly approaching, a gangly Haley Joel Osment stars as a city kid forced to spend a summer in Texas with his two eccentric uncles, played by Michael Caine and Robert Duvall. They turn out to be a couple of colorful characters who treat the boy to tales of their youthful adventures as bank robbers. Get ready for some big bear hugs! Tim McCanlies ("Dancer, Texas") is the director.

TIBET: CRY OF THE SNOW LION -- Ed Harris, Tim Robbins, Susan Sarandon and Martin Sheen are among the celebrities who contribute voice-over narration to this documentary study of Tibet's rich past, oppressed present and uncertain future. Tom Peosay is the director; the producers are Lon Bender, Maria Florio and Victoria Mudd.

TO BE AND TO HAVE -- Directed by Nicolas Philibert, this French documentary is an enchanting portrait of a small-town schoolteacher in northern France.

UNDERWORLD -- It's Vampires vs. Werewolves in the battle of the century -- or centuries, actually, since the conflict has extended across several of them. The vampires are the aristocrats of the underworld, led by Kate Beckinsale in a skintight leather suit; the werewolves have a working-class touch provided by Scott Speedman. Directed, with lots of digital flourish, by Len Wiseman, a music-video specialist.

Sept. 26

BOLLYWOOD/HOLLYWOOD -- Despite its title, Deepa Mehta's film is set largely in Toronto, where a successful Indian businessman (Rahul Khanna) hires a high- paid escort (Lisa Ray) to pretend to be his fiancee during his sister's marriage celebration. The uptight businessman succumbs to the working girl's irresistible charm, and rediscovers the joy of living.

BUBBA HO-TEP -- Two residents of an East Texas nursing home -- one believes himself to be Elvis Presley (Bruce Campbell), the other John F. Kennedy (Ossie Davis) -- team up to defeat a soul-sucking mummy who has risen from the local swamp. An original premise, if ever there was one, from the veteran horror film writer-director Don Coscarelli ("Phantasm").

DUPLEX -- Two New Yorkers, Drew Barrymore and Ben Stiller, discover the perfect apartment, then plot to murder the little old lady (Eileen Essell) who lives there. The actor Danny DeVito directed a cast that includes Harvey Fierstein and Swoosie Kurtz.

LUTHER -- The third screen version of John Osborne's play about Martin Luther, it stars Joseph Fiennes as the titular monk and was directed by a television-movie veteran, Eric Till. With Alfred Molina, Jonathan Firth, Claire Cox, Peter Ustinov and Bruno Ganz.

MY LIFE WITHOUT ME -- A 28-year-old Vancouver woman (Sarah Polley) lives in a trailer surrounded by her unfeeling, ungrateful family (including her mom, played by Deborah Harry, and dad, Alfred Molina). When she learns she has only a short time to live, she draws up a list of things to do -- including telling the truth and getting fake fingernails -- that helps her reawaken to the beauty of life. Does that list include seeing inspirational movies? Isabel Coixet wrote and directed this Canadian film.

THE RUNDOWN -- Don't look for Wildean banter in this study of a "retrieval expert" (played by the professional wrester the Rock) sent to the Amazon in search of a gang leader's son (Seann William Scott). Christopher Walken is the local heavy, the evil president of a gold-mining corporation; Rosario Dawson is the hotly disputed love interest. Directed by Peter Berg ("Corky Romano").

7 YEAR ZIGZAG -- Richard Green wrote, directed, scored and stars in this philosophical comedy done entirely in rhyming couplets. It's 1978, and an aspiring filmmaker is struggling to raise money by opening an Art Deco-themed nightclub.

UNDER THE TUSCAN SUN -- Diane Lane stars as the author Frances Mayes in a fictionalized version of Ms. Mayes's best-selling travel book. She's now a recent divorcee who buys a Tuscan villa on impulse and meets the Italian man of her dreams while she's fixing it up. Audrey Wells wrote the new story and directed it; with Sandra Oh, Lindsay Duncan and Raul Bova.

YOSSI & JAGGER -- Two Israeli soldiers fall in love while stationed together in an isolated post. Based on a true story and directed by Eytan Fox, this Israeli film stars Ohad Knoller and Yehuda Levi.

October

Oct. 3

ANYTHING BUT LOVE -- Robert Cary's film aspires to the look and tone of a 1950's musical, offering Isabel Rose as a cabaret singer in an unfulfilling affair with a lawyer (Andrew McCarthy).

BOUNCE KO GALS -- Masato Harada ( Kamikaze Taxi ) directed this Japanese film about a 16-year-old schoolgirl who becomes a prostitute for one night to earn money for a trip to America. Sounds like more Japanese comic nihilism in the Takashi Miike tradition ("Ichi the Killer" ), though Mr. Harada cites his influences as Howard Hawks and Samuel Fuller.

THE EVENT -- From the Canadian filmmaker Thom Fitzgerald ("The Hanging Garden"), a police drama set in New York City. Parker Posey abandons her usual ditzy type to play an N.Y.P.D. inspector investigating a series of suspicious "suicides" in Chelsea. Don McKellar, Sarah Polley and Olympia Dukakis also star.

THE FLOWER OF EVIL -- The French New Wave director Claude Chabrol may be 73, but he's showing no signs of slowing down: his new feature is a deliciously perverse study of intermarriage among France's provincial bourgeoisie, with intimations of murder, incest and collaborationist secrets deep in the past. Nathalie Baye, Benoit Magimel and Thomas Chabrol (the director's son) star.

THE HUMAN STAIN -- Robert Benton directs Nicholas Meyer's adaptation of Philip Roth's novel. Anthony Hopkins plays Coleman Silk, a college professor whose relationship with a younger woman (Nicole Kidman) forces him into a violent confrontation with his past -- as well as the young woman's angry husband (Ed Harris). Gary Sinise is Silk's best friend (and Mr. Roth's alter ego), Nathan Zuckerman.

OUT OF TIME -- The reliable Carl Franklin ("Devil in a Blue Dress") directed this noirish thriller about a police captain (Denzel Washington) in a small Florida town who dips into a pile of cash being held as evidence so he can run off with the love of his life, sultry Sanaa Lathan. But she turns out to be false and heartless, taking the cash and leaving Mr. Washington to face disgrace -- and plot his revenge -- alone.

THE SCHOOL OF ROCK -- The hard-working Mike White ("Chuck and Buck," "The Good Girl") wrote this comedy about a down-and-out rock musician (Jack Black) who takes a job teaching music at a private grade school. The kids, of course, learn more than the principal (Joan Cusack) would prefer. With Sarah Silverman and Mr. White as a fellow teacher; Richard Linklater ("Waking Life") directs.

THE STATION AGENT -- Tom McCarthy's Sundance hit -- it won the Dramatic Audience Award, the Waldo Salt Screenwriting Award and a special jury performance award for its star, Patricia Clarkson -- is an eye-wiper about a group of lovable losers who band together for moral support. Peter Dinklage is Finbar, an emotionally isolated dwarf who inherits an abandoned small-town railroad station; Ms. Clarkson is a neighbor still reeling from the breakup of her marriage; and Bobby Cannavale is a chatty hot-dog vendor who opens a stand near Finbar's property.

WONDERLAND -- The sordid life and death of the 1970's porn star John Holmes (a k a Johnny Wadd). Val Kilmer plays Holmes; the cast includes Kate Bosworth, Christina Applegate, Lisa Kudrow and Dylan McDermott; James Cox directs. A related article is on Page 67.

Oct. 8

BUS 174 -- When the Rio de Janeiro police bungled a bus hijacking in 2000, killing a woman held hostage instead of the hijacker, who was trying to surrender, it set off a violent public reaction much like the Rodney King riots in Los Angeles. Jose Padilha's documentary examines the incident, reconstructing the hijacker's wretched childhood. At Film Forum, through Oct. 21. A related article is on Page 68.

MYSTIC RIVER -- Clint Eastwood directs this adaptation of Dennis Lehane's psychological thriller. In a working-class Boston neighborhood, three childhood friends are thrown back together when the daughter of one of them is found brutally murdered. Sean Penn is the bereaved father; Tim Robbins a prime suspect (with abuse in his past); and Kevin Bacon the cop on the case. As always in Mr. Eastwood's films, the secondary women's roles come to assume a surprising importance; here they're played by Marcia Gay Harden and Laura Linney.

Oct. 10

DOPAMINE -- One of a package of four films to be released in theaters this year by the Sundance Channel, Mark Decena's feature is a comedy about a computer programmer (John Livingston) whose theories about rational romance are defeated by a schoolteacher (Sabrina Lloyd) he meets in a bar.

GIRLS WILL BE GIRLS -- Richard Day's camp comedy sounds like a drag remake of "Valley of the Dolls," following three Hollywood actresses (all played by men) as they face romantic disaster, creeping age and tottering careers.

GOOD BOY! -- Family entertainment from Jim Henson Pictures, in which we discover that dogs are actually emissaries from outer space, sent to take over our planet but co-opted by friendly humans. Matthew Broderick provides the voice of Canid 3942, a hound who has been dispatched from the Dog Star to see what's holding things up, only to be adopted by a lovable, all-American kid (Liam Aiken).

INTOLERABLE CRUELTY -- After an unscrupulous Beverly Hills divorce lawyer (George Clooney) frames a client's wife (Catherine Zeta-Jones) to avoid a settlement, she vows revenge, which means marrying him and taking him to the cleaners. Originally a Jonathan Demme project, the picture passed into the hands of Joel and Ethan Coen. With Geoffrey Rush and Billy Bob Thornton.

KILL BILL VOL. 1 -- Quentin Tarantino's first film since "Jackie Brown" is an homage to ultra-violent Asian action films. It's being released in two, 90-minute parts, with the next installment in 2004. Uma Thurman stars as the Bride, a professional assassin betrayed by her employer, Bill (David Carradine). She swears revenge on him and his other employees, played by Lucy Liu, Daryl Hannah, Vivica A. Fox and Michael Madsen.

PORN THEATER -- Titled "La Chatte a deux tetes" ("The Cat With Two Heads") in France, Jacques Nolot's film chronicles the love affair of a 50-year-old man and a young projectionist who works in a Parisian sex-movie theater.

Oct. 17

KHACHATURIAN -- The Soviet composer, whose "Sabre Dance" remains a favorite, is examined in a documentary.

9 DEAD GAY GUYS -- A grisly black comedy about a couple of earnest young Irishmen who arrive in London hoping to pursue careers as male prostitutes but instead get mixed up in a murderous pursuit of a mattress stuffed with money. With Brendan Mackey, Glen Mulhern and Steven Berkoff; Lab Ky Mo directs.

PIECES OF APRIL -- The hottest acquisition at the 2003 Sundance Film Festival, Peter Hedges's film is a comedy that finds an East Village bohemian, Katie Holmes, struggling to cook a Thanksgiving dinner for her conventional suburban family. Oliver Platt and Patricia Clarkson are her anxious parents.

PREY FOR ROCK AND ROLL -- Gina Gershon stars as a rock musician pushing 40 who has one last shot at the big time when her band gets an offer to open for a major act. But can her fellow girl-group members -- Shelly Cole, Drea DeMatteo and Lori Petty -- overcome their assorted personal crises and get it together in time for the gig? Alex Steyermark directs.

THE RETURNER -- Takeshi Kaneshiro ("Chungking Express") as a Tokyo assassin who accidentally shoots an emissary from the future (Ann Suzuki), sent back in time to prevent an alien invasion. Takashi Yamazaki directed this Japanese import.

RUNAWAY JURY -- John Grisham's novel finally emerges from six years in development hell; it stars John Cusack as a mysterious operative who tries to influence a trial involving a gun manufacturer. Rachel Weisz is his equally cunning girlfriend; Gene Hackman and Dustin Hoffman play the lawyers in the case. Gary Fleder ("Impostor") directs.

SYLVIA -- The gifted New Zealand director Christine Jeffs ("Rain") tackles the story of Sylvia Plath (Gwyneth Paltrow) and her disastrous marriage to the poet Ted Hughes (Daniel Craig). Expect an Oscar push. With Ms. Paltrow's real mom, Blythe Danner, as Plath's mother.

THE TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE -- Tobe Hooper's seminal 1974 horror film, about a family of crazed backwoods killers, has spawned three sequels and now this remake, directed by the music video veteran Marcus Nispel. Not too many names in the cast: Jessica Biel, Eric Balfour and Andrew Bryniarski as the iconic Leatherface.

VERONICA GUERIN -- The true story of Veronica Guerin (Cate Blanchett), a Dublin journalist whose reports on her city's drug scene led to her murder. Joel Schumacher directs an impressive supporting cast: Colin Farrell, Brenda Fricker and Ciaran Hinds. A related article is on Page 40.

Oct. 22

IN THE CUT -- Meg Ryan is a sexually repressed college writing teacher whose libido is stirred by a series of sex crimes in her neighborhood. Mark Ruffalo is the investigating officer, with whom Ms. Ryan's character has a passionate affair. A first American film for the New Zealand writer-director Jane Campion ("The Piano"), adapted from the novel by Susanna Moore.

MORNING SUN -- China's Cultural Revolution, explored in all its horror, in a documentary directed by Carma Hinton, Geremie R. Barme and Richard Gordon. At Film Forum, through Nov. 4.

Oct. 24

BEYOND BORDERS -- A spoiled socialite, Angelina Jolie, pursues an idealistic doctor (Clive Owen of "Croupier") on a tour of the world's trouble spots, from Africa to Asia, developing a soul of her own along the way. With Noah Emmerich and Linus Roache; Martin Campbell directs.

BROTHER BEAR -- The voices of Joaquin Phoenix, Rick Moranis and Dave Thomas (reviving their Doug and Bob McKenzie characters) contribute to this Disney animated film, about a young Inuit who is transformed into his most hated enemy -- a bear.

ELEPHANT -- A M iddle American high school comes under attack by two disaffected students. Gus Van Sant's film, inspired by Columbine, won two major awards at this year's Cannes Film Festival, for best film and best director. Mr. Van Sant uses overlapping points of view to tell his story, giving it a "Rashomon"-like effect. With Eric Deulen and Alex Frost; Timothy Bottoms and Matt Malloy are among the clueless adults.

GOTHIKA -- A psychiatrist (Halle Berry) awakens from a blackout to find herself a patient in the hospital where she works, accused of having killed her husband (Charles Dutton). There are ghosts in it, too, as well as Penelope Cruz, Robert Downey Jr. and Bernard Hill. The young French filmmaker Mathieu Kassovitz directed, in his English-language debut.

LIL' PIMP -- A parody of squeaky-clean family cartoons, in which a lovable 9-year-old (voiced by Mark Brooks) and his stable of prostitutes caper through a Middle American suburb. Directed (in the economical Flash animation process) by Mr. Brooks and Peter Gilstrap, with the voices of Ludacris, Lil' Kim, Bernie Mac and William Shatner.

SCARY MOVIE 3 -- Things come full circle as David Zucker, a member of the team that invented the modern movie parody with "Airplane!," steps in to direct the latest installment in one of the many series directly inspired by his own work. With the Wayans brothers gone, both as filmmakers and stars, Mr. Zucker has brought in some veterans of the genre, including Charlie Sheen, Leslie Nielsen, Pamela Anderson, George Carlin and Eddie Griffin.

THE SINGING DETECTIVE -- Dennis Potter's 1986 television drama adapted as a feature film. It has Robert Downey Jr. stepping into the central role of a hospitalized writer who dreams about being a hard-boiled detective. A boatload of guest stars, including Mel Gibson, Katie Holmes, Robin Wright Penn and Adrien Brody. Keith Gordon ("Mother Night") directs.

SISTER HELEN -- The life of Helen Travis, a nun who runs a halfway house in the Bronx, explored in a documentary by Rob Fruchtman and Rebecca Cammisa.

Oct. 31

ALIEN -- The 1979 haunted-house-in-outer-space horror classic comes back, with a digital refurbishing and some newly added scenes. Ridley Scott is still the director (though he's now Sir Ridley); Sigourney Weaver remains the star.

DIE MOMMIE DIE -- The playwright and drag performer Charles Busch wrote and stars in this sendup of Joan Crawford's late career as a horror movie star. Angela Arden (Mr. Busch) is a fading star surrounded by leeching relatives (Natasha Lyonne, Philip Baker Hall) standing in the way of her elopement with a hunky actor played by Jason Priestly. Someone has got to go! Directed by Mark Rucker.

GIRLHOOD -- Liz Garbus, co-director of the Sundance-winning documentary "The Farm," returns with a study of two pre-teenagers accused of violent crimes.

SHATTERED GLASS -- The cautionary true-life tale of the ambitious young journalist Stephen Glass (Hayden Christensen), who was found to have fabricated many of the stories he wrote for The New Republic. Chloe Sevigny plays his sympathetic co-worker; Hank Azaria is Michael Kelly, the editor who brought Mr. Glass on board. Billy Ray directs.

SUSPENDED ANIMATION -- The Michigan-based filmmaker John Hancock ("Bang the Drum Slowly") presents the tale of a Hollywood animator (Alex McArthur) held prisoner in the Michigan woods by a pair of homicidal, flesh-eating sisters. He escapes, makes his way home and the fun begins.

November

Nov. 5

THE MATRIX REVOLUTIONS -- The third and final installment in the Matrix trilogy. Look for major metaphysical payoffs, as the alien ships finally invade Zion (earth's last colony of humans), causing great anxiety for the cyber-revolutionaries Keanu Reeves, Laurence Fishburne and Carrie-Anne Moss. Monica Belluci, whose character (a computer-generated femme fatale) was introduced very briefly in the previous episode, presumably has more to do in this one. Lots of Australians in the supporting cast (the film was shot in Warner's down-under studios), including Hugo Weaving and Bruce Spence.

THE REVOLUTION WILL NOT BE TELEVISED -- The filmmakers Kim Bartley and Donnacha O'Briain were on hand in April of last year when Venezuela's populist president, Hugo Chavez, was threatened by a right-wing coup, and managed to record most of the action on videotape. At Film Forum, through Nov. 11.

Nov. 7

ELF -- Accidentally transported to the North Pole when he falls in Santa's bag, a human child grows up to be Will Ferrell, and a little disturbed that he doesn't resemble the other elves. With the help of Mr. Claus (Ed Asner) and his chief assistant (Bob Newhart), he sets out for New York in search of his biological father (James Caan). With Zooey Deschanel and Mary Steenburgen; Jon Favreau directs.

IN MY SKIN -- When a young woman accidentally cuts herself at a party, the wound opens up a whole new world of sadomasochistic self-abusive pleasure for her. Marina De Van, Francois Ozon's co-writer on "Under the Sand" and "Eight Women," directs and stars.

Nov. 12

MY ARCHITECT -- Nathaniel Kahn, the son of the celebrated architect Louis I. Kahn, examines the many mysteries in his late father's life in this documentary, which had its premiere at the 2003 New Directors/New Films festival.

Nov. 14

ETERNAL SUNSHINE OF THE SPOTLESS MIND -- Another impossible-to-summarize plot line from the mind of Charlie Kaufman ("Adaptation"), though the broad outlines look like this: Jim Carrey and Kate Winslet play a battling couple who have their bad memories erased by a mad scientist (Tom Wilkinson), and find themselves falling in love again. But Mr. Carrey's character senses that something is wrong, causing the doctor and several of his assistants (Kirsten Dunst, Elijah Wood, Mark Ruffalo) to invade his dreams. I think. Michel Gondry ("Human Nature") directs.

HONEY -- Jessica Alba plays a tough girl from the inner city who becomes a top music video choreographer, only to quit show business in disgust when a producer makes a pass at her. She returns to her roots, teaching kids to dance (among them, Lil' Romeo). With Mekhi Phifer; directed by Bille Woodruff.

LOONEY TUNES: BACK IN ACTION -- Warner Brothers follows "Space Jam" with another attempt to revive their stable of cartoon characters, including Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck and Yosemite Sam. The movie is a mix of animation and live action, the latter directed by Joe Dante ("Gremlins") and featuring Brendan Fraser and Jenna Elfman as secret agents fighting a plot by the Acme Corporation to take over the world. With Steve Martin and Timothy Dalton.

MASTER AND COMMANDER: THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD -- Fox is looking to tap the "Gladiator" audience with this adaptation, theoretically the first in a series, from Patrick O'Brian's popular naval adventure novels, set in the 19th century. Russell Crowe is Mr. O'Brian's recurring hero, the sea captain Jack Aubrey, who gets to say things like "All right, lads!" as his frigate is chased through the open seas by a vicious privateer. Directed by Peter Weir; Paul Bettany and Ian Mercer are Mr. Crowe's co-stars.

THE SINGING FOREST -- From the writer-director Jorge Ameer, the story of a young couple killed during the Holocaust and reincarnated in the present day. Mr. Ameer also stars, with Erik Morris and Shelley Price.

TUPAC: RESURRECTION -- A portrait of the rap artist Tupac Shakur, who was fatally shot in 1996, assembled from music videos and interviews. Lauren Lazin directed for MTV Films.

21 GRAMS -- That's the weight of the human soul, as claimed by one of the characters in this English-language film by Mexico's acclaimed young director Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu ("Amores Perros"). A university professor with a bad heart (Sean Penn), an ex-con who works in a Christian center (Benicio Del Toro) and a woman who has lost her husband and two daughters (Naomi Watts) find their fates intertwined as Guillermo Arriaga's screenplay unfolds.

Nov. 19

THE COOLER -- Known as the "unluckiest man in Las Vegas," Bernie Lootz (William H. Macy) makes his living as a "cooler," standing next to big winners at the Vegas tables and cooling down their luck. But when he falls in love with a cocktail waitress (Maria Bello), his luck takes a turn for the better -- and his employer (Alec Baldwin) couldn't be unhappier. Wayne Kramer directed.

Nov. 20

EL LEYTON -- A fisherman disappears, leaving the lives of his family in chaos. Gonzalo Justiniano directed this Chilean feature, which has been making the festival rounds.

Nov. 21

AROUND THE WORLD IN 80 DAYS -- Steve Coogan is Phileas Fogg and Jackie Chan is his resourceful valet Passepartout in this latest adaptation of Jules Verne's adventure novel about a mad Englishman who bets that he can circumnavigate the world in 80 days. Like the Mike Todd version of 1956, the picture is full of cameo appearances by stars like Jim Broadbent, Kathy Bates, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Owen Wilson, Rob Schneider and John Cleese. An ambitious project for one of Adam Sandler's house directors, Frank Coraci ("The Waterboy," "The Wedding Singer").

THE BARBARIAN INVASIONS -- A loose sequel to the French Canadian hit of 1986, "The Decline of the American Empire." Directed and written (again) by Denys Arcand, the picture picks up the first film's community of oversexed academics and asks them to confront the coming specter of death, as the charismatic womanizer Remy (Remy Girard) slowly succumbs to cancer. Stephane Rousseau plays Remy's son, who returns from a busy career in London to take care of the father he never really knew. The film picked up two awards this year at Cannes, one for Mr. Arcand's screenplay and the other for the actress Marie-Josee Croze.

DR. SEUSS' THE CAT IN THE HAT -- Mike Myers plays the trouble-making feline of Dr. Seuss' famous children's book in this live-action adaptation, directed by the longtime production designer Bo Welch ("Edward Scissorhands"). Kelly Preston is the concerned mom; Sean Hayes provides the crucial voice of thee Fish. With Dakota Fanning, Spencer Breslin and Alec Baldwin.

LOVE ACTUALLY -- Richard Curtis, the screenwriter of "Four Weddings and a Funeral," "Notting Hill" and "Bridget Jones's Diary," takes up directing with an ensemble piece that intertwines 10 different love stories. One takes place between the British prime minister (Hugh Grant) and his new tea girl (Martine McCutcheon); the other lovestruck actors include Laura Linney, Rowan Atkinson, Colin Firth, Keira Knightley, Denise Richards and Alan Rickman.

RADIO -- The heartwarming tale of a high school football coach (Ed Harris) who shocks his South Carolina town by taking a mentally challenged young man (Cuba Gooding Jr.) under his wing. Despite all the odds, their friendship endures for decades. Radio is the boy's nickname; the director's name is Michael Tollin. With a rare appearance by Debra Winger.

THE TRIPLETS OF BELLEVILLE -- From France, an animated feature directed by Sylvain Chomet about a young misfit who grows up to be a championship bicycle rider, with some help from three former vaudeville singers.

Nov. 26

BAD SANTA -- A different kind of Christmas story from the director Terry Zwigoff ("Ghost World"). Billy Bob Thornton and Bernie Mac are a pair of professional criminals who tour the shopping malls of the Midwest, posing as Santa and his elf and knocking over stores as soon as the lights go down. John Ritter is the mall manager who gets hip to their scam. Joel and Ethan Coen, executive producers, contributed to the screenplay.

EL BONAERENSE -- Pablo Trapero's film satirizes the rampant corruption of his home country, Argentina, through the story of a provincial locksmith (Jorge Roman) who becomes a Buenos Aires cop and discovers that everyone is on the take. At Film Forum through Dec. 9.

IN AMERICA -- Jim Sheridan's drama, first announced last fall, is about a hardy family of Irish immigrants (Samantha Morton and Paddy Considine, plus two children) living in an East Harlem squat. With Djimon Hounsou as an angry downstairs neighbor. A related article is on Page 72.

THE HAUNTED MANSION -- After Disney turned the theme park ride "Pirates of the Caribbean" into a live-action hit, it got to work on another Disneyland attraction. Eddie Murphy plays the head of household who learns from a ghost how to spend more time with his family. With Jennifer Tilly, Don Knotts and Terence Stamp; the director is Rob Minkoff, fresh off the "Stuart Little" films.

TIMELINE -- Five junior archaeologists go 600 years back in time to rescue their professor, who has been trapped in the Middle Ages. Paul Walker heads the team; also in the cast are Frances O'Connor, Billy Connolly and David Thewlis. Richard Donner, the creator of the "Lethal Weapons" films, directs from the novel by Michael Crichton.

Nov. 28

INDEPENDENT SPIRITS -- A documentary study of John and Faith Hubley, animators who broke with the naturalism of the Disney tradition to help create the modernist style of the 50's and 60's. Directed by Sybil DelGaudio.

December

Dec. 5

JAPANESE STORY -- One of the few popular successes at this year's Cannes Film Festival, Sue Brooks's Australian film is about an Australian geologist (Toni Collette) thrown in with a surly Japanese man (Gotaro Tsunashima) as they explore the Pilbara desert, one of the earth's last remaining uncharted regions.

THE LAST SAMURAI -- The opening of Japan to the West as seen through the eyes of a Winchester salesman, played by Tom Cruise, who arrives in Tokyo to train the imperial troops in the use of this strange new weapon, the rifle. But he is captured by samurai and trained in their noble traditions, and must decide which side of the cultural divide he belongs on. A big production, directed by Edward Zwick from a script by John Logan. With Ken Watanabe, Billy Connolly, Tony Goldwyn and Timothy Spall.

MONSIEUR IBRAHIM -- In the Arab quarter of Paris in the 1960's, an elderly convenience store owner (Omar Sharif) takes a young Jewish man (Pierre Boulanger) under his wing, teaching him the mystic ways of Sufism. Francois Dupeyron directed this French production, adapted from a best-selling novel by Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt.

Dec. 10

THE MISSING -- When Ron Howard's "Alamo" project fell through, he turned to this western based on a novel by Thomas Eidson. Tommy Lee Jones is a wanderer who returns to his New Mexico family after several years of living with the Apaches. He finds that his wife is dead and his daughter (Cate Blanchett) despises him. But when a gang of Army deserters kidnap Mr. Jones's younger daughter, Ms. Blanchett joins him in riding for revenge. Look for a big Oscar push.

POWER TRIP -- What's happened to the power supply in post-Soviet Georgia? That's the real question after an American company enters the market after the state relinquished control. Paul Devlin directed this documentary, at Film Forum through Dec. 23.

Dec. 11

ABOUNA -- Set in Chad, Mahamat-Saleh Haroun's film tells the story of two brothers who, suddenly abandoned by their father, seek solace at the movies. "Mr. Haroun, for his part, is alive to every nuance of feeling and immune to sentimentality," said A. O. Scott of The New York Times when "Abouna" was shown in the 2002 New Directors/New Films festival.

Dec. 12

THE GIRL WITH A PEARL EARRING -- Scarlett Johansson in a period piece that finds her, as an unassuming Dutch housekeeper, modeling for the famous painting by Johannes Vermeer (Colin Firth). Tom Wilkinson and Judy Parfitt also appear in this British film directed by Peter Webber ("Wagner's Women"). A related article is on Page 39.

LOVE DON'T COST A THING -- An African-American remake of the 1987 white-bread comedy "Can't Buy Me Love," in which a high school nerd (Nick Cannon) hires a cheerleader (Christina Milian) to be his date for the prom. Steve Harvey plays the boy's father; Troy Beyer directed.

SOMETHING'S GOTTA GIVE -- From Nancy Meyers, the director of "What Women Want," a comedy about an aging playboy (Jack Nicholson) who falls ill at the home of his young girlfriend's mother, only to find himself strangely attracted to the older woman -- no surprise, since she's played by Diane Keaton. But there's another complication in the person of Keanu Reeves, playing a young doctor who has a crush on Ms. Keaton himself.

THE STATEMENT -- High Oscar credibility, given its statuette-laden crew: the director Norman Jewison (an Irving G. Thalberg Memorial Award winner), the writer Ronald Harwood ("The Pianist") and the star Michael Caine ("The Cider House Rules," "Hannah and Her Sisters"). Mr. Caine plays an elderly Frenchman whose past, as a Nazi sympathizer responsible for denouncing 14 Jews, is uncovered by an investigator played by Tilda Swinton.

STUCK ON YOU -- Not the 1984 Troma classic, but a new comedy from the Farrelly brothers. Matt Damon and Greg Kinnear are Siamese twins who have shared a happy life together, as dual goalies for the hockey team and an unbeatable pair of wrestlers. But now Mr. Kinnear's character wants to go to Los Angeles to pursue a television career, causing problems for the less ambitious Mr. Damon. With Seymour Cassel, Evan Mendes and a lot of celebrities playing themselves: Meryl Streep, Jack Nicholson, Al Pacino and others.

Dec. 17

LORD OF THE RINGS: THE RETURN OF THE KING -- Peter Jackson's three-part adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien's "Ring" saga comes to a thundering conclusion with this episode, in which Viggo Mortensen's Aragorn emerges as the legitimate heir to the ancient kings. All your favorites are back: Elijah Wood, Sean Astin, Ian McKellen, John Rhys-Davies, Orlando Bloom, Christopher Lee, Andy Serkis, Liv Tyler, Ian Holm and Miranda Otto. A related article is on Page 39.

Dec. 18

BIG FISH -- Finally, a new picture from Tim Burton ("Edward Scissorhands"). This is a project he inherited from Steven Spielberg, and it still sounds more suited to Mr. Spielberg's talents than to Mr. Burton's: it's about a young man (Billy Crudup) who tries to distill the true biography of his dying father (Albert Finney) by looking for the kernels of truth in the many tall tales he has told over the years about his life in the South as a traveling salesman. Much of the movie is devoted to flashbacks, with Ewan McGregor playing Mr. Finney's character as a young man. Adapted by John August from Daniel Wallace's novel; with Helena Bonham Carter, Danny DeVito, Jessica Lange, Alison Lohman and Steve Buscemi.

Dec. 19

CALENDAR GIRLS -- The true tale of the middle-aged members of a woman's club in Yorkshire, England, who posed nude for a calendar to raise money for the medical research that might save the husband of one of the members from leukemia. Helen Mirren, never that shy about dropping her knickers ("The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover") stars, with support from Julie Walters and Penelope Wilton.

MONA LISA SMILE -- A stand-up-and-cheer drama, starring the stand-up-and-cheer Julia Roberts as a noncomformist hired to teach art appreciation at Wellesley in the 1950's. But her real specialties are self-esteem and proto-feminism, as she casts a Jean Brodie-ish spell over her students (who include Kirsten Dunst, Julia Stiles and Maggie Gyllenhaal). Of course, the reactionary forces on the faculty try to drive her out. Mike Newell ("Four Weddings and a Funeral," "Enchanted April") directed.

Dec. 24

CHILDREN OF LOVE -- From Belgium, the tale of three children destroyed by their parents' divorces. Geoffrey Enthoven directed. At Film Forum through Jan. 6.

Dec. 25

THE ALAMO -- The director John Lee Hancock ("The Rookie") stepped in when Ron Howard dropped out over budget disputes with Disney (he remains on board as a producer). It's the time-honored tale of a small band of Texans, including Sam Houston (Dennis Quaid), Jim Bowie (Jason Patric) and Davy Crockett (Billy Bob Thornton), defending a mission-turned-fort against the vastly more powerful Mexican army, led by Santa Anna (Emilio Echevarria). With a script by John Sayles and Stephen Gaghan, this promises to be a more culturally sensitive version than the John Wayne film of 1960.

CHEAPER BY THE DOZEN -- A loose remake of the 1950 family favorite that starred Clifton Webb as an efficiency expert and father of 12; the efficiency angle has been excised from the new screenplay, attributed to no fewer than 11 writers. Now, Steve Martin is a college football coach who must uproot his large family when he gets a new job in a new city. Among the offspring: Hilary Duff, Piper Perabo and Tom Welling; Bonnie Hunt is Mom. Shawn Levy ("Just Married") directed.

COLD MOUNTAIN -- Charles Frazier's best-selling literary novel about a wounded Civil War soldier (Jude Law) and his long journey home to North Carolina, where his sweetheart (Nicole Kidman) is waiting for him. It's been adapted by the writer-director Anthony Minghella ("The English Patient") and filled out with a stunning supporting cast: Renee Zellweger, Natalie Portman, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Giovanni Ribisi, Charlie Hunnam, Ray Winstone and Donald Sutherland.

THE COMPANY -- Neve Campbell, an erstwhile ballerina, wrote and produced this study of work habits and relationships within a Chicago-based dance company. Robert Altman directs; the cast includes James Franco and Malcolm McDowell (as the artistic director). A related article is on Page 40.

HOUSE OF SAND AND FOG -- Ben Kingsley is Massoud Amir Behrani, an exile from Iran (where he belonged to the Shah's inner circle) now trying to make a life for himself in America. He sees his chance at achieving the American dream when he buys a house at a back-taxes auction, only to find that the former owner, Kathy Nicolo (Jennifer Connelly), still has a valid claim on the property and is determined to get it back. The first-timer Vadim Perelman directs this adaptation of the novel by Andre Dubus III.

PAYCHECK -- One of those bafflingly complex Philip K. Dick illusion-and-reality plots, this time about an engineer (Ben Affleck) who tries to quit his top-level security job and wakes up to find that his memory has disappeared. And there's a government agent (Michael C. Hall) on his trail as well. With Uma Thurman, Aaron Eckhart and Paul Giamatti; the inimitable John Woo ("The Killer") directed.

PETER PAN -- The latest in a long, long list of adaptations of J. M. Barrie's play, about a group of London children transported to the mysterious realm of Never-Never Land, to do battle with the infinitely evil Captain Hook (Jason Isaacs, this time). Jeremy Sumpter is Peter, Rachel Hurd-Wood is Wendy and Olivia Williams is Mrs. Darling. Weary dads dragged along by the kids will have the consolation of Ludivine Sagnier (the French actress who starred in "Swimming Pool") as Tinkerbell. The Australian P. J. Hogan ("My Best Friend's Wedding") directed.

SPARTAN -- David Mamet wrote and directed this thriller about a government agent (Val Kilmer) who is assigned to rescue the kidnapped daughter of the president but who finds that the kidnapping is only the tip of a nasty iceberg involving a nefarious plot within the White House. With Derek Luke, William H. Macy, Kristin Bell and Natalija Nogulich.

YOUNG BLACK STALLION -- Made in the giant-screen Imax process by the Walt Disney organization, Simon Wincer's film is a prequel to Carroll Ballard's beautiful children's film of 1979. Here, we discover that the horse had a previous relationship, with a young girl abandoned in the desert during World War II. With Biama Tamimi and Patrick Elyas.

Dec. 26

THE FOG OF WAR -- Subtitled "Eleven Lessons of Robert S. McNamara," this documentary by Errol Morris links a probing interview with the former secretary of defense (for Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson) with newsreel clips illustrating his exploits. With a Philip Glass score.

2004

Jan. 9

FIRST DAUGHTER -- When the president's daughter, played by Katie Holmes, goes off to college, she refuses to be accompanied by a squad of Secret Service agents. Instead, the feds plant a young operative (Marc Blucas) among the students to keep an eye on her, never dreaming that the two will fall in love. Yeah. Forest Whitaker, a wonderful actor ("Bird") and a hard-working director ("Hope Floats"), is the filmmaker in chief.

Jan. 16

THE PERFECT SCORE -- Erika Christensen leads a group of high school students in a plot to steal the answers to the SAT Chris Evans, Scarlett Johansson and Darius Miles also star under Brian Robbins's direction.

TORQUE -- An outlaw biker (Martin Henderson) returns to his hometown and finds himself blamed for a murder he didn't commit. The victim's brother, the most feared motorcycle gang leader in the country (Ice Cube), swears to snuff him. That patented Ice Cube sneer is bound to be on ample display in this genre piece, directed by Joseph Kahn.

Jan. 30

THE BIG BOUNCE -- The gifted George Armitage ("Miami Blues") wrote and directed this adaptation of Elmore Leonard's novel about an amoral drifter (Owen Wilson) caught up in a web of sex, murder and betrayal among Miami real estate developers. With Sara Foster, Morgan Freeman, Gary Sinise and Charlie Sheen.

Feb. 13

DIRTY DANCING HAVANA NIGHTS -- A remake of the 1987 hit "Dirty Dancing," with the action shifted from the Catskills to prerevolutionary Cuba. Romola Garai plays the naive American girl vacationing in Havana with her family; Diego Luna is the local teenager who admires her dancing style and teaches her a few new moves of his own. Patrick Swayze, who starred in the original, makes a guest appearance; Guy Ferland directed.

Feb. 27

BROKEN LIZARD'S CLUB DREAD -- The Broken Lizard comedy troupe, most recently responsible for "Super Troopers," returns with a look at life in a tropical resort -- a life somewhat complicated by the presence of a serial killer. Jay Chandrasekhar stars and directs, with appearances by Bill Paxton, Kevin Heffernan, Steve Lemme, Paul Soter and Erik Stolhanske.

March 5

HIDALGO -- In 1890, an Arabian chief (Omar Sharif) invites an American cowboy (Viggo Mortensen) to ride as the first Westerner in a legendary horse race across the desert. A family film going out under the Walt Disney banner, it was directed by the Disney vet Joe Johnston ("Honey, I Shrunk the Kids") and also stars Malcolm McDowell and Zuleikha Robinson. A related article is on Page 39.

STARSKY & HUTCH -- The writer-director Todd Phillips, of "Old School," takes on the 70's television show about a pair of hot-dogging detectives. Ben Stiller is Starsky, Owen Wilson is Hutch, and, in an inspired casting coup, Snoop Dogg is Huggy Bear, the duo's ace informer. With Vince Vaughn, Fred Williamson and Chris Penn.

March 19

NED KELLY -- Australia's most notorious (and beloved) outlaw is portrayed by Heath Ledger in a film based on Robert Drewe's novel "Our Sunshine." With Geoffrey Rush and Naomi Watts (given a rare opportunity to use their actual accents), and the teenage heartthrob Orlando Bloom; Gregor Jordan ("Buffalo Soldiers") directed.

April 2

HELLBOY -- The Gothic specialist Guillermo del Toro ("The Devil's Backbone") tackles the Dark Horse comic book created by Mike Mignola. Ron Perlman is the title character, a demon from hell conjured up by Nazi paranormal researchers near the end of World War II; with the help of a kindly scientist, John Hurt, and his psychically gifted assistant, Selma Blair, he learns to use his powers for the benefit of mankind.

April 23

MAN ON FIRE -- An embittered ex-marine, Denzel Washington, takes a job protecting the 10-year-old daughter (Dakota Fanning) of a wealthy family from kidnappers. When he fails, he sets out on a revenge mission of his own. Tony Scott ("Crimson Tide") directs; Christopher Walken and Radha Mitchell co-star.

May 7

VAN HELSING -- Universal revives its stable of movie monsters -- Dracula (Richard Roxburgh), Frankenstein's monster (Shuler Hensley) and the Wolf Man (Will Kemp) -- for a special-effects spectacular directed by Stephen Sommers (who did the recent "Mummy" remakes). Hugh Jackman takes time off from "The X-Men" to play the title character, the famous monster hunter created by Bram Stoker for his novel "Dracula," and Kate Beckinsale is his comely assistant.

May 21

SHREK 2 -- America's favorite ogre, voiced by Mike Myers, returns from his honeymoon with his new ogress mate (Cameron Diaz); further adventures ensue. Andrew Adamson, Conrad Vernon and Kelly Asbury direct the computer animation; other voices are provided by Eddie Murphy, John Lithgow, John Cleese, Julie Andrews and Antonio Banderas.

TROY -- What, was "The Iliad" too hard to spell? That pesky Helen (Diane Kruger) does it again, setting off war between Sparta and Troy when Paris (Orlando Bloom) takes her home to meet the folks. What a cast: Brad Pitt as Achilles, Eric Bana as Hector, Sean Bean as Odysseus, Peter O'Toole as Priam, Brendan Gleeson as Menelaus, and so on and on. Wolfgang Petersen directs.

June 4

HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN -- Alfonso Cuaron, who directed the excellent children's film "A Little Princess" (and the not-bad adult film "Y Tu Mama Tambien") takes over the direction of the Harry Potter films with this third entry in the series. Michael Gambon replaces Richard Harris as Professor Dumbledore and Julie Christie turns up as Madam Rosmerta; the rest of the cast (Daniel Radcliffe, Emma Watson, Rupert Grint, Robbie Coltrane) looks to be intact.

June 18

GARFIELD -- Bill Murray provides the voice of the lasagna-loving cat in this blend of computer animation and live action, directed by Peter Hewitt ("Thunderpants"). Breckin Meyer is Garfield's custodian; Jennifer Love Hewitt and Debra Messing are his co-stars.

July 2

SPIDER-MAN 2 -- The moody teenage superhero (Tobey Maguire) takes on the villainous Doctor Octopus (Alfred Molina) in the director Sam Raimi's sequel to his runaway hit of 2002. With Kirsten Dunst, Rosemary Harris and James Franco. Compiled with the assistance of SUZANNE O'CONNOR

CORRECTION-DATE: September 14, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An annotated list of films in the New Season issue last Sunday misidentified the source of "Luther," opening Sept. 26. It was made from an original screenplay based on the life of Martin Luther, not based on the play "Luther" by John Osborne.
An annotated architecture listing misidentified an architect for the Aqua residential community in Miami Beach. She is Alison Spear. (Laurinda Spear, also an architect, is her sister.)

(Photo by Jasin Boland/Universal Studios)(pg. 74); The ogre (voiced by Mike Myers) returns this spring -- from his honeymoon, no less -- in "Shrek 2."; Hugh Jackman portrays the title character in "Van Helsing." (Photo by Fran Masi/Universal Studios); Romola Garai and Diego Luna star in "Dirty Dancing Havana Nights," set in 1950's Cuba. It's a sequel to "Dirty Dancing" (1987). (Photo by Barry Wetcher)(pg. 75) Drawing (Drawing by Mark Ulriksen)(pg. 65)
