PUB-DATE: September 7, 2003
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 5895 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW SEASON/DANCE; 
Dancing Onstage, Out of Doors, Even in a Dream

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
 All dates are subject to change.

September

DANCENOW/NYC -- The intention of this sprawling series is to celebrate dance and the community, as its founders put it. But as it has grown, over nine years, Dancenow has become unpredictably fringy. It also serves as an unpretentious guide to what is happening in dance south of 14th Street. The choreography is wildly varied. The heart of the event is the "Base Camp" program, which features dance by artists including Paul Matteson and Roger C. Jeffrey (Monday), Wil Swanson and Lisa Gonzales (Friday) and Robert Battle, Ivy Baldwin, Chris Elam and the Young Dancemakers (Saturday). Monday-Saturday. Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street. (718) 850-2488. www.dancenownyc.org

EVENING STARS FESTIVAL: TWYLA THARP DANCE -- Ms. Tharp takes us back to a more innocent time in dance with her 1970 "The One Hundreds," a piece meant to be performed in part by amateur dancers, who will be drawn here from politics, literature and the visual arts. Tuesday. Battery Park, State and Pearl Streets, Lower Manhattan, (212) 219-9401. www.lmcc.net

BILL T. JONES/ARNIE ZANE DANCE COMPANY -- The troupe begins its 20th year with a retrospective at the Kitchen, where it all began, followed early next year with an engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which gave the company its first major commission. Zane, who died in 1988, was a short, stubby white man who specialized in irony. Mr. Jones, who was Zane's partner off as well as on the stage, is a tall slender black man who believes in getting to the heart of things in his dances. Short pieces created by each and both of the men in the 1970's and 80's will be shown in this first season. The larger-scale and more recent works in the academy's season sound provocative, including the premiere of "Reading, Mercy and the Artificial Nigger," drawn from a short story by Flannery O'Connor. Also on the bill are "The Phantom Project: Still/Here Looking On," which uses sections of Mr. Jones's 1994 examination of mortality as a jumping-off point for a choreographic look back and forward, and "Another Another History of Collage," the last collaboration by Zane and Mr. Jones. Tuesday-Sept. 20. The Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street. (212) 255-5793. www.thekitchen.org. Feb. 3-7. Brooklyn Academy of Music. Also Feb. 20-22. New Jersey Performing Arts Center. www.billtjones.org

DANCER'S NIGHT OUT: RENEE REDDING JONES -- This ingenious series is devoted to dances created by vibrant performers. Ms. Jones, whose credits include the companies of Ronald K. Brown, Bebe Miller and David Rousseve, will present "Nudging Toward Normal," on a program shared with Karen Graham, who has danced with David Gordon and Mikhail Baryshnikov, and Heather Kravas, currently performing with Jennifer Allen and DD Dorvillier and Peter Jacobs's Human Future Dance Corps. Wednesday-Saturday. Dance Theater Workshop.

HEADLONG DANCE THEATER -- From Philadelphia, this bright and brash young Bessie Award-winning company will take a look at MTV culture and Dante in "Britney's Inferno," a piece presumably inspired by Ms. Spears that The Philadelphia Inquirer described as having "a hellish heart." Sept. 17-20. Dance Theater Workshop.

NEW YORK DANCE AND PERFORMANCE AWARDS -- This ceremony, at which Bessie Awards are given in just about every category of dance and performance-art activity, is open to everyone, though it is fundamentally less a public event than a jubilant and sometimes poignant celebration of a community. This year promises to be extra-memorable, however, given that the hosts are Julie Atlas Muz and Jennifer Miller, rightly described by event organizers as "two of New York's most outrageous hotpots." Sept. 19. Joyce Theater.

DANCING IN THE PARKS: RENNIE HARRIS PUREMOVEMENT -- Mr. Harris and his company have successfully made a sleek yet gritty new dance form by blending traditional modern and hip-hop dance. Performances of "Students of the Asphalt Jungle," a piece derived from old and new choreography, will inaugurate an outdoor dance series in Coffey Park in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. Once a proud neighborhood of shipyards, Red Hook, despite some signs of gentrification, has not forgotten its colorful past, keeping it alive with eloquent dance by innovative choreographers like Mr. Harris, much of it presented by Dancing in the Streets. Sept. 20-21. Coffey Park, Dwight Street between Verona Street and Visitation Place, Red Hook, Brooklyn, (212) 625-3505.

MOMIX -- Moses Pendleton's dream adventure, the company called Momix, will perform its classics "Baseball," "Opus Cactus" and "Passion," whose themes are the great American pastime, the American West and its desert creatures, and love. Sept. 23-Oct. 12. Joyce Theater. Momix opens a Joyce season that runs through Aug. 21 and features performances by 37 companies and individuals, and still counting. The troupes performing this fall and spring include Garth Fagan Dance (Nov. 11-23), Maria Benitez Teatro Flamenco (Nov. 25-30); Les Ballets Jazz de Montreal (Dec. 2-7); Compagnie Marie Chouinard (Dec. 9-13); Savion Glover (Dec. 16-Jan. 4); James Sewell Ballet of Minneapolis (Jan. 20-25); Buglisi/Foreman Dance (Jan. 27-Feb. 1); Doug Varone and Dancers (Feb. 3-8); Compania Maria Pages (Feb. 24-29); Stephen Petronio Company (March 23-28); North Carolina Dance Theater (April 13-18); Philadanco (May 18-23), and BalletMet Columbus (May 25-30). Momix will also perform Jan. 25 at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, Purchase, N.Y., (914) 251-6200, and April 30-May 2 at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.

PATRICK CORBIN AND DANCERS -- Mr. Corbin is a quietly powerful and intelligent dancer, a longtime member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company. Can he choreograph as well as he performs? He will present dances set to Bach, Part, Dvorakand the German composer Marsha Groethe with a group that includes the fellow Taylorites Michael Trusnovec and Julie Tice. Sept. 25-28. Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church.

'MOTION STUDIES' -- You may have to be a rocket scientist to understand how the new technologically inspired dance forms work, but it is possible simply to sit back and revel in the mystery of it all. This series of talks and exhibitions of drawings, sculpture, video and 3D animation projections begins with the kamikaze choreographer Elizabeth Streb (Sept. 29) and continues with programs on Twyla Tharp (Oct. 8) and on street performance, new media and public display (Nov. 12), ending with a program on electronically augmented space (Nov. 25). Participants include Ms. Streb, the dancer Sara Rudner, the anthropologist Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett and the digital artists Marek Walczak, Shelley Eshkar and Paul Kaiser. Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, 1 Wall Street Court, (212) 219-9401. www.lmcc.net

NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL: BALLETT FRANKFURT -- William Forsythe has made a name for himself as a dance iconoclast in the two decades he directed this German ballet company. The trickster titles are heartsinking, but the themes and styles of the four dances he will present here, which range from 1996 to last year, may suggest why. The breathing of eight dancers governs the rhythms of "The Room as It Was." Two women move in intricate and spiraling patterns in a small space at the front of the curtain in "Duo" and four men move through close physical counterpoint in "(N.N.N.N.)" Quick shifting tables form the set and dance floor in "One Flat Thing, reproduced." Sept. 30-Oct. 5. Brooklyn Academy of Music. A related article is on Page 15.

October

TERE O'CONNOR DANCE -- Is he the real turtle soup or only the mock? You either love Mr. O'Connor's enigmatic pieces or you don't. In this one, called "Lawn," environmental issues and the poetics of dance are said to meet head on. "Lawn" is a collaboration with the filmmaker Ben Speth, with whom the choreographer says he has shared a dialogue for years, and the composer James Baker, whose score is described as comprising electronically disfigured natural sounds. Oct. 1-4, 8-11 and 15-18. Dance Theater Workshop.

CARLOTTA SAGNA -- It's a sure thing that "A," the mysterious title of Ms. Sagna's piece, has nothing to do with badges of dishonor. Advance word is that Ms. Sagna, who choreographed two shows by the enterprising Belgian Needcompany, is probably addressing the downside of performing, like stage fright and post-euphoria confusion. Oct. 1-4. The Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, (212) 255-5793. www.thekitchen.org

WENDY ROGERS -- Ms. Rogers, who is known for subtle, intelligent modern-dance choreography, will investigate the shifting, merging boundaries of urban life and wilderness in her new "movement refuge," which will be performed by a group that includes Monica Bill Barnes and Allyson Green. Her program begins the fall season, which runs through Dec. 21, at Danspace Project. Oct. 2-5. Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church.

METROPOLITAN OPERA -- The company's Stravinsky program is back, featuring choreography by Frederick Ashton for "Rossignol" and by Doug Varone for "Le Sacre du Printemps." Opens Oct. 4. Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, 212 362-6000. www.metopera.org

PENNSYLVANIA BALLET -- This Balanchine centennial year is as good a time as any to acknowledge George Balanchine's help in building a stable foundation for American ballet. Not only did he create the New York City Ballet but he encouraged grants to select companies outside New York, among them this unassumingly vibrant troupe. The season, which continues through June, includes Ben Stevenson's "Dracula" and Christopher Wheelson's eagerly awaited production of "Swan Lake." Pennsylvania will also celebrate Balanchine with performances of "The Four Temperaments" and "Concerto Barocco." Also on the bill is the company premiere of Jerome Robbins's "Fancy Free." Oct. 8-12. Merriam Theater, University of the Arts, Philadelphia, (215) 336-2000. www.paballet.org

THE SUZANNE FARRELL BALLET -- Ms. Farrell selects dancers and dances as if she were choosing different kinds of caviar. The ensemble, sponsored by the Kennedy Center, will perform in several New York-area theaters before returning to its home theater in Washington, where it will present two programs in December. One program will consist of ballet set to Tchaikovsky as part of the theater's Tchaikovsky Festival. In the other, the company will explore the notion of the pas de deux couple, which Ms. Farrell believes is at the heart of Balanchine ballets. Oct. 11. New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Oct. 12. Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues, Brooklyn. (718) 951-4500. www.brooklyncenter.com

NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL: MERCE CUNNINGHAM DANCE COMPANY -- Merce rocks! This time, to scores by Radiohead and Sigur Ros in his new "Split Sides," a choice of music that seems, mysteriously, to be stirring the henhouse even more than the reliably provocative John Cage. The decor is by Catherine Yass, the British photographer, and Robert Heishman, a high school student and photographer in Kansas whom Mr. Cunningham met on tour. Also on the bill, in this program celebrating the Cunningham company's 50th anniversary, is the New York premiere of "Fluid Canvas," with a score by John King and decor by Marc Downie along with the digital design team of Shelley Eshkar and Paul Kaiser, Mr. Cunningham's collaborators on the exquisitely beautiful "Biped." Oct. 14-18. Brooklyn Academy of Music.

AKRAM KHAN -- The brainy young Mr. Khan is a leading member of England's new modern-dance generation and a leading practitioner of the fusion of contemporary Western and classical Indian movement. His new "Kaash," which is Hindu for "if," draws on the Kathak style in dance inspired by Hindu gods, black holes, Indian time cycles, tablas and themes of creation and destruction. Oct. 14-19. Joyce Theater. The British mini-invasion, which provides a welcome chance to savor the healthy and individualistic modern-dance culture of that country, continues with performances by George Piper Dances troupe, founded only two years ago by the former Royal Ballet principal dancers William Trevitt and Michael Nunn. It is already equipped with a repertory that includes work by established choreographers like Russell Maliphant, William Forsythe and Christopher Wheeldon. Nov. 4-9. Another English choreographer, Richard Alston, will follow with his company in mid-May. Joyce Theater.

BOSTON BALLET -- The company, another beneficiary of Balanchine's early concern, begins its year in mid-month with two showings of Rudolf Nureyev's exuberant production of "Don Quixote" with a mixed bill of dances by George Balanchine and the English choreographer David Dawson sandwiched between. The season continues, through mid-May, with programs of dance by choreographers including Val Caniparoli and Mark Morris, performed by dancers who include the exquisite Cuban ballerina Lorna Feijoo, a new Boston principal dancer. Oct. 16-Nov. 2. Wang Theater, 270 Tremont Street, Boston. (800) 447-7400. www.bostonballet.com

BALLET NACIONAL DE CUBA -- These irresistible, beautifully schooled dancers suggest that the sometimes remote-seeming art of classical ballet is a fundamentally human activity. Under the direction of Alicia Alonso, they will present the full-evening "Don Quixote" and a program of romantic repertory, including Antonio Gades's "Blood Wedding," Ms. Alonso's staging of "Les Sylphides" and Azari Plisetski's "Canto Vital." Oct. 15-19. City Center.

RONALD K. BROWN/EVIDENCE -- Mr. Brown has become one of the most powerful choreographic voices of his generation. He has fused African and Western modern dance and come up with an influential style that is all heart, grace, skill and passion. His new "Come Ye" will celebrate the life and voice of Nina Simone. And how the years pass. Once a shiny-eyed youngster himself, Mr. Brown is now an avuncular role model who will present work from the company's repertory project by four fledgling choreographers, Lamine Thiam, Maria Basse Willes, Wilhemina Taylor and Richard Gonzales. Oct. 21-26. Joyce Theater.

NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL: SUSAN MARSHALL & COMPANY -- Ms. Marshall is probably best known for her acute, deft evocations of complex buried emotions in dances that suggest rather than tell a story. There's no getting around the tale abstracted in her "Sleeping Beauty," which will take place in a mazelike set, but this new work definitely won't look Disneyesque. Also on the bill is "Other Stories," a piece in which fragments of intimate dance are intercut to suggest what Ms. Marshall describes as the chaos of life and the communicative power of movement. Oct. 21-25. BAM Harvey Theater.

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER -- The company's fall season in New York will have the requisite marquee attractions, among them premieres of one sort or another of ballets by William Forsythe, Robert Hill, Jiri Kylian and Christian Spuck. I'll take the revivals, however, chief among them Frederick Ashton's luminous "Symphonic Variations" but also Antony Tudor's "Pillar of Fire" and Agnes de Mille's goofy "Three Virgins and a Devil." Another bit of repertory will be an excerpt from a new full-evening production of "Raymonda," created by Anna-Marie Holmes and the company director Kevin McKenzie, that will be the centerpiece of Ballet Theater's summer season. Oct. 22-Nov. 9. City Center. May 10-July 3. Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center. (212) 362-6000. The company will also present a full-evening "Bayadere" and a mixed-repertory program in Washington. Feb. 3-8. Kennedy Center. www.abt.org

REGGIE WILSON/FIST AND HEEL PERFORMANCE GROUP -- Mr. Wilson named his company after a term for the music American slaves accompanied themselves with as they continued to dance after drums were denied them. Mr. Wilson's choreographic explorations of the culture of his forebears, and the haunting traditional song-chants he chooses as accompaniment, have the raw power of that earlier artistic invention, as well as a covert tenderness. In the ambitious new "Black Burlesque (Revisited)," produced by Dance Theater Workshop and 651 Arts, Mr. Wilson collaborates with the Black Umfolosi a cappella singing group from Zimbabwe and the Noble Douglas Dance company of Trinidad. Oct. 22-Nov. 1. Dance Theater Workshop.

ARTHUR AVILES'S TYPICAL THEATER -- Mr. Aviles, a born -- and funky -- dance storyteller, will present two new works and excerpts from his "History Dances" project, a series of pieces drawn from the lives of lesbians, gay men and bisexuals living in Mr. Aviles's home neighborhood of the Bronx. Oct. 24. BAAD! (The Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance), 841 Barretto Street, Hunts Point, Bronx. (718) 842-5223. www.bronxacademyofartsanddance.org. "History Dances" will be seen in full on Nov. 24. Dance Theater Workshop.

CAREER TRANSITION FOR DANCERS -- This slinkiest and most jubilant of galas, this year called "Gotta Dance!: A Dance Tribute to Hollywood," will feature Alina Cojocaru and Johan Kobberg of England's Royal Ballet and dancers from many American ballet and modern-dance troupes including, delightfully, the all-male Ballets Grandiva. There will also be hosts and performers from the golden years of the Hollywood musical, among them Cyd Charisse, Donald O'Connor, Fayard Nicholas, Jane Powell and Esther Williams as well as the ineffably elegant Donald Saddler of Broadway fame, without whom no gala is quite gala enough. Oct. 27. City Center.

November

NOCHE FLAMENCA -- You don't see much dance at the Lucille Lortel, but the theater should be the perfect intimate setting for this company and its star dancer, Soledad Barrio, whose building passion each night is uncontainable anyway. Nov. 1-30. Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street. (212) 239-6200.

ANNA SOKOLOW'S PLAYERS PROJECT -- Sokolow may have died, in 2000, but she has not been forgotten. Works by this famously cranky humanist will be performed by her company, along with a new work by David Parker, as part of the 92nd Street Y's "Sundays @ Three" series. Nov. 2. 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue. (212) 415-5500. www.92y.org

KARI HOAAS -- From Norway, Ms. Hoaas addresses the myths of a consumerist utopia and the longing for heroes. Sounds timely. Nov. 6-9. Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. (212) 477-5200. www.ps122.org

DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP: SPLITSTREAM -- More and more seasoned choreographers are turning to series devoted to the work of relative newcomers, as the expense of putting on a show gets further out of reach in a poor economy. That is the case with the SplitStream series this year. Nia Love, who is known for the intelligence, emotional energy and humor of her dances, will share the first of two programs with Ori Flomin and Osmany Tellez. Nov. 6-8. Next comes Pat Cremins, who creates mysterious microcosms out of anything from a tilted body to an animal skull, and then turns them upside down. She will be joined by Nichole Canuso and Yanira Castro. Nov. 13-15. Dance Theater Workshop.

MARTHA GRAHAM DANCE COMPANY -- The company's hectic national and international touring schedule, pending the outcome of legal action brought against the troupe by Ron Protas, its former director, includes two New York area engagements. The first, at Purchase College, will include performances of "Satyric Festival Song," "Deep Song," "Maple Leaf Rag," "Embattled Garden" and Graham's stunningly simple, cinematic "Chronicle." Nov. 7. The Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, Purchase, N.Y. (914) 251-6200. The company will perform in New York City in late April in "Chronicle," "El Penitente," "Errand into the Maze" and revivals of the erotic "Circe" and the playful "Owl and the Pussycat." April 20-25. City Center. www.marthagrahamdance.org

MARJORIE GAMSO -- This cheerfully unpredictable dance and video artist has been marching to her own experimentalist drumbeat for several decades. Now she's back at Construction Company, an intimate free-ranging theater and exhibition space that tends to serve as a home for the uncategorizable (Nov. 9). The fall season continues with programs by Barbara Mahler (Nov. 16-17), Sally Silvers (Nov. 23) and Ariane Anthony and Jeffrey Bauer (Dec. 6-8). Construction Company, 10 East 18th Street. (212) 924-7882.

'CAPTURED: A VIDEODANCE SERIES' -- Up to now, the Dance on Camera festival at Lincoln Center each January has been it as far as dance film series go in New York City. Now Dance Theater Workshop is making the most of its new high-tech video equipment with screenings of experimental dance videos, part of an informative-sounding series of discussions and informal showings at the workshop called "Beyond the Main Stage." Nov. 10 and Dec. 1.

KRASNOYARSK NATIONAL DANCE COMPANY OF SIBERIA -- Krasnoyarsk, one of the leading practitioners of Russian folk dance and music, fills the stage with kaleidoscopic colors and patterns in acrobatic dance with ballet underpinnings. Nov. 15. Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Bedford Park Boulevard West and Goulden Avenue, Bronx. (718) 960-8833.

MARK MORRIS DANCE GROUP -- One of the most celebrated choreographers of his time, Mr. Morris is a rumpled individualist whose dances have his gutsy, why-not energy and color. The work of an artist who clearly loves music, the pieces are set to unusual scores that are always performed live. Nov. 29-30. New Jersey Performing Arts Center. www.mmdg.org

BALLET HISPANICO -- The company founder Tina Ramirez and her dancers celebrate things Latin, including the tango and ballroom and club-dance forms, with the sleek cool of classical ballet. The company inaugurates the 900-seat Skirball Center at New York University with this season. Nov. 11-16. Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, La Guardia Place at Washington Square South, (212) 992-8484. Also March 5-7. New Jersey Performing Arts Center.

NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL: ANNE TERESA DE KEERSMAEKER -- Every season should have an engagement by Ms. de Keersmaeker and her Brussels-based Rosas troupe, which keeps the blood flowing speedily to the brain, aesthetically speaking. The company will perform her "Rain," created in 2001 and inspired by the novel of the same name, written by the New Zealander Kirsty Gunn, which tells the story of a child's drowning. Seventy minutes of uninterrupted motion, "Rain" is set to music by Steve Reich, Ms. de Keersmaeker's frequent choice of composer, and has been described by an English reviewer as looking like "wind streaking the surface of water." Nov. 12-15. Brooklyn Academy of Music.

DANCE CUBA -- Most dancegoers think Alicia Alonso when they hear the term "Cuban dance," but this all-female company is celebrated in Cuba for its fiery mix of flamenco, ballet and Afro-Cuban music, in choreography by the company director, Lizt Alfonso. Nov. 14-30. New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street. (212) 239-6200. www.newvictory.org

NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL: CLOUD GATE THEATER OF TAIWAN -- Lin Hwai-min, the company's choreographer and director, specializes in large-scale evocative spectacle of a sort seldom seen in today's modern dance. His "Moon Water," inspired by a Buddhist proverb about the elusive nature of reflected images of flowers and the moon, eventually sprawls out across a stage described as looking like a vast liquid mirror, inhabited by drenched dancers in billowing costumes. Nov. 18-22. Brooklyn Academy of Music.

ELISA MONTE DANCE -- Ms. Monte is known for dance that assumes the sexual component of being a woman. Her new "Shekhina," inspired by the erotic photographs of Leonard Nimoy -- yes, that one -- will be the centerpiece of her company's New York winter season, which will also include performances of "Light Lies," Ms. Monte's recent homage to the painter Josef Albers, and her classic "Treading." Nov. 19-22. Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, La Guardia Place at Washington Square South. (212) 992-8484.

'BALANCHINE 100: THE CENTENNIAL CELEBRATION AT NEW YORK CITY BALLET' -- This ambitious festival will take place at the New York State Theater, City Ballet's home at Lincoln Center, and arenas around the city, through the spring. The company has sorted the Balanchine oeuvre -- some 81 dances -- still in repertory into two segments. Ballets performed during "Balanchine's Heritage," which occurs during the latter part of the winter season, will suggest the artists, eras and places that influenced the choreographer, among them Petipa, Diaghilev, Bournonville and Broadway. The winter season opens with a gala on Nov. 25, then moves into Balanchine's standard-setting production of "The Nutcracker," a ballet in which he danced as a young student at the Maryinsky Theater. Nov. 28-Jan. 4. The balance of the winter season will consist of "Heritage' programming. It includes an evening-long commissioned work by Susan Stroman in honor of Balanchine's musical-theater choreography and early and mid-period Balanchine ballets. The company will also perform the company director Peter Martins's productions of "Swan Lake" and "The Sleeping Beauty." The City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet students will dance Michel Fokine's "Chopiniana." The repertory will also include August Bournonville's "Flower Festival in Genzano" as well as works by Balanchine that were influenced by Bournonville ballets. Jan. 6-Feb. 29. The second segment, "Vision," will include new works by Christopher Wheeldon, Boris Eifman and Mr. Martins, and 42 ballets by Balanchine. The repertory will be performed in three mini-festivals centering around music by European, American and Russian composers. April 27-June 27. (212) 870-5570. www.nycballet.com. Balanchine's work processes and early archival history will be probed in events next year in New York City at the Guggenheim Museum, the Museum of Television and Radio, the New York Public Library, Symphony Space, the Manhattan School of Music and a city park, as well as on the PBS "American Masters" television series. There will also be events at Harvard University and the San Francisco Performing Arts Library, and at least 20 American ballet companies will present tribute performances. www.balanchine.org

DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM -- Michael Smuin's sumptuous "St. Louis Woman: A Blues Ballet" sweeps over the eye and mind like a wash of warm and brilliant color, sweet and sad as the blues. Nov. 29-30. New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Also Dec. 14. Tilles Center for the Performing Arts, C.W. Post Campus, Brookville, N.Y. (516) 299-3100. www.tillescenter.org. June 8-13. Kennedy Center. www.dancetheatreofharlem.com

December

ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER -- These wonderfully warm, do-or-die performers could probably get away with dancing the Staten Island telephone directory. Instead, they will perform in premieres by Robert Battle, Alonzo King, Jennifer Muller and Dwight Rhoden and in new productions of "Hymn," Judith Jamison's poignant evocation of Ailey himself, and the Donald McKayle classic "Rainbow 'Round My Shoulder," as well as a host of Ailey dances. Dec. 3-Jan. 4. City Center. Also May 5-7. New Jersey Performing Arts Center. www.alvinailey.org

CENTRAL STATION AT DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP -- This festival, created by the workshop but taking place at three downtown dance theaters, celebrates the work of choreographers from Eastern and Central Europe and the strength of modern dance there. The series begins with dances by Cosmin Manolescu of Romania, Galina Borissova of Bulgaria and Marta Ladjanszki of Hungary. Dec. 3-6. Next comes Sasha Pepelyaev, from Estonia, and Peeter Jalakas, from Russia, with a deconstructed "Swan Lake" performed by the Von Krahl Theater. Dec. 10-13. Dance Theater Workshop.

CENTRAL STATION AT PERFORMANCE SPACE 122 -- The philosophers of Croatian modern dance, the BADco troupe will present "Solo Me," a "solo" for two people that explores individuality and duality. Dec. 4-7. Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. (212) 477-5200. www.ps122.org

CENTRAL STATION AT DANSPACE PROJECT -- Ioana Popovici, from Romania, begins the final segment of the festival with "Requiem for a Dog." Dec. 12-14. United Dancers of ZUGA, an Estonian modern-dance company, complete the festival offerings with choreography by Kaja Kann, Jarmo Karing and Tiina Molder. Dec. 19-21. Danspace Project at St. Marks Church.

NEXT WAVE PROJECT: DAYTON CONTEMPORARY DANCE COMPANY -- "The Flight Project," a suite of dances commissioned by this Ohio-based company to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Wright Brothers' first flight, sounds like a marketer's dream. That intelligence may be what has driven him over the last decade to collaborate with choreographers and dancers with decidedly different aesthetics, most often Molissa Fenley. Mr. Boal is back to ballet but with his own chamber company, consisting of Wendy Whelan and Sean Suozzi, also of City Ballet. The repertory includes works by Twyla Tharp and Marco Goecke. HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
45 Rentals Planned for Neglected Area in Norwich

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

DATELINE: NORWICH 

 BODY:
ON a historic hilltop overlooking this city's downtown and its harbor, two old and neglected houses are getting a makeover and some new neighbors. A local developer has won city approval for a $6 million project on Jail Hill that will create 45 new apartments in seven buildings off Cedar Street.
 Much of the land consists of ledges or is overgrown and was divided into parcels that were too small to interest most developers. But over the last year, Darwin C. Gebbie, owner of P&D Enterprises in neighboring Lebanon, which specializes in renovations and rental property development, has assembled almost four acres in six different purchases, including some sites that were in foreclosure. He now controls most of the hilltop, which towers 210 feet above the Thames River. 
 He plans to construct Harbor View Estates, five new three-story brownstones with a total of 40 two-bedroom units, and renovate two existing historic houses into a mix of one- and two-bedroom apartments. 
Mr. Gebbie's plans have won accolades from a number of city officials. The city planner, William R. Sweeney, noted that among the many housing projects proposed in recent months, most have been on "greenfields," virgin land on the city's fringes.
"Jail Hill is a part of town that's seen better days," Mr. Sweeney said. "To see this kind of reinvestment into this neighborhood is a real positive sign. This is going to give us some really high quality apartments immediately adjacent to downtown. He put something together that a lot of developers wouldn't have taken the time to do."
Mr. Sweeney said he was particularly pleased that Mr. Gebbie agreed to restore one of the houses on the property, the Rev. Seth Paddock house, named for the 19th-century preacher who once lived there. It is believed to be the first house on Jail Hill, an area named for the jail established there in 1830, when it was a mostly vacant section of town. The second house to be restored is known as the Cook house. The entire neighborhood is a National Historical District because of old houses there.
"He originally looked at tearing the Paddock house down to make room for development, but when he found out through the state Historical Commission that it had some real historic value, he immediately changed his plan and integrated it into his development," Mr. Sweeney said.
Another official, Peter W. Davis, director of planning and neighborhood services in Norwich, said, "It was nice to have a developer come to the city and show so much respect for its historical resources." 
Mr. Davis said the architecture of the neighborhood is a mix of Federal style, a few Greek Revivals and Colonials and some 1970's houses.
U SING new building materials can't replicate the buildings that are there exactly," Mr. Davis said. "But he was sensitive to the style of housing in the neighborhood and tried to honor the character of the neighborhood."
Mr. Gebbie said that renovating the historic buildings would be more costly than razing them and building anew, but the old buildings make the project distinctive. One building had to be jacked up so the sills could be replaced, for instance, but he was also able to salvage six of the eight original fireplaces.
"I've saved a lot of historic buildings," Mr. Gebbie said. "This is what I enjoy doing." In more than 30 years in the real estate business, he has built a strong local reputation for preservation, renovating the Fitchville Inn and Peterson House in Bozrah, some mill houses in the Baltic section of Sprague and some early 19th-century residences in Jewett City.
"It's always the easy answer to knock it down and start over," Mr. Gebbie said. "Anybody can build a new house, but it takes a different kind of person to save an old house."
Mr. Gebbie said it took about 15 months to lay the groundwork for the Jail Hill project.
"In May of last year, my Realtor called me and said, 'Darwin, I have a project you're going to want to take a look at,' " Mr. Gebbie said. "So we went up there and we were there for an hour, taking in the view of the water and the city, before the first car went by. It's a beautiful site, no traffic, and I asked her, 'How could anyone not have seen this before -- the potential that this project has?' "
The broker was Denise C. Robillard, president of Continental Realty in Jewett City, who has worked with Mr. Gebbie several times over the years. "He does a lot of restoration work, and I knew right away this was a Darwin Gebbie project," Ms. Robillard said. "I knew he could do it, he could handle it and he could make it something nice that would lift up that whole section of Norwich. He's always looking for ways to improve an area."
At his behest, she began negotiating with abutting property owners.
"When we started to look at how many properties we could put together, then we really started to see the potential of what could happen up there," Ms. Robillard said. 
Mr. Gebbie said one of the properties had a house that had been on the city's list of blighted properties, which he acquired through a foreclosure.
"I had to pay more for it than it was worth, but if that building had remained and continued to be an eyesore, it would have devalued my property and the buildings I was putting in," Mr. Gebbie said. Similarly, one of the parcels will serve little purpose other than guaranteeing the views for his tenants for years to come, but it was important for the overall aesthetic effect.
"With all of these parcels together it's going to be a beautiful, charming site," Mr. Gebbie said.
Mr. Sweeney, the city planner, said: "I like this project, personally, because of the mix that it represents. It's not only new construction and historic renovation. You can also make the argument that it's about combating urban blight. It's a real unique mix of economic development in a very historic neighborhood."
Mr. Gebbie said he expected to set the rents at $1,000 to $1,100 a month, fairly typical rents in the current market.
Mr. Gebbie already owns more than 100 units of rental housing in towns in the Norwich area. He said as recently as the 1990's the housing market might not have supported this project -- a few years ago, he was lucky to maintain current rents when a tenant moved out, even though his own costs for taxes and insurance and maintenance were increasing. 
But the housing market tightened considerably with the economic impact of Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun, two thriving casinos within a 10-minute drive of the downtown.
"You can place an ad in the paper now for just two days and you get so many calls you can never get back to everybody," Mr. Gebbie said. "It's not unusual to get 50 or 60 calls, the demand is so high."

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; 
House and Garden, and Offices With a Penthouse

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
 230 East 50th Street

Q -- For many years, I have walked past a very unusual and attractive prewar apartment building on 50th Street in Midtown, and I am curious if you can provide some history or other information on this structure. The address is 230 East 50th Street. . . . Russell Raman, Manhattan.

A -- Colton Hall was built in 1927 by the developer Keitt P. Walker, who did several other buildings, like 1088 Park Avenue, with its unusual courtyard garden.
 For Colton Hall, the architects Leonard Cox and Arthur C. Holden developed a simple facade of subdued modernism, dominated by the steel casement windows, especially the oversized ones marking double-height spaces in the duplex units.
Consonant with Walker's other developments, the architects for Colton Hall made a particular effort with the rear garden, which was flagged and planted and given a fountain, unusual for a New York apartment building, where the rear yards are usually treated as a desert of concrete and garbage pens. 
Walker's organization, the Garden Plan Company, also built 333 East 57th Street, 350 East 57th Street and 325 East 72nd Street around this time.
All were co-ops, like Colton Hall, and most were built with very shallow lot coverage, slightly more than 50 percent, instead of the usual 75 percent or so, allowing a comparative flood of light and air. 
In 1928, Marcia Zimbalist, in her Penthouse column in The New Yorker, praised the garden on the roof, where "you and your friends can take tea and the air on one half of the roof while your children behave as noisily as you have trained them to on their particular half." 
Duplexes had "a glorious living room, two stories high, with a gallery and the most intriguing flight of toy stairs you can imagine," she said. The prices for the duplexes ran from $25,000 to $29,000, she said, but they were also for rent at around $450 a month. 
An early tenant list shows mostly Midtown businessmen and businesswomen, like Sarah Field Splint. Over her career in publishing, Splint was editor or assistant editor of The Delineator, Today's Housewife, McCall's and Women's Home Companion and wrote at least one cookbook. 
Talbot Hamlin, writing in the magazine Pencil Points in 1939, thought that Colton Hall was "indecisive in its choice of whether to be a conventional colonial or a frankly revolutionary and modern building" but praised the "imaginative planning for economy, beauty and convenience." Although more than 10 years old, the building's unusual solutions "still deserve study," Hamlin said, especially for the shallow lot coverage, which provided cross-ventilation and much better light than in the typical building. 

729 Seventh Avenue

Q -- An article from Pioneer Western Lumberman of 1917 describes an "aerial bungalow built for a theater couple on top of the Godfrey Building." Where is the Godfrey Building, and how common was such an arrangement? . . . R. Price Jepsen, architect, Manhattan.

A -- The Godfrey Building was put up in 1916 for the film industry, and still stands at 729 Seventh Avenue, on the southeast corner of 49th Street.
Some penthouse apartments on commercial buildings existed in the 19th century, like one on top of the 1898 Bowling Green Building at 5-11 Broadway. But that one was for a resident superintendent, as were most other known examples. 
In 1912, Dr. Thomas Addis Emmet developed a similar project by demolishing his old row house and others on the lot at the southeast corner of 29th Street and Madison Avenue and building a 16-story commercial building. He reserved a penthouse on the top floor, which he occupied until his death in 1920. But such residential units were quite rare. 
The 49th and Seventh site was owned by the Godfrey family, which leased it to the developer George Backer, who built the Heckscher/Crown building at 57th Street and Fifth Avenue a few years later. 
Backer retained Arthur Loomis Harmon, a sensitive designer who especially appreciated the picturesque possibilities of variegated brickwork. Harmon gave his 16-story building a medieval cast, with a projecting top-floor balcony like those seen on castles for defense, and small crosses of projecting brick on the facade, enhancing the fortified aspect. 
In 1916, the magazine Brickbuilder called the Godfrey Building "an extraordinary piece of architecture" and "something of great originality.' 
The New York Times reported that the new Godfrey Building was organized exclusively for motion picture companies, with special film vaults and a screening room. A photograph published in 1919 in American Architect shows delicate storefronts in copper or perhaps ironwork, and the signs of film industry tenants in the upper floors.
Periodical articles do not refer to any top-floor residential unit, but in 1916 Backer filed an alteration application to add a penthouse.
The article in Pioneer Western Lumberman, "A Bungalow in the Clouds," mentions the rooftop apartment as built for "a newly wedded pair whose affiliations are theatrical and who are blending at this altitude stage stares and celestial stars." 
One of the earliest tenants in the Godfrey Building was the Pickford Film Company, founded by Mary Pickford; she later founded United Artists with Douglas Fairbanks, Charlie Chaplin and others.
By 1916, Pickford was deep in a love affair with Fairbanks and, according to Eileen Whitfield's "Pickford: The Woman Who Made Hollywood" (University Press of Kentucky, 1997), she signed a new contract with Adolph Zukor that included a "private studio in New York." 
But if the 1917 article is accurate in describing the two as "newly wedded," then the star couple cannot have been the penthouse's tenants -- they were married in 1920. 
Leslie Himmel, who owns the property with Stephen Meringoff, says that the 2,000-square-foot penthouse still survives as offices but has no remarkable features. "It has great light, but otherwise it's just plain vanilla," she says.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The apartment building at 230 East 50th Street in 1939, above, and today (inset). (Photo by Library of Congress); (Photo by Jennifer S. Altman for The New York Times); The Godfrey Building, at Seventh Avenue and 49th Street, in 1919. It was built for film company offices, with an "aerial bungalow built for a theater couple on top." (Photo by Library of Congress)

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Converting Rental Buildings

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
WHILE the number of rental buildings being converted to co-ops or condominiums is nowhere near the level of the 1970's and 80's, conversions still occur and navigating the twists and turns of the process can be stressful, confusing and frustrating. Only 14 conversions took place in the years 2000, 2001 and 2002, involving about 600 apartments, but condominium lawyers say they are noticing an increase in the filings this year.
 "Regardless of whether you have any interest in purchasing your apartment and regardless of your status as rent-regulated or free-market tenant, you should be very concerned whenever the building you are in is being converted," said Stuart M. Saft, a Manhattan lawyer who is chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums. 
 Mr. Saft noted that while state law protects existing tenants in most conversions, the protections do not apply to all tenants equally, or they apply to a greater or lesser degree depending on the type of conversion. 
Moreover, he said, since the interests of tenants who will be purchasing their apartments may not be the same as those of residents who intend to remain as rental tenants, it is important for individuals in both groups to have professional guidance.
At the same time, however, since all tenants in a building have a common interest at the early stages of the conversion -- basically, to negotiate the best terms possible -- -- it is usually advisable for residents to form a tenants' committee.
"Membership in the tenants' committee is for everyone," Mr. Saft said, "regardless of whether you wish to stay on as a rental tenant or if you wish to buy or if you think you may want to sell your rights to buy at some future time." 
Mr. Saft said the first step in the conversion process in New York is the filing of the preliminary offering plan (commonly known as a "red herring" because of the red printing on the cover) with the office of the state attorney general. The office then has four to six months to issue initial comments on the red herring; after that, the sponsor will submit a revised plan. "The tenants are not a party to the review process," Mr. Saft said, adding that the entire review can take about one year.
Once the attorney general's office has determined that the plan contains "full disclosure" of the conversion, it will accept the plan for filing. Once the plan is accepted for filing, the tenants receive a final offering plan (or a "black book" because of the absence of red ink on the cover). 
Mr. Saft emphasized that under the law, the acceptance by the attorney general's office of a plan for filing does not mean the plan is fair or even economically viable. "It must only contain a full disclosure of the terms of the plan and the condition of the building," he said. In fact, Mr. Saft said, neither the attorney general's office nor any other governmental agency "approves" an offering plan or insures that the plan is fair or equitable or that the prices the sponsor is asking for apartments in the building have any relationship to the actual fair market value of those apartments. 
"Each tenant has the exclusive right to agree to purchase the apartment in which he resides for 90 days after the black book is presented," Mr. Saft said. 
Most conversions in New York, Mr. Saft said, are what are known as "noneviction plan conversions." Basically, this means that in exchange for agreeing to allow existing tenants to remain in occupancy -- and enjoy the protections of the rent laws -- the sponsor can begin selling apartments (or "declare the plan effective") when he or she has obtained agreements to sell at least 15 percent of the residential units in the building to tenants in occupancy or to outside purchasers who intend to reside in units they have purchased -- usually people who are buying vacant apartments. By law sponsors are allowed to keep up to 10 percent of the units vacant for sale to outsiders.
"If the sponsor is unable to declare the plan effective within 15 months, the plan is deemed abandoned," Mr. Saft said.
(The "eviction plan" conversion, which requires agreement from 51 percent of apartments and allows eviction of those who do not purchase, is rarely used.)
Arthur I. Weinstein, another Manhattan lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, said that since the sponsor needs agreements to sell at least 15 percent of the apartments in a building to be able to declare the plan effective and schedule closings, the tenants in the building -- including prospective purchasers and renters alike -- have leverage to negotiate with the sponsor for the best terms possible. 
Mr. Weinstein said it is at this point in time, after the plan has been accepted for filing, that tenants and future apartment owners can negotiate with the sponsor to amend the final offering plan to ensure, for example, that enough money is placed in the building's reserve fund -- an account for future repairs and improvements. It is also possible for tenants who intend to buy their units to negotiate a better price with the sponsor. 
Mr. Weinstein said those tenants who decide not to buy their apartments generally have the right to remain in their apartment as long as they continue to pay rent and abide by the terms of their lease.
Rent-stabilized and rent-controlled tenants, he said, are entitled to continue their tenancy on the same terms and conditions they enjoy under their current tenancy and are then entitled to a renewal lease at the end of each lease term, with rent increases as permitted by law. Such tenants are also entitled to the same "succession rights" as other rent-regulated tenants, meaning that the right to remain in the apartment as a tenant can be passed along to spouses and, in some cases, children, other family members and domestic partners. 
The rights of tenants who are nonregulated "market rate tenants" at the time of the conversion, are slightly different. Mr. Weinstein explained that while such tenants may not be evicted unless they violate the terms of their lease, they can be required to pay market rate rents when their current lease expires.
Mr. Saft, who along with Mr. Weinstein conducts seminars for tenants in buildings undergoing conversions, noted that regardless of whether a tenant plans to buy his or her unit or remain in the building as a rental tenant, he or she should be cognizant about the physical condition of the building. 
"The sponsor or future unit owners can decide to do renovations to the building, such as installing new elevators or new windows," he said, adding that such improvements could result in "major capital improvement" rent increases for nonpurchasing tenants, as well as increased maintenance charges for apartment owners. 
In addition, he said, once the plan is declared effective, the apartments of renters who remain can still be sold by the sponsor, subject, of course, to the right of the tenant to remain in the unit. And while that will be a risky proposition for the buyer, who has to wait for the tenant to vacate the apartment, it can also be a major inconvenience for tenants. "This means people coming into your apartment, looking around, examining the premises and upsetting your daily life."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Long Island; 
Upscale Shopping Centers Without Usual Anchors

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE

 BODY:
DISPENSING with their traditional anchors, two longtime shopping centers in wealthy areas of Nassau County are finding room for more high-end stores by subdividing space that had formerly been occupied by supermarkets. 
 While traditional shopping centers depend on anchor stores to bring in customers, upscale centers like the Americana Manhasset and Woodbury Village do not, retailing experts say. 
 "Does Rodeo Drive need a supermarket?" asked Alvin J. Rosenstein, a marketing and business professor at Adelphi University in Garden City. "In effect, these upscale centers are upscale department stores with an upscale selection." Dr. Rosenstein is a consumer psychologist and a retail consultant whose clients have included J. C. Penney, General Foods and the New York Stock Exchange. 
"Shoppers want convenience and if they want upscale convenience, it's a waste of time putting in something that is not upscale," he said.
"There's a synergy here" for shopping center managers, he added. "The more upscale brands they bring in, the better positioning they acquire as an ultimate resource for the upscale shopper seeking a broad selection of prestigious brands."
Marshall Felenstein, president of the retail consulting firm Felenstein, Was & Associates in Manhattan, said, "While the Woodbury center is not as unique as Americana, which is so upscale that in order to compete you'd have to come to Manhattan, I think both shopping centers will be very successful because they are enhancing their critical mass for their day-to-day customers."
In Manhasset the 47-year-old Americana shopping center has redivided a 40,000-square-foot space that had included a Waldbaum's supermarket and six adjacent stores into nine stores occupied by such high-end international retailers as Gucci, Christian Dior and Yves Saint Laurent. The new stores opened last week.
Manhasset and its surrounding communities, including Sands Point, Old Brookville, Munsey Park, Plandome and Old Westbury, were listed last year by Worth magazine as among the 250 richest communities in America. The annual average household income of the Americana customer is above $150,000, according to Deirdre Costa Major, the creative director.
The 220,000-square-foot center was developed in 1956 by Castagna Realty on a 16-acre parcel along Northern Boulevard, a major North Shore road. There are 45 stores in the center, which had always had a supermarket as an anchor on its eastern end. 
AMERICANA was originally named Fifth Avenue of Long Island by Frank Castagna, an owner. Castagna Realty began in 1922 as a construction company and built a number of notable Long Island buildings, including the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum and the University Hospital at Stony Brook. 
The plan for high-end leases at the original Manhasset center "didn't go through," Ms. Major said, "so at that time we did the best we could to fill it up, and we had two supermarkets." In 1983 the first upscale store, Brooks Brothers, came in and then the Armani line was added to Hirshleifer's, which carries designer women's clothing. 
The architect Peter Marino of Manhattan, who designed Barneys New York on Madison Avenue, was brought in "to create a concept for the sophisticated and affluent area," she said. One store at a time, the old facades were removed and new limestone buildings with a town house effect and granite sidewalks were created.
Three years ago, the lease expired for the 29,000-square-foot anchor space occupied by Waldbaum's supermarket since 1959. Last year, the store was demolished and construction began on the new building.
Tenants include the 185-year-old Brooks Brothers, which is moving from a 10,000-square-foot store to a two-level 13,000-square-foot space. 
St. John and Louis Vuitton are relocating from a 7,125-square-foot space farther west in the center that is being subdivided into four spaces designed especially for high-end jewelry tenants. Cartier will occupy 1,400 square feet; Van Cleef & Arpels, 500 square feet; and London Jewelers, a 77-year-old Long Island firm that has five stores in upscale communities, including the Hamptons, will occupy 4,275 square feet. Negotiations are pending with a fourth jeweler for the remaining 950 square feet. 
Those stores are expected to be completed before Christmas, according to Andras Frankel, the owner of the Manhattan-based IBEX Construction, which is building the new spaces. 
In Manhattan, IBEX recently completed a three-story, 21,000-square-foot clothing story, Faconnable, at Rockefeller Center and is constructing six stores in the AOL Time Warner Center on Columbus Circle. "What is being done in Manhasset is not any less than the high-ends on Madison Avenue," Mr. Frankel said.
Twelve miles east at Woodbury Village, the Hauppauge-based Staller Associates, the owner, is subdividing a 31,000-square-foot store into about 10 boutique-type shops. The space had been occupied by a supermarket since the center opened as an enclosed mall with 10 stores in 1977, according to Cary F. Staller, a principal with his father, Erwin P. Staller. The firm manages and owns, through various partnerships, 50 shopping centers on Long Island. 
Six years ago, with the exception of the supermarket, the mall was rebuilt and expanded into a 100,000-square-foot, L-shaped open strip of 30 shops and restaurants; about 75 percent are LongIsland-based retailers with high-quality goods, Cary Staller said. The rest are national specialty chains, like Arizona-based Cold Stone Creamery, which sells custom-mixed homemade ice cream. Eight of the stores are on Jericho Turnpike, another of the North Shore's main roads. The remaining are on South Woods Road fronting the rolling hills of the Town of Oyster Bay golf course. 
The new center was designed by the architect John Notaro of the Melville-based Notaro Grupp with a colonial theme modeled after a 20,000-square-foot center that Staller also owns in the historic Bellport village on the south shore.
About 20 percent of the $15 million project was spent on the facade and its details, Mr. Staller said. "We needed to create an upscale look, and so it wouldn't look so massive, we broke it up with dormers, pillars and brick trim," he said. 
Three months ago, Stop & Shop supermarket closed its doors at the center with one year left on its lease. Last month, Staller acquired the lease, "so we could control the direction of the shopping center and bring in a new mix, with no chance of getting an incompatible tenant," Mr. Staller said. 
Construction is to begin soon on the subdivision, creating eight to 10 stores of 1,500 to 7,500 square feet, he said. The center's annual rents are $36 to $40 per square foot, not including taxes or utilities. 
"It is our vision to continue to bring in leading Long Island merchants and some chains that are high-end," Mr. Staller said. Despite today's sluggish economy, the tenants have all been "very successful, so there has to be a need for this type of center, especially in selected areas," he said. 
The average annual household income within a five-mile radius of the center is $120,000, according to San Diego-based Claritas Inc., a market research firm. Woodbury and its surrounding communities, including Oyster Bay Cove, Laurel Hollow and Muttontown, are also on Worth's magazine's list.
DAN KULCHINSKY, an owner of the 48-year-old Mayfair Diamonds and Fine Jewelry, which handles couture jewelry, has four stores on Long Island. He said the demographics were right for a store at Woodbury. "This is our client base," Mr. Kulchinsky said. "Many of them have homes in the Hamptons as well as here and shop in our two Hampton stores." 
Efrem Aaron, the owner of Efrem, which specializes in fine leather goods, had been in the 250-store Roosevelt Field Mall in Garden City before moving into a 2,000-square-foot space at Woodbury Village. "We are a high-end specialty store and many of our customers do not go to the mall," Mr. Aaron said. 
To highlight their centers, both developers have also focused on luxurious landscaping.
At Woodbury Village colorful perennials bloom beside clusters of swaying native grasses in a parklike setting created by the East Norwich-based Ireland Gannon Associates, a landscape firm. 
At the Manhasset center, Oehme, van Swede, landscape designers based in Washington, have created gardens with flowers, Ms. Major said, that "change every season, like fashion."

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
Look Underground, and Unemployment Is Low

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
ANOTHER Labor Day has passed, with the usual cookouts, marches and store sales but characteristically little notice of what may be the fastest-growing part of the work force: those who labor off the books.
 By its nature, of course, the underground economy is hard to measure. But it's not hard to see. Lately, it has been all around us, which is especially noteworthy now that the unemployment rate seems stuck at more than 6 percent. 
 Some people have suggested that the unemployment figure is deceptively low. There are, after all, more than two million people in prison, many more than in decades past, and disability claims are up, too. If all these potential workers were counted, the unemployment rate would indeed be higher.
But the number of such potential workers is far exceeded by the total of those working off the books -- whose labors would drive down the unemployment rate significantly if counted. That is especially true by historical standards, because the amount of underground economic activity has been expanding so much. The International Monetary Fund, in a global survey of underground economic activity last year, found that this sector has been growing in the United States for 30 years. The authors of the I.M.F. report have estimated underground economic activity at 8.6 percent of gross domestic product in the United States, up from 6.7 percent in 1990 and just 4 percent in 1970.
Because most people who work off the books are in labor-intensive fields -- investment bankers and heart surgeons tend to operate within the confines of the tax system -- it is a safe bet that 9 percent of G.D.P. translates to more than 9 percent of the work force.
No one is sure how many people work off the books. But most of us don't need the I.M.F. to tell us that the total is significant. If you have children, for instance, you may be paying somebody off the books to care for them, perhaps full time.
Edgar L. Feige, a retired economist at the University of Wisconsin who is an authority on the underground economy, has estimated from currency data that unreported income in the United States more than doubled during the 1990's, reaching $1.25 trillion in 2000.
One reason for this growth is the arrival of millions of immigrants, especially illegal ones. There were an estimated 8.7 million illegal immigrants in this country in 2000, according to the Census Bureau. And a large proportion are working off the books for employers who appreciate cheap, compliant labor free of employment regulations and payroll taxes. Another reason is the growing importance of the service economy: it is easier to keep this activity off the books. In the case of child care, for instance, parents do not want to wrestle with paperwork and payroll taxes, while the child care providers often prefer to avoid taxes. In effect, parents get cheaper labor while workers get higher wages.
Changes in society over the decades have also encouraged off-the-books work. Women's participation in the labor force exceeded 60 percent in 2001, up from 34 percent in 1950. That change has created much more demand for child care, gardening and other domestic help.
While a large underground economy suggests a lot of tax evasion, it also implies something positive: that inflation is even lower than the official rate. And, of course, it means that an awful lot of employment is not captured by government statistics.
So I'm doubtful that unemployment was a big problem this Labor Day, especially given the odds that someone out of work might be living with someone else who still has a job and thus can put food on the table. That the United States economy has produced enough jobs for millions of women and immigrants over the years -- without unemployment soaring far beyond 6 percent -- is close to miraculous.
The real problem is what has happened to the least skilled -- and least paid -- workers. From 1979 to 2001, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the real earnings of men without high school diplomas fell by a horrifying 28 percent. For women, whose pay was already lower, the decline was still 9 percent. Here, too, immigration and off-the-books labor have played roles, by sharply increasing the pool of low-skill labor.
A lot has changed since Labor Days past. But we still haven't managed to repeal the law of supply and demand.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS; 
Kica Matos, Henry Fernandez III

 BODY:
Angelica Matos and Henry Joseph Fernandez III are to be married today. Judge Guido Calabresi of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit will officiate at his home in Woodbridge, Conn.
 Ms. Matos, who is 37 and is known as Kica, will keep her surname. She is the executive director of the Junta for Progressive Action, a nonprofit agency in New Haven for Latinos. She is also a tutor at the Yale Law School. A graduate of Victoria University of Wellington, New Zealand, the bride received a master's degree in political science from the New School in New York and a law degree from Cornell. She is a daughter of Aurelia Santos de Matos and Dr. Cruz Alfonso Matos of Vega Alta, P.R. Her father, who is retired, was the chief United Nations technical adviser for natural and marine resources in the South Pacific, based in Suva, Fiji. 
 Mr. Fernandez, 35, is the city economic development administrator in New Haven. He is also the vice chairman of the Center for Community Change, a nonprofit agency in Washington that organizes and represents poor people nationwide. He graduated cum laude from Harvard and received a law degree from Yale. His mother, Margaret Fernandez, lives in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and is a case manager for the Dutchess County Office for the Aging there. He is also a son of Henry Fernandez.
Ms. Matos and Mr. Fernandez met in summer 1996 in Washington at a conference of the National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty. She was a member of its board, and he was a nominee for the board.
"I thought Henry was strange-looking," Ms. Matos said. "He was really thin, 40 pounds less than he weighs now. His hair was in a crew cut style, and his eyes, which are very green, looked yellow from the angle I was in when I first saw him. It wasn't a negative feeling -- just strange."
Mr. Fernandez recalled that at the conference, he made "very conservative" comments to Ms. Matos's outspoken feminist statements, "just to get under her skin."
"I always took the bait, and then he would say he was just kidding," said Ms. Matos, who said she found his impudence appealing.
They soon began dating. When Ms. Matos began her studies at Cornell Law School that fall, one or the other would make six-hour drives on weekends between New Haven, where he was living, and Ithaca, N.Y. Their relationship, which Mr. Fernandez said was casual at first, became more serious over three years and many miles.
"If you are driving all that distance, there is a point where you realize that this must be something significant," he said. When she moved to Philadelphia, they saw each other every weekend. Finally, in spring 2001, after "much negotiating," Ms. Matos said, Mr. Fernandez persuaded her to move to New Haven.
"We both realized we loved each other and wanted to settle down," she said. "But I kept telling him to give me reasons why it would make sense for me to move. We both share a passion for justice and are both driven by a sense of justice in our work. I thought it was important that it really be a part of our relationship as well. Finally, I said I would move if I had assurance that he would make the same sacrifice for me, if the situation came up. He immediately said yes, and after that it was easy."

HEADLINE: The World; 
For the Japanese Connoisseur, Cheap Trick Rules

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
NEIL YOUNG once sang, "It's better to burn out than to fade away." With all due deference to Mr. Young, the Japanese taste for aging foreign rock stars suggests that some things improve with age.
 While Americans are certainly no strangers to dinosaur rock, most Western fans follow their favorite aging act with a wink, understanding all too well that the music is often stale and played by musicians old enough to be grandparents. In Japan, the fans are far more earnest -- particularly with performers who long ago fell somewhere below top-tier aging acts like the Rolling Stones and Eric Clapton. 
 Small wonder then that Japan has become not just a departure point for foreign bands seeking to build a following -- something it has long been -- but also a final destination for older acts looking to pad a nest egg for retirement. 
Just last month, the world's second-largest music market welcomed Chuck Berry, now 76, who lit up the stage as the band Cheap Trick celebrated the 25th anniversary of "Live at Budokan," the album recorded at Tokyo's most famous concert hall. Olivia Newton-John visited in April, trying to generate the same spark the Bay City Rollers ignited here in 2001. King Crimson, Yes and Lou Reed all made whistle stops this year. Journey and the Eagles may arrive next year.
"It was like Beatlemania when we came over the first time," said Bun E. Carlos, the drummer for Cheap Trick, during the band's recent tour. "The Japanese are really loyal fans. If they take to you, you can come back many times."
The Japanese fixation with older musicians is not as whimsical as it may seem. From an early age, Japanese are taught to specialize and refine their skills to perfection -- not just in music, but also in the workplace, in sports and in other pastimes. This helps explain why small groups of fans, many of whom have little facility with English, can recite lyrics to every Kiss song ever written.
In a society where everyday life is so regimented, hobbies also provide an outlet for people to express their identity. A Japanese financier might wear a blue suit and starched shirt by day, but by night be found in a bar devoted entirely to the music of the Grateful Dead or the Beatles. Wearing a company lapel pin does not exclude one from donning a ripped concert T-shirt after hours and swapping album liner notes with fellow fans.
Still, some critics have suggested that has-been bands come to Japan less for the doting fans than for an easy payoff and audiences that can't recognize -- or are too forgiving of -- a bad performance. The country has also been seen as something of a crash pad where jet-lagged and unrehearsed bands come to polish their licks before taking their tours elsewhere. 
But touring here is actually only about as lucrative as it is in the United States, given the high taxes and pricier cost of living, Mr. Carlos and others said. And while the sour economy has forced Japanese promoters to cut back on perks they once paid to attract foreigners, like airfare and food, bands are lured to the country for far less mercenary reasons: high-quality studios, comfortable hotels, safe streets and warm hospitality. 
"Bands are treated like gold in Japan," said Akiko Rogers, an agent at the William Morris Agency who brings American bands to the country. "It spoils them. All the older bands have fond memories of Japan. Everyone remembers the hospitality, how they were treated. It's an easy sell to get them to go there."
As for the charge that foreign bands use Japan as a place to practice rather than perform, Japanese fans take a philosophical stance. "Professionals like me don't feel satisfied when we see shows and they feel like rehearsals," said Reiko Yukawa, a well-known Japanese songwriter and music critic. "But I know the bands love Japan and the fans, so that's why we accept their music even if it sounds like they are practicing."
And, it seems, even if they're long past their prime. How else could the Ventures, the archetypal 1960's American surf band now relegated to oldies radio, be considered gods in Japan? Nearly four decades after they hit the scene, there are still more than 100 Ventures copy bands roaming the country, where the actual group often tours.
"It was like when a duckling hatches and sees its mother for the first time," said Minoru Shiraishi, a 51-year-old interior designer, recalling the first time he saw the Ventures in concert back in 1966. "I knew I had to follow them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Performing in Tokyo last year, Chuck Berry climbed on top of a drum set to escape an overexcited crowd of admirers. (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Paper Industry Awaits Its Bounce

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIMELMAN

 BODY:
PAPER and forest products companies generally outperform the broader market in the early stages of an economic recovery, and some analysts are holding out hope that companies in this sector will live up to their billing soon.
 Moreover, many Wall Street analysts expect that the stocks will rally further because of the weak dollar. 
 "As bullish as I am about an economic recovery, I am even more confident that the dollar will continue to decline," said Michael A. Kagan, a managing director at Salomon Brothers Asset Management. "That's why I like U.S. paper companies so much right now." 
When the dollar declines against other currencies, American paper and wood products companies generally benefit in foreign and domestic markets because their products are priced below those of their foreign rivals. And foreign buyers can use their stronger home currencies to buy more goods sold in dollars.
Conversely, the American paper and forest products industry -- a sector that includes big, broad-based companies like International Paper and Weyerhaeuser and smaller specialty companies like Smurfit-Stone Container -- has underperformed the market when the dollar has strengthened against the home currencies of rival companies, said Lise Shonfield, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase. This negative correlation between the dollar and stock prices, she added, was generally strong during the last eight years. 
Since February 2002, the dollar had lost 21 percent of its value relative to the euro and 14 percent to the Canadian dollar. While the dollar has recovered somewhat against the euro in recent months, many Wall Street economists question whether the recovery can continue. 
Some economists regard the weak dollar as a long-lasting phenomenon, in part because of a chronic trade deficit, which has bolstered the currencies of countries from which Americans import goods. The trade deficit is running at 5 percent of gross domestic product, the highest share since World War II, said Brian Keyser, the chief domestic economist for Citigroup Asset Management. "The deficit is so big that I expect to see further weakness in the dollar," he said. 
But in the paper and wood products industries, the theory behind the dollar-based optimism has not yet proved itself. Despite the dollar decline that began early last year, the level of American imports has not fallen, and exports have not grown. 
To the contrary, imports of many paper and wood products are continuing to climb, and exports are fairly flat for most kinds of paper. 
Analysts offer a number of reasons for the lag between the dollar's swoon and the rising fortunes they expect for American makers of paper and wood products. For one, they say, a weaker-than-expected pickup in global demand for paper and wood products is forcing European manufacturers to continue shipping to the United States, even though the euro's strength against the dollar has made those sales less profitable. 
Ms. Shonfield at J. P. Morgan said that many European manufacturers, like the Finnish companies UPM-Kymmene and Stora Enso, did not regard the dollar's weakness over the last year and a half as a lasting condition. In recent years, when the dollar was stronger, these companies built a presence in the United States. Early this year, they viewed the dollar's weakness as temporary and expected the dollar to strengthen once the United States defeated Saddam Hussein in Iraq. "But the euro has remained stubbornly strong," she said. 
Once economic activity picks up, Ms. Shonfield said, American producers may get a "double whammy" benefit from the recovery and a currency shift. 
MR. KAGAN likes Smurfit-Stone Container because he expects its sales of container board, the basic material in paper-based shipping containers, to pick up as consumer spending rises. 
Container board is expected to benefit greatly from a weak dollar. Smurfit-Stone derives about three-quarters of its sales from container board and corrugated containers. Mark Wilde, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, wrote recently that "container-board producers could be the biggest winners on the export side."
Smurfit-Stone is trading at $15.41, about 110 times its earnings per share over the last four quarters.
Mr. Kagan also likes International Paper, which he sees as benefiting from a recovery in a variety of paper products. The company makes a wide variety of coated and uncoated paper, as well as packaging materials. It is trading at $39.65 a share, about 40 times its earnings over the last four quarters.
Richard Schneider, an analyst at UBS, likes Weyerhaeuser, a leading manufacturer of pulp. The dollar's decline will help shift manufacturing of this basic wood product from Europe to the United States in coming years, he said. "By far, the biggest impact to these stocks will be the pickup in orders and growth in economic activity," he said. "But the currency situation will also help these stocks."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Even Match"Paper companies have kept pace with the overall stock market in the last 12 months. Graph tracks the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and Bloomberg U.S. Forest Products and Paper index since 2002. (Source by Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: Americans in Poverty 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Census Shows Ranks of Poor Rose in 2002 by 1.3 Million" (news article, Sept. 3): News that the number of people in poverty rose last year is sad enough, but even sadder still when we consider that this figure only includes people who fall below the official "poverty line" of $17,960 for a family of four. 
 Most people realize that this figure is shockingly low, and researchers estimate that it takes about double that amount for a family to meet the cost of food, health care, housing and child care alone.
Using this benchmark, almost 30 percent of families fall short. That's the sad reality, and a clear indication that our economy isn't working for everyone.

TAMARA DRAUT
New York, Sept. 3, 2003

The writer is director, economic opportunity program, at Demos, a public policy group.
