HEADLINE: LOVE & MONEY; 
When a Windfall Frays Family Ties

BYLINE:  By ELLYN SPRAGINS; Ellyn Spragins is a freelance writer in Pennington, N.J. Her column about money's influence on relationships appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: loveandmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IF you're anything like me, it's at times like these, with the economy still on crutches and bonuses disappearing, that you fantasize about the jackpot that will lift the yoke of worries from your neck. 
 Experts say giant chunks of money don't really make you happy. I've always wanted to test that theory, specifically on Fifth Avenue. But being jackpotless, I've consoled myself lately by studying how windfalls don't simply fall -- they sometimes detonate. 
 Last month, Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight boxing champion, filed for bankruptcy despite making about $400 million over the past 20 years. In the line of creditors and claimants are former loved ones -- Monica Turner, one of his former wives, and Kimberley Scarborough, a former girlfriend and the mother of their daughter.
In early July, Kenneth Parker, 77, who lives on Long Island, sued his wife of 17 years, Connie, 74, for a $25 million New York Lotto jackpot they won on Valentine's Day. Mrs. Parker contends that she is entitled to the entire amount because she bought the winning ticket with her own money, according to her lawyer, Mark Brancato, who is based in Manhasset. Mr. Parker's lawyer, Dominic Barbara, who has offices in Manhattan and Garden City, says his client gave his wife $20, with which she bought the winning ticket and a Valentine's Day card for him. "The money came in and the love walked out," he said.
Mr. Barbara said the couple had no apparent marital problems beforehand, while Mr. Brancato said they did.
It may not be surprising if Mr. Tyson and the Parkers had a few fault lines running through their relationships. Who doesn't? But it is too glib to suggest that the money simply served as a megawatt searchlight, illuminating those flaws. There is a peculiar intensity to the vitriol, a grotesqueness in the acrimony, that breaks out among windfall winners' relationships.
What is the number that turns an inheritance or a windfall from a pleasant, let's-go-to-Hawaii experience into a vengeful slugfest, and why does it do so?
First, it has to be a life-altering amount, said Stephen Goldbart, co-founder of the Money, Meaning and Choices Institute, a wealth counseling organization in Kentfield, Calif. (I would define it as enough to let you live well without having to work anymore.)
Next, for a relationship to turn really ugly, the windfall recipient should ascribe supercharged, magical powers to the money. "When money represents a panacea for all ills in someone's life, they believe they can make their life perfect once they get it," Dr. Goldbart said.
For many of the suddenly wealthy, life's perfectibility becomes the mission. They are obligated to be happy. The delicate mechanism that keeps marriage partners in equilibrium breaks apart when a newly rich spouse no longer sees a need to accommodate imperfection or compromise.
Worse, purchased perfection can negate many of the partner's contributions. Who cares about your hand-knit sweaters or your fastidious housekeeping when they can easily be bought? Who needs your good job and your responsible saving habits? Just as a jackpot winner is willing to discard an old identity for a shiny, seamless, new self, her spouse is being forced to recognize that what he stands for isn't worth much in the new marital order.
The dispossessed half of the couple may or may not understand that he or she has been devalued. "If they can articulate it, they say things like, 'I feel like I've lost my voice,' 'I feel diminished,' or 'I feel like I'm competing with money,' " said Ellen M. Perry, a founder and managing partner at Wealthbridge Partners in Washington, which conducts education programs for wealthy families.
The effect of sudden wealth on sibling relationships is just as charged. Everything that is part of being a sibling -- shared values, common experiences and competition for parents' attention -- sets you up for a lifetime of covert comparison. When the company owned by your entrepreneurial brother goes public, it's as if a marker for your own life has been moved beyond reach. Once, you were more or less following the same road map. Now he has gained entry to a territory that you don't havea prayer of seeing. If we share so much, you wonder, why have things turned out so differently for him?
Eileen Gallo, a psychotherapist in Los Angeles and a columnist for the Journal of Financial Planning, spent two years studying people who had hit the jackpot through initial public offerings of stock, lotteries or unexpected inheritances. She found that half of them spontaneously wanted to talk about the money's impact on sibling relationships, and that nearly all said the effect had been negative. She concludes that many family members feel envy or an astonishing sense of entitlement about a relative's new wealth, expecting handouts or permanent financial support.
IN other families, the change in status is so deeply dividing that siblings repudiate generous gestures with stiff-necked pride. Dr. Goldbart recalls a couple in their early 40's who experienced sudden wealth after exercising stock options in the mid-1990's. They offered to pay for the cost of a private high school for their favorite niece so that she could get a better education than the one offered by her neighborhood's so-so public school. The girl's mother reacted angrily, accusing the couple of undermining her relationship with her own daughter.
See what troubles you've been avoiding by being unlucky? Me, too. The next time my windfall fantasy gets out of hand, I'll remind myself what Spike Milligan, the late comic performer, said: "Money can't buy friends, but it can get you a better class of enemy."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Debt Trouble Could Be Piling Up Overseas

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
FOR the world's poorer countries, this year has been remarkably free from financial meltdowns.
 Argentina, having had one-fifth of its economy evaporate in 2001, is mending fences with international creditors and slowly putting itself back together. In Brazil, where investors seemed close to a panic last year, exports are surging and the currency remains stable. The Asian and Russian meltdowns of five years ago seem like distant memories. 
 But watch out. In a report that will be published this week, the International Monetary Fund warns that some Asian and Latin American governments have loaded up with much more debt than a first glance might suggest.
The total public debt of Asian governments has risen to nearly 70 percent of their gross domestic product, from less than 60 percent at the height of the Asian financial crisis in 1998. In Latin America, the debt ratio has climbed to 60 percent from about 40 percent.
By contrast, the debt ratio of industrialized countries is about 40 percent. What worries economists at the I.M.F. is that the world's poorer nations are on much shakier ground to begin with. Their tax collection systems are weaker and less reliable. Their exposure to outside shocks is larger.
Though the I.M.F.'s economists bent over backward to avoid inflammatory rhetoric, they nevertheless concluded that debt levels needed to come down drastically. For the typical emerging-market economy, a "sustainable" government debt would be about one-third its current level, the report said.
The obvious question, of course, is this: Why have debt levels increased in so many countries?
The new report shows that there has been an important new twist to the old borrowing patterns. Instead of turning first to foreign lenders, whether public institutions like the I.M.F. or the big international banks, many governments are raising money at home.
In Asia, for example, external borrowing has been virtually flat ever since the financial crises that swept from South Korea to Indonesia. But domestic government borrowing has ballooned.
In Latin America, external borrowing had been on a downward trend while domestic borrowing rose year after year.
The distinction between foreign and domestic borrowing is subtle. The "domestic" lenders can be foreign institutions, and they often are. The debt may even be denominated in dollars or euros.
The real difference is that domestic borrowing falls under the laws of the borrowing country rather than the creditor country.
But I.M.F. officials contend that the rise in domestic debt is important for several reasons. For starters, it is often more difficult for foreign investors and lenders to evaluate a government's domestic debt levels. As in the United States, governments can often push public debt off the books by setting up the loans through quasi-public corporations or private corporations supported by government loan guarantees.
Domestic debt can also be more difficult to collect. The security of a loan will depend in part on the laws of the country and the effectiveness of local courts at enforcing contract terms and adjudicating disputes.
The new report, which will be released on Thursday as part of the I.M.F.'s annual World Economic Outlook, points out some notable exceptions in the trend toward heavier indebtedness.
Chile, which is Latin America's most open economy as well as one of its most prosperous, has chopped its public debt from 54 percent of gross domestic product in 1990 to just 21 percent in 2002.
The post-Communist countries of central Europe, several of which got into trouble with overborrowing in the early 1990's, have reduced their debt levels as well.
THE report also takes note of what may be hidden time bombs. It says that one major cause of the rise in public debt has been a country's "contingent liabilities." These liabilities often come in the form of special loan conditions, like indexing loan repayments to changes in the borrowing country's exchange rate. If the country's currency plunges, as happened in Brazil last year, debt payments can soar.
Of course, poor countries are not the only ones that need to watch their debt. The United States government is by far the world's biggest government borrower, expected to run up nearly $1 trillion in new debt over this year and next.
If poorer countries need any lecturing about reining in their debts, American officials would be well advised to stay in the background.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Pension Funds Weighing the Risks of Emerging Markets

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
FOUR New York City pension funds are on the verge of shifting $1.7 billion of their assets to one of the riskier sectors of the equity markets -- emerging-markets stocks.
 The question is: Are these pension funds, along with other investors, getting in too late, with these markets already up almost 32 percent this year? 
 George R. Hoguet, head of State Street Global Advisors' emerging-markets equity team that manages $1.8 billion, says emerging markets are "in a sweet spot,' and can continue to thrive. Still, he is worried that a "shock" could bring a halt to the rally. 
The board of the City Employees Retirement System, the largest of the four pension plans, is taking the dip into emerging markets for the first time, with the goal of shifting as much as $900 million to them. The boards of the Police and Fire Department Pension Funds and the Board of Education Retirement System are looking to commit a total of $790 million to emerging markets, three times the $262 million the three plans now have invested in them. The money managers who will invest the funds' assets are expected to be chosen by year-end.
While $1.7 billion is a small portion of the four funds' total assets of $51 billion, the proposed move by the city pension funds reflects a trend among institutional investors, who have been pouring money into emerging markets. This, in itself, is a big reason emerging markets are doing well.
One cause of the shift is a change in attitude about these markets, which have a volatile history of huge gains and big losses that kept many investors away in the past. Morgan Stanley Capital International's emerging-markets index surged 63.7 percent in 1999 followed by a decline of 31.8 percent, in dollar terms, in 2000.
"We have a situation where people are looking to increase returns," Mr. Hoguet said. With the bond market selling off and the United States stock market providing only modest double-digit returns over all, investors are considering anything that looks better.
The office of the New York City Comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., who is on the board of all of the city's pension funds, had essentially the same explanation. "Each board," a spokeswoman for the comptroller said, "did an asset allocation study and as a result some opted to diversify their equity portfolio by adding emerging-market equity investments because these fit in with their investment strategies."
But emerging-markets investors are often chasing the most recent returns, only to find that they have missed the boat.
Since 1998, the M.S.C.I. Emerging Markets Free Index is up 28.7 percent, compared with a decline of 16.9 percent for the S.& P. 500-stock index. The 31.7 percent increase this year is almost double the gain in the S.& P. 500. But since 1996, the M.S.C.I. emerging-markets index has been down in five years and up in just two, including 2003. And since 1993, these markets are down 28.7 percent, while the S.& P. 500 is up 119 percent.
Mr. Hoguet is upbeat because valuations in emerging markets are still relatively low. But he said the standoff with North Korea over the production of nuclear weapons could turn ugly, sending South Korea's market lower and dragging down other markets with it. He also said emerging markets could face a problem if the United States economic recovery "does not gather momentum."
Investors, he said, are not "properly pricing the risk" in South Korea, the largest emerging market, accounting for a fifth of the M.S.C.I. index. The South Korean stock market, as measured by M.S.C.I., is up 25.9 percent this year, more than he said it should be, and money from investors outside Korea has been pouring in since June, based on data collected by State Street.
The managers of the fifth New York City pension fund, the Teachers Retirement System, evidently did not want to take on this kind of risk. They decided not to put a piece of the fund's $23 billion in assets into emerging markets. In this case, the comptroller's spokeswoman said, "allocating assets to emerging-markets equities is not necessary to achieve the fund's risk and return objectives at this time."

The gains have come despite concerns about the effect of an international nuclear standoff involving North Korea and how it might affect South Korea, the largest emerging market. HEADLINE: Investing; 
From Canada, New Roads to Gold

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON

DATELINE: TORONTO 

 BODY:
SENSING a renewed appetite among Americans, a small army of foreigners is invading the United States with new kinds of gold investments.
 Ten small and midsized Canadian gold producers have been listed on the American Stock Exchange in the last year. The World Gold Council, a promotional group based in London, is awaiting approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission for a new exchange-traded fund backed by gold bullion. A similar fund was set up this summer on the Toronto Stock Exchange by a Canadian group with significant participation from American investors. 
 "When gold gets moving, there's nothing like it," said Ilja Graulich, general manager for investor relations at Durban Roodepoort Deep, a South African gold producer that also has interests in Australia and Papua New Guinea and is listed on the Nasdaq. "It's very easy to get hold of money at the moment," he said.
Gold is a part of many investors' portfolios, whether in the form of bullion, coins or shares of the companies that produce it. While the price of gold occasionally bursts higher on fear of runaway inflation, political instability or turbulence in financial markets, it has yet to come close to its peak, in January 1980, when it reached $850 an ounce. Gold investments were a big disappointment for much of the 1980's and 90's.
Investors in gold and the mines that produce it have done well in the last year. The metal was trading at $377 an ounce on Friday, about 18 percent higher than its 2002 average of $309. It briefly topped $380 this year, before the war in Iraq began.
The Amex's Gold BUGS index has soared 86 percent from its 52-week low, reached in October. (BUGS stands for basket of unhedged gold stocks.) The Philadelphia Stock Exchange Gold and Silver index, which includes some companies that hedge part of their output, has chalked up more modest gains, rising 17 percent so far this year. 
American gold funds are reporting substantial inflows. "We're having our best year in quite some time," said Joe Foster, who manages the Van Eck International Investors Gold fund. The fund's assets have grown by 60 percent so far this year, to $250 million, with inflows from investors accounting for about three-quarters of the increase.
John C. Hathaway, manager of the Tocqueville Gold fund, said that the fund's asset value had grown more than 50 percent in the last year, to about $293 million. The rising prices of its holdings accounted for less than one-fifth of the increase, Mr. Hathaway said, with inflows making up the rest.
Big gold producers like Newmont Mining of Denver, AngloGold of South Africa and Barrick Gold and Placer Dome of Canada, have traded on the New York Stock Exchange for years. The 10 Canadian companies that have been listed on the Amex in the past year include the Iamgold Corporation, Northgate Exploration, Wheaton River Minerals, the Minefinders Corporation, the Eldorado Gold Corporation, the Miramar Mining Corporation and Great Basin Gold. The most recent was Gammon Lake Resources of Nova Scotia, listed on Aug. 29.
"We're hearing from the companies that now is the time when they can use the increase in the gold price to gain access to the United States capital markets," said John McGonegal, vice president for equity sales at the Amex.
The exchange has assigned one of its sales representatives to Canada virtually full time to attract listings and is sponsoring two conferences on gold this year. Officials of International Investment Conferences of Miami, which is organizing the events, said 252 analysts and fund managers had registered for one of them, to be held this week in New York, roughly double the number last year. About 3,000 individual investors are also expected to attend, a fifth more than last year.
Jon A. Douglas, the chief financial officer at Northgate Exploration, says that overall trading volumes in the company's stock, which was already listed in Toronto, have more than doubled since it was listed on the Amex on July 11. Trading on the Amex has accounted for 31 percent of Northgate's daily volume. 
Barry Cooper, a metals analyst at CIBC World Markets in Toronto, wrote in a recent report that the stocks of smaller gold producers had become more attractive partly because of the weak financial performance of some large producers, despite higher gold prices. Mr. Cooper singled out Eldorado Gold and Cambior, which also trade on the Amex. On the other hand, he called Minefinders and Wheaton River "underperformers."
Mr. Hathaway, the fund manager, said, "People didn't know about a lot of those stocks a year ago; now they do know them."
STILL, Barry J. Landen, vice president for corporate affairs at Agnico-Eagle Mines, a Canadian gold company listed on the New York Stock Exchange, said that while investor interest was high, most of it was coming from familiar faces. "We want to see some new faces," Mr. Landen said.
In another move to expand choices for investors, the World Gold Council applied to the S.E.C. in May for approval to list its Equity Gold Trust, an exchange-traded fund, on the New York Stock Exchange. Richard Simonelli, a spokesman for the council, said, "Hopefully, sometime in the fall, we'll have a better understanding on the timing of the rollout."
A similar exchange-traded vehicle, Central Gold Trust, listed on the Toronto exchange through a public offering in July. The trust's president, Stefan Spicer, said that the 207 gold bars backing the trust were stored in the vaults of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and were not pledged as collateral on any loans. The trust has also said it will buy more gold whenever it issues new units so as not to dilute existing shareholders' interests.
Mr. Spicer said investors outside Canada had bought about 20 percent of the units. "The amount of interest in the United States has been very significant," he said. The trust's units are trading at about 23 Canadian dollars ($16.79), compared with the issue price of 20 Canadian dollars.
Of course, the performance of all these investments ultimately depends on the price of gold. 
The current popularity of gold has stoked the exuberance of gold fund managers, newsletter publishers and others. Mr. Hathaway concluded in a recent article that "neither the stock or bond market is capable of delivering anything close to the returns of the last 20 years."
"Once investors 'get real,' " he added, "they will migrate from paper to tangible assets."
Not everyone shares such enthusiasm. Observing that the gold market has its share of eccentrics, who tend to interpret a small rise in prices as the start of a major bull run, Mr. Graulich, the South African executive, said that "half the gold stocks are discounting a price of between $450 and $475 at the moment." If the price fails to reach those levels, investing in these stocks could lose much of its present allure.

HEADLINE: The World; 
30 Years Later, a Coup's Scars Have Been Masked

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile 

 BODY:
THE first thing a visitor is likely to notice on entering La Moneda presidential palace here after a prolonged absence is that the bullet holes that once pockmarked the exterior have been plastered over. But while the visible scars of the coup that overthrew Salvador Allende Gossens on Sept. 11, 1973, and installed Gen. Augusto Pinochet may have finally been erased, the same cannot be said of the deeper, interior trauma that was inflicted.
 As it prepares to mark the coup's 30th anniversary, Chile likes to think of itself as a normal, even boring country -- prosperous and calm, more concerned with mundane issues like the fishing law and the marriage code than plans to transform society. It has achieved that condition, though, only by ignoring -- or by failing to heal -- the most painful wounds left by its past, in what a resentful minority describes as a calculated act of "collective forgetting." 
 To the rest of the world, of course, Chile remains mostly a symbol rather than a real presence. In Europe and the United States, it is still possible to find people of a certain age who refuse to consume Chilean wine as a silent, quixotic protest against the atrocities that Pinochet's armed forces committed, while the wizards of Wall Street would rather praise Chile as their ideal of an open, capitalist economy in a developing country.
What few here or abroad wish to acknowledge, however, is that Chileans did not, at first, freely choose the economic model under which they now live. Instead, it was imposed on them as the result of the coup. Underlying the current prosperity, in other words, is a long trail of blood and suffering that makes the thought of reversing course too difficult to contemplate.
When General Pinochet was forced to leave power and democracy was restored in 1990, "the people who took over very deliberately decided for both political and psychological reasons that they wanted to bury the past," the writer Ariel Dorfman said. "They wanted a new life in which Chileans would no longer be victims, but the pain is still there and there is still a reluctance to talk about it."
Outwardly at least, Chileans are brimming with self-confidence these days, so much so that references to them as "the new Argentines" are beginning to appear in the regional press. As any Latin American knows, that is not a compliment but a way of suggesting that Chileans have become arrogant and patronizing, as their neighbors across the Andes were considered to be before their economy collapsed in 2001.
During the 1990's, Chile's resolutely free-market economy grew faster than any other in South America, at rates of up to 7 percent a year. This convinced many Chileans that the recipe that had been used here should be exported. 
"Welcome back to a country that works," the press secretary for a cabinet minister told a reporter just arriving from Venezuela.
Though cocky, that assertion is hard to deny. Visitors from other parts of Latin America are startled to find that taxes are actually collected, that the police generally do not seek or take bribes and that the political culture here places a premium on public rectitude. An isolated case of payoffs in the awarding of government contracts -- a story that would have been a minor scandal elsewhere -- was front-page news for weeks earlier this year.
Politically, too, Chile seems increasingly distinct from its neighbors.
In their most recent presidential elections, Argentina, Brazil, Ecuador, Paraguay and Venezuela all elected presidents who harshly criticized policies supported by Washington that restrict government expenditures, lower tariffs and privatize state companies. Instead, these successful candidates promised voters a greater focus on social justice and equality.
Here, in contrast, the nominally Socialist government led by Ricardo Lagos, once a member of the Allende cabinet, talks only about deepening free-market reforms. In a statement issued last month, the International Monetary Fund "congratulated the Chilean authorities" for remaining loyal to those principles during a global recession and predicted that Chile would be rewarded with increased growth next year.
And while Brazil's president, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, recently cautioned the rest of Latin America not to let Washington's plan for a Free Trade Area of the Americas become "an instrument to suffocate our possibilities for growth," Chile has already negotiated such agreements with both the United States and the European Union. 
"Chile has shown the value of free trade and having solid policies" and now "will have the opportunity to advance even further," President Bush said last week when he signed the accord.
But the modernization process has had its costs, as life here in the capital demonstrates. Though gleaming new hotels and office buildings have sprung up in neighborhoods that barely existed when Mr. Allende was overthrown, the magnificent view of the Andes that once dominated the skyline has been so diminished by automobile exhaustand smog that on many days the snow-capped mountains are not even visible.
The remnants of the left, demoralized and nostalgic for the Allende days, are disgusted by what they see and constantly complain that the populace is hypnotized by television programs that are among the most mindless anywhere. They forget that the agitprop of the Allende era was no better.
But even ordinary Chileans acknowledge a certain loss of solidarity and community.
"It took a trip to Brazil to remind me that our pace of life here is just not natural," lamented Ciro Colombara Lopez, a lawyer. "People work such long hours and are so busy making money that they barely have time to enjoy life and talk to their neighbors anymore."
But the principal problem is the persistence of a huge gap between the rich, who delight in flaunting their imported cars and vacation trips to Cancun, and the poor in whose name Mr. Allende claimed to speak. Though spending on health, education and transportation has zoomed since democracy was restored, the historic dream of an egalitarian society seems as distant as ever.
"We're a country that has reduced poverty from 40 percent to 20 percent in 10 years, and how many countries can say that?" Mr. Lagos asked during an interview here. "But the people always want more, and we have to do much more. It is a tremendous challenge."

HEADLINE: The Return of Lost Jobs? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "As Factories Move Abroad, So Does U.S. Power" (Economic View, Aug. 17) and recent letters in response to it (Aug. 31) did not focus on what is probably the major impact of the steady shift abroad of manufacturing, administrative, middle management and technical jobs. 
 A hundred years ago, Henry Ford paid his workers $5 a day, then extremely high wages, explaining that if his workers could not afford to buy his cars, he would not have enough customers. Today, our corporate managers, in their drive to lower costs, increase profits, increase share price and fatten their substantial compensations, have lost sight of the potential of losing their customers as the jobless and their families cut back on their spending.
It is no surprise that the present so-called recovery is sputtering, that lost jobs are not reappearing and that the public sector is not increasing its spending. It will be a long time before American inventiveness will develop new technologies and industries as engines of new job creation and prosperity.

GEORGE WOLF
Manhattan, Sept. 1

The writer is owner of Princess Knitwear Inc. in the Bronx.

HEADLINE: A Major Figure In a Quiet Resting Place 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "A Cemetery for the Living" (Aug. 31), about the New York City Marble Cemetery: Most New Yorkers are unaware that a historically important yet virtually unknown person is buried in the "sister" cemetery, New York Marble Cemetery. 
 That is Benjamin Wright (1770-1842), who was the chief engineer of the Erie Canal and has been designated by the American Society of Civil Engineers as "the father of American civil engineering." It was the Erie Canal that made New York the Empire State and New York City the nation's economic engine. 
 Civil engineers built the city: its bridges and tunnels, subways and highways, skyscrapers and water supply systems. Without civil engineers, the city would not be the metropolis it is today.
 It is fitting that final resting place of the father of American civil engineering is New York City.

ROBERT A. OLMSTED
Jackson Heights, Queens

The writer is chairman of the history and heritage committee of the (New York) Metropolitan Section of the American Society of Civil Engineers.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Grounded, and Fighting for Her Benefits

BYLINE:  By Terry Pristin

 BODY:
It is often said that industry consolidation leads to greater efficiencies, but that does not necessarily mean that the employees' lives will run more smoothly.
 Patricia A. Kusnick, who joined T.W.A. in 1966, when flight attendants wore girdles and white gloves and were still referred to as stewardesses, knows this first hand. The acquisition of her company by American Airlines cost her seniority rights and saddled her with many unpaid hours of commuting. Eventually she, like the other 4,000 T.W.A. flight attendants, was laid off with no severance pay. And in what she sees as a final indignity, New York State recently denied her request for unemployment benefits even though she has lived in Manhattan most of her life. 
 Once the last word in glamorous air travel, T.W.A. had struggled for many years before it was bought by American in April 2001. But although Donald J. Carty, American's chief executive at the time, assured T.W.A. personnel that they would be welcomed into "the American Airlines family," the two companies had very different cultures, she said. T.W.A. flight attendants, for example, tended to be older and more conservative in appearance than their counterparts at American, said Ms. Kusnick, who did not want her age published.
The first setback came when the union now representing them, the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, put the newcomers from T.W.A. at the bottom of the seniority roster, depriving them of job protection as well as the right to choose their base. Some American Airlines flight attendants, called "native Americans" by the T.W.A. workers, took to wearing buttons reading, "Hired, Not Acquired".
Then, after Sept. 11 curtailed air travel, American Airlines eliminated the former T.W.A. hub at John F. Kennedy International Airport and reassigned the flight attendants, including at least 150 from New York, according to airline officials, to T.W.A.'s former hub in St. Louis. An American Airlines spokeswoman, Julia Bishop-Cross, said that only T.W.A. personnel were transferred because the two airlines were still separate entities. "Integration takes years to complete," she said. "There's a very long process by which crews are retrained and airplanes are reconfigured."
Unable to relocate, Ms. Kusnick, who is married to a private investigator, said she would hop an early-morning bus to LaGuardia airport and queue up for as long as three hours in the hope of being able to travel standby to St. Louis, often on a jump seat. By the time her actual workday began, Ms. Kusnick said, she was already wiped out. "You were totally exhausted," she said. "It was like the last leg of an international flight."
In July, Ms. Kusnick was among the last 1,800 TWA flight attendants to be furloughed (2,000 of American's 20,000 flight attendants have been laid off). But when she sought unemployment benefits, she was told that she was entitled to collect from Missouri, not New York. Missouri, however, pays a maximum benefit of $250 a week, far less than New York's top weekly benefit of $405. She has appealed New York's decision. Her case is scheduled to be heard tomorrow by an administrative law judge at the New York State Department of Labor offices in SoHo.
Robert M. Lillpopp, a labor department spokesman, said he could not comment specifically on the flight attendants' case. But he said that unemployment benefits were linked to a person's base of operations, rather than his or her residence. Ms. Bishop-Cross said it made no difference to American Airlines which state awarded the benefits. But she said that airline officials would testify, if asked, that the T.W.A. flight attendants were based in Missouri.
At her hearing, Ms. Kusnick will be represented by Joel Leichter, an advocate for the Workers Defense League, a nonprofit organization that is financed in part by labor unions. Mr. Leichter said he would argue, among other things, that Ms. Kusnick was not actually based in Missouri because she received her work orders over the Internet from the airline's headquarters in Dallas and was unlikely to spend more than an hour of her workday in St. Louis. "A base of operations," he said, "has to involve something more than where they start and finish a business trip."
Determined to keep fighting, Ms. Kusnick has accumulated three wire baskets of documents about unemployment law. "I'm not going to accept that they aren't going to give me what I am due," she said.

HEADLINE: For Many Chinese, America's Allure Is Fading 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN

DATELINE: CHANGLE, China 

 BODY:
His older brother was the pioneer, more than a decade ago. His son followed three years ago. As recently as last year, his daughter planned to join this exodus of thousands from Fujian Province who have gambled that the life of a smuggled immigrant in America would eclipse that of an impoverished native in China.
 But she lost interest after her brother's experience. 
 "Life is much more difficult than he expected, so I regret sending him to America," said the father, Mr. Wang, who -- like some others interviewed for this article -- spoke on the condition that only his surname be used. "He is miserable. He says to me, 'Why am I working so hard in America? I can get rich at home.' It's very different from the way it used to be."
Ten years ago this summer, human smuggling exploded into international consciousness when the Golden Venture, a decrepit freighter stuffed with 286 Chinese, most from the Changle area in southern China, ran aground off Queens, New York. Ten people died in the cold and pounding surf, and soon, the name Golden Venture became shorthand for a cruel world of exploitation of desperate people.
Today, the smuggling trade continues, though perhaps at a slower clip, people here say, costing $60,000 per head. But for the first time, many Fujianese feel less urgency about venturing abroad.
They have more options at home, with jobs available in small businesses, steel factories or construction sites. It is far more convenient and less troublesome, some people say, to make small money in the comfort of familiar surroundings, instead of relatively big money in the clutches of a lonely and inhospitable land.
Some smuggled Chinese are even leaving America as soon as they pay their debts, and without gaining permanent residency, because they want a less stressful life at home.
"America is no paradise," said one man surnamed Zheng, who returned to the village of Shengmei a few years ago. He described a seven-year odyssey that started in New York but took him to many other places. "It was the same routine every day for six or seven years," he droned. "Get up. Work for 16 hours. Go to bed. Get up again. I was a fool. A machine."
America is still in people's thoughts here. Of dozens of people interviewed in half a dozen villages around Changle, nearly everyone claimed to have at least one relative overseas, most in New York.
In small fishing villages like Houyu, where jobs are scarce, the urge to leave remains strong.
But in many places, that desire is now muted by considerations such as economics, family and safety. Some people attribute their reluctance to tighter security in China and America after the Sept. 11 attacks.
"The Golden Venture has defined the discourse for years, and people still have the same ideas about Chinese and smuggling," said Peter Kwong, director of the Asian-American studies program at Hunter College. But things have changed, he said, adding, "The economic incentive is no longer absolute."
The woman accused of being the chief smuggler, or "snakehead," behind the Golden Venture, Cheng Chui Ping, is on trial in New York. The lawyer who represented many of the immigrants, Robert E. Porges, is in jail, after admitting that he helped many of them concoct false stories of persecution to bolster their asylum cases. The ship itself is being used as an artificial reef about a mile off the coast of Boca Raton, Fla.
Changle, a county of about 650,000 people, has changed, too. Several years ago, the county seat, also named Changle, was a dusty, lethargic town with bleak prospects, said Mr. Kwong, who collaborated on a documentary film about Fujianese emigrants in the mid-1990's. Now, it is a bustling city crowned by new high-rise apartments, stylish new stores and a new boulevard, North Shiyang Street.
Changle is full of people, like Zhou Xueqing, whose attitudes toward emigration have changed. More than a decade ago, her husband went to New York to work as a cook, and he sends home a few hundred dollars a month. But he is depressed, and his health is deteriorating.
His hard life deterred their son from going to America. He went to Shanghai instead. He now runs a mobile phone business and earns $12,000 a year, a good income there.
"The average person doesn't want to be smuggled into America anymore," said Ms. Zhou, who works at a new bedding store. "The economy is so terrible there." 
That view can also be heard on the busy streets of Jinfeng, another longtime starting point for illegal emigration. At her family's fashionable Wei Wei wedding store, Chen Meicun described a conundrum of yearning and conflict, risk and reward.
Ms. Chen, 21, said she once thought of joining her brother, who left 10 years ago for Peru. But she is loath to give up her job and the comforts of an upwardly mobile life.
"It's dangerous to go -- look at what happened in England," she said, referring the deaths three years ago of 58 Chinese who were being smuggled in the back of a truck. "Every country has its good and its bad, so why should I leave?"
In village after village, people outlined the same choices. If they got a good job here, they would stay. If not, they would try to borrow enough money to leave. Not one person talked about politics or human rights here, or China's one-child policy. The issue was money.
In a small store in Tingjiang, across the Min River in Lianjiang County, questions about smuggling people into America prompted a lively discussion.
The owner, a 28-year-old woman surnamed Lin, said she wanted her only child, a 4-year-old boy, to study hard and get a job close to home. She could not bear the thought of him going to America. "Everyday life here is not too bad," she said. "Our country is developing very quickly."
One customer, playing cards with some underemployed friends under a creaky ceiling fan, disagreed. "Not everyone can afford to go, but everyone wants to go," he said.
The nearby town of Shengmei is the hometown of Ms. Cheng, the alleged Golden Venture mastermind, and she is revered there as a benevolent patron.
But it is also the home of Mr. Zheng -- the man who called himself a fool for having gone to America. Mr. Zheng, 50, who holds a degree in marine biology from Xiamen University, said he had a miserable existence overseas. Though he was able to send home about $2,000 a year, he said he never laughed or smiled when he was in America.
His life now is not carefree. He has found only sporadic work, mainly in construction. But at least he can have tea with his friends, go for leisurely strolls and watch his son mature, day by day.
"You don't have to climb too high up the mountain -- just climb to a place in the middle that's more suitable," he said. "If you make a lot of money but don't have the time to enjoy it, what's the point? Money isn't everything."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Changle, which used to be a sleepy town, apartment buildings now line bustling North Shiyang Street. (Photo by David W. Chen/The New York Times) Map of China highlighting Changle: Job opportunities are growing in Changle, a once-poor county seat.

HEADLINE: THE VIEW/From Norwich; 
Class Act: Calling On Alumni to Back a Cause

BYLINE:  By GAIL BRACCIDIFERRO

 BODY:
WHEN Arthur Desrosier was invited to his 50th high school reunion five years ago, he was reluctant to attend. He left home after graduating from Norwich Free Academy and seldom looked back in college or during a career in which he spent 25 years as president at three successive colleges. 
 That is until the superintendent and principal of the academy, Mary Lou Bargnesi, whose family once lived on the same Norwich street as the Desrosiers, contacted him. Not only did she persuade Dr. Desrosier to attend the reunion, but she also enlisted him to be the honors speaker and to serve as a volunteer development consultant for his alma mater, a private school most of the city's working-class students attended. 
 "After I left Norwich, it sort of dawned on me how lucky I was to have an N.F.A. education," Dr. Desrosier said in a telephone interview from Billings, Mont., where he lives. "People from my time didn't expect to go to college if they were from a laboring family. 
"It pleased me to go back and see the same high quality and the demands on the students there today." 
Dr. Desrosier is assisting with the school's largest capital campaign, which is seeking to raise $10 million for an art and music building, $7 million to renovate the landmark Slater Memorial Museum -- a Romanesque-style art museum on the campus that opened in 1886 -- and $20 million to add to the school's endowment.
Construction on a new parking and bus lanes has already begun. Digging for the foundation for the new art and music building is expected to begin in March. 
Large-scale educational fund-raising was an integral part of his work as a college president, and Dr. Desrosier said he was eager to share his expertise. But while fund-raising and constant courting of alumni and philanthropists are part of daily life at independent schools, Norwich Free Academy is a different case.
The academy, the designated high school for the city of Norwich, along with seven small communities surrounding the city, is one of three privately governed, independent secondary schools in Connecticut that primarily serves public school students. (The other two are Woodstock Academy in northeastern Connecticut and the Gilbert School, which serves students in Winchester and Hartland.)
Towns that send students to Norwich Free Academy pay the tuitions, but the school receives no public funds and must rely on private fund-raising and philanthropy to pay for capital projects. The school serves a 2,300-member student body, and its leaders say they have come to realize that fund-raising and development is going to be a long-term, large-scale commitment.
"The tuition pays for the students' education, but not the buildings," Dr. Bargnesi said.
The founders of the academy had lofty goals. In 1853, Dr. John P. Gulliver, a Norwich educator and pastor, outlined to community leaders his plan to establish a free academy to provide a secondary education to boys and girls of every socioeconomic class. 
"N.F.A. was founded on educational altruism," said Dr. David E. Oakley, a Norwich ophthalmologist and a member of the school's board of trustees. "It was founded to educate the sons and daughters of mill workers."
In the days leading up to the Civil War, Norwich was an economic powerhouse fueled by the textile industry; it was one of the wealthiest cities in New England.
The academy was established after 36 people contributed a total of $86,000. The school opened in 1856 on a 13-acre campus.
In the late 1980's, the school's trustees and administrators decided the school should dedicate more effort to development if it wanted to keep its gracious 19th-century buildings in shape, while also adding new buildings and equipment, Dr. Oakley said. 
"It grew out of the realization that to remain independent, we would need a source of income," he said.
What began as a modest effort to identify and locate alumni in an effort to raise money has grown to include a foundation office with five full-time employees, as well as the team of volunteer educational consultants.
The school now frequently sponsors alumni events in areas such as New York City, Washington and Florida, where concentrations of alumni live.
The development director of alumni fund-raising, Deborah J. Lee, said the school was also reaching out by publishing several publications, sponsoring events ranging from reunions and homecomings to black-tie cocktail receptions and family days, and providing distinguished alumni awards. 
"We have 28,000 reachable alumni," Ms. Lee said. "We are always making sure the alumni are communicated with."
Ms. Lee said the percentage of alumni who donated to the school runs slightly below national averages. While independent schools consider a 20 percent to 25 percent alumni giving rate as excellent, the national average is about 15 percent and the academy's rate is currently 13 percent, she said.
During the last school year, alumni contributed $251,000 to an annual appeal to pay for "extras," including guest speakers and computers. In a previous campaign, they contributed most of the $4 million needed to build a science center.
As for the current effort, the school would not say how much it had raised so far, saying it was still in the "silent phase" of the campaign, which has been going on for about a year. The school expects to kick off the public phase next spring.
"People give to what they love and they give to successes," Dr. Bargnesi said.
Last year, the school received Blue Ribbon status from the Federal Department of Education, a designation that recognizes high achieving schools, especially those serving a diverse population that includes minority and low-income students.
"Look at the record it has achieved in so many fields," Dr. Desrosier said. "And the museum; not even many colleges have a museum like that."
Ms. Lee said the academy is one of only two high schools in the nation to have an art museum on its campus. (The other is at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.)
"It's going to be a fun campaign," Dr. Desrosier said. "If you believe in what you ask people for, they'll support you."
Still, he and others at the academy say they know there are hurdles to surmount.
"They need to forget that word 'Free,"' Dr. Desrosier said of the word the academy's founders included in its name to refer to free access to education, not freedom from payment. "Sometimes, I regret that word's in there."

Far right, a view of the private school, which is seeking to raise funds for a new arts and music building and is largely attended by public school students. (Photographs by C.M. Glover for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
You Won't Hear a Refrain of 'All That Jazz'

BYLINE:  By ALLAN RICHTER

 BODY:
IN another blow to Long Island's jazz scene, the restaurant 69 Wall Street in Huntington has scaled back the weekend jazz shows it has been featuring on its second floor for the last year and a half. The restaurant is one of the few places on the Island where jazz can be heard in an intimate setting.
 The move comes as its owners try to combat the loss of business in a sour economy. Among the cost-saving measures, begun last month, are the suspension of Friday night performances and the cutting of band fees by $100, to $300, said Kelly Buffalino, who books groups for 69 Wall, which is owned by her husband, Chris. 
 Ms. Buffalino added that she will try to recruit more local musicians instead of pursuing the more expensive Manhattan-based bands. Saturday jazz performances will continue, as will 69 Wall's psychic and karaoke nights.
 Ms. Buffalino said that despite abolishing a $7 cover charge and advertising heavily in print and radio, 60 Wall was "really struggling to get the people in." She added: "We're waiting to see how the fall season transpires. If it gets busier, we might bring Fridays back, but at this point we're paying the bands out of our pockets totally."
 This is a familiar refrain to local jazz artists. Bob Hinz, a Huntington jazz pianist and teacher, recounted when one bookstore that used to feature jazz nights began paying musicians in gift certificates instead of cash.
 "You get kind of discouraged, and you realize that it's not that you're not making an effort," said Dr. Hinz, who has a Ph.D. in piano performance. "It's that there are no opportunities, not only because there aren't that many venues, but also because the venues that are around know jazz might not provide an audience." 
 Al Cardillo, a Mineola upright bass player, said he started a Sunday jazz brunch at the Papa-Razzi restaurant in Westbury in 1996. The restaurant added a Wednesday night jazz program in 1998.
 Then, the Sept. 11 attacks occurred. Shortly after that, Mr. Cardillo said, "Nobody wanted to go into Manhattan." He added, "My business tripled." But, the economy eventually took its toll, and the restaurant ended the program in 2001.
 Steve Adelson, a Long Beach jazz player, criticized local restaurants and clubs, saying they do not stick with the genre long enough.
 "It takes some money and advertising," he said. "If you have a bad week, you can't give it up. They try it because they think it's a cool thing to do, and after two or three weeks, they see economically it's not working out, and they go back to wet T-shirt night."
 But Ms. Buffalino of 69 Wall Street said her restaurant has stuck with its jazz program. She said demographics, not restaurateur commitment, was to blame.
 "Our crowd is middle-aged and usually have kids at home," she said. "They can't stay there till 2 in the morning," she said. "It's not like the city where people are out bar hopping." 
 At one time, the Island's jazz scene was livelier. At the heart of it was Sonny's Place in Seaford, which opened in 1972. The club is fondly recalled by many fans and musicians because it was devoted only to jazz and so could attract name acts like Count Basie or Sarah Vaughn. 
 But Mr. Meyerowitz became ill with cancer and closed his business in 1997; he died three years later. A few nightspots have featured jazz bands in the six years since Sonny's Place closed. But local musicians say none has managed to focus on jazz like Sonny's or replicate its familial atmosphere.
 Mr. Adelson, who plays a hybrid guitar and bass called a Chapman stick, and a group of Long Beach jazz lovers are hoping to rekindle an appreciation for the music with the first Long Beach Jazz Festival, which begins tomorrow. The festival will include films about jazz, including "Celebrating Bird: The Triumph of Charlie Parker," at the local library and performances by local and international players at area restaurants. The festival's Web site is www.longbeachjazzfest.com. 
 "It won't fill the gap in the sense that it's temporary," Mr. Adelson said, "but hopefully it will be an annual thing. We are putting 50 musicians to work."

HEADLINE: Poll Shows Support For Public Education 

BYLINE:  By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
LONG Islanders support public education and want more options for early childhood learning and after-school programs in Nassau and Suffolk counties, according to an opinion poll released Thursday by the Rauch Foundation.
 The poll, "Caring for Long Island's Children," surveyed 1,500 Long Islanders on their attitudes about children, family, education and community. The results showed that the agenda of Long Island families is dominated by education, balancing work and family needs and economic security. 
 Comparison interviews were conducted with 600 New York City residents, 300 from the New Jersey suburbs and 400 from northern suburbs in New York. Rauch is a family foundation based in Garden City that is active in Long Island affairs. CharneyResearch, a New York polling firm, conducted the survey. 
 "Results of the survey demonstrated that despite concerns about fiscal issues, Long Islanders are cautiously optimistic and committed to preserving the high-quality public education for which Long Island has become known," Phillip Sparks, a spokesman for the Rauch Foundation, said. "If given the choice of budget cuts in their local school districts that would mean larger class size and teacher layoffs or a tax increase, they opted for higher taxes, by a 19 percent margin."
 Dr. James Hunderfund, president of the Suffolk County School Superintendents Association, said he was not surprised by the survey results.
 "This attitude was reflected in June, in the resounding passage of school budgets by local communities," he said. "Voters supported higher budgets and tax rates because they are responsive to the needs of their children and appreciate the continued improvement of achievement levels in their communities."
 Compared with the other areas polled, Long Islanders were more positive about their children growing up in this region, largely because of the schools. Among a cross section of every racial, income and social group surveyed, 68 percent of Long Islanders felt that growing up there gives children an advantage, compared with 49 percent in New York City, 64 percent in the northern suburbs and 61 percent in New Jersey.
 Long Island was also the region in the metropolitan area most satisfied with the performance of its public schools. Among Long Islanders polled, 77 percent said they were satisfied with the quality of public education in their area, slightly higher than the satisfaction rate in the northern suburbs (71 percent) and New Jersey (70 percent). In New York City, 55 percent said they were satisfied with the public schools.
 Dr. Charles Fowler, president of the Nassau County School Superintendents Association, said that the commitment to education correlated with a high level of participation among the residents of a community and that is high on Long Island. 
 "Long Island residents are typically more successful and more highly educated than in other parts of the country, and we recognize the importance of education in our lives and for our children," he said.
 While the general view of Long Island schools was positive, low-income and minority parents said they were concerned about the quality of education their children received. The poll found the highest levels of discontent among two groups: blacks of all income categories and residents earning less than $20,000.
 Long Island parents are also concerned about the choices they must make between work and family, the survey concluded. Half of Long Island mothers work full time, with 70 percent of those working women having children under 18 and 30 percent with children under 5.
 Long Islanders with children want more support, more help choosing programs and developing parenting strategies, and more policies that provide greater flexibility regarding work time, the survey shows. 
 The responses confirmed the need for more options for preschool-age children and after-school programs, said Ellen Galinsky, president of the Families and Work Institute, a nonprofit research and planning organization based in New York. 
 "The poll is very promising because it shows that Long Islanders understand the important connection between school readiness and later school success," she said.
 According to the 2000 Census, 365,000 households on Long Island have children, with 78,000 preschoolers and 520,000 children enrolled in elementary and secondary schools. 
 This survey, focusing on issues facing Long Island's children and educational systems, was the second in a series of three commissioned last year by the Rauch Foundation. 
 The first survey, completed last December, addressed the perceptions of Long Island's identity, quality of life, environment and transportation system. The final survey, to be conducted this fall, will explore issues related to economic and work-force development. 
 The newest survey had many positive findings but also showed serious concerns among Long Islanders, Mr. Sparks said.
 "While it found that local schools are the pride of Long Island and Long Islanders are hopeful about the future of their children growing up here," he said, "it also found that there is still an unmet demand for a coordinated system of quality early childhood learning programs and after-school care on Long Island."

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK; 
For $1,500 Retainer, the Doctor Will See You Now

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
AFTER building his medical practice to nearly 4,000 patients over 18 years, Dr. Nick Fitterman, an internist in Huntington, has decided to start scaling back. Last month, he made the formal transition, and on Sept. 1, he began seeing only those patients who paid a $1,500 annual retainer.
 Four hundred patients have signed up, forgoing the usual insurance reimbursements but becoming what Dr. Fitterman calls "participants in a long-term wellness plan." The patients can have unlimited appointments at no additional cost, same-day or next-day appointments and what his brochure calls "unhurried" visits. Dr. Fitterman also promises he will keep his beeper on and answer phone calls around the clock, seven days a week. He has even begun making house calls again. 
 Dr. Fitterman employs three other doctors at his practice, on New York Avenue, and they continue to see patients -- including many of Dr. Fitterman's former patients -- under the usual insurance reimbursement arrangements. 
 Dr. Fitterman, who said he changed his practice to provide better care for his patients, is one of two Long Island physicians adopting what is sometimes called "boutique" or "concierge" medicine. The other is Dr. Steven R. Goldfarb, an internist in Southampton, who is scheduled to convert his practice on Tuesday. Both men have signed agreements with a medical practice consulting company in Boca Raton, Fla., called MDVIP, which has provided guidance, data and technical support for their transitions. Darin Engelhardt, the general counsel and chief financial officer for MDVIP, said that some 140 doctors have converted their practices, about 30 of them affiliated with MDVIP. 
 He said the company believes the time is right to expand its network. "Primary-care physicians are under tremendous constraint in their ability to deliver comprehensive preventive care," he said. "The current health-care environment is one in which physicians are facing continuously declining reimbursements from insurance and Medicare, and that has unfortunately led to an increase in the number of patients physicians must see for economic reasons."
 MDVIP allows doctors to distance themselves from insurance bureaucracies and set up less pressured schedules while maintaining substantial incomes. In return for its advice, MDVIP collects a third of the doctors' retainer fees. 
 On average, only one out of every five patients will decide to make the transition to a new retainer arrangement, but many will stay with the practice itself, seeing a different doctor, Mr. Engelhardt said. He said a doctor with a caseload of 3,000 patients, an average number, could expect a retainer base of about 600 patients.
 A retainer of $1,500 per patient would bring in a total of $900,000 a year. Salaries for doctors in retainer practices range from $200,000 to $250,000, Mr. Engelhardt said. By comparison, family practitioners earned less than $136,000 in 2001, according to the American Association of Family Practitioners.
 But neither of the two Long Island doctors who are converting their practices named money as their motivation. Dr. Fitterman said: "The quality of medicine is suffering in this country because what we're doing here isn't right. We're all trying to see more people in less time."
 He cited his own professional dissatisfaction, and the dissatisfaction his patients expressed in a survey last year, as his motivation. His patients complained, he said, about waiting too long for appointments and about delays in the waiting room.
 Dr. Goldfarb said he began thinking about converting his practice five years ago because he felt squeezed out of the health-care decision-making process. "Unlike other professionals, we are in a business over which we have no control over fees," he said, referring to the insurance companies and government agencies that reimburse for medical services. "Decisions are made for us by powers greater than us." 
 But a retainer practice changes that. "This model allows me to give patients more time without losing money," he said.
 Retainer practices usually emphasize wellness and preventive medicine. Dr. Fitterman now spends most of his time administering annual physicals and discussing the results with patients. "The discussions are very intensive," he said. "I schedule them for an hour, but some last an hour and a half."
 Dr. Goldfarb, who plans to phase his new practice, said that analyzing the results of the physical and helping patients develop priorities and goals formed the core of his philosophy.
 In addition to taking detailed medical histories, he said, he also emphasizes nutrition, exercise and what he called "prophylactic medicine." 
 Some critics contend that an emphasis on annual physical exams is misguided. Since 1989, the federal Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, part of the Department of Health and Human Services, has issued a series of reports questioning the validity of annual check-ups. The reports warned that exams sometimes produced false alarms, subjecting healthy patients to unnecessary tests and discomfort.
 Dr. Goldfarb said he thought the annual check-up was a good idea. "The value of the annual exam may be not be tangible in the sense of 'We're going to find it before you get it,"' he said, meaning discovering a problem before symptoms appear. "But the relationship you as a doctor create with your patient is worth it on a variety of levels."
 Patients follow a doctor's advice more closely, Dr. Goldfarb said, when they see him taking a personal interest in their health.
 The prospect of the spread of retainer practices has raised concerns at groups like the American Medical Association. On June 17, the A.M.A. established new ethical guidelines on the subject.
 "A retainer contract is not to be promoted as a promise for more or better diagnostic and therapeutic services," the organization said.
 Robert McMillan, an A.M.A. trustee who is a partner in the Melville law firm of Fischbein Badillo Wagner Harding, said, "The ethical requirement is that all patients be given the same level of care" regardless of the payment plan. 
 Dr. James Martin, the president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, said: "The academy has great concern that a more universal acceptance of this type of practice will result in various levels of health care. Our current dysfunctional system relies on cost sharing and cost shifting to provide even the poorly distributed care we offer now."
 Dr. Martin said retainer medicine does fix a major problem in the current system of health-care financing by paying doctors for the time they spend coordinating care and conferring with patients. Currently, doctors are paid only for the procedures they perform, Dr. Martin said.
 The underlying issue, said Dr. Jon Cohen, the chief medical officer for the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, is the country's ambivalence about health-care entitlement. "The American public believes it's a right," he said, "but our economic system treats it as a privilege."

He has even begun making house calls again, like this one to Rita Lo Russo in Northport. Her husband, Joseph, is seated behind her. (Photo by Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Treasures in the Attic 

BYLINE:  By BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

 BODY:
IT is the end of summer, and New Jersey's museums are gearing up for their big fall shows. There is much to look forward to, but also evidence of the challenges facing museums, with a weak economy, state budget cuts to the arts, and a decline in private contributions. 
 Over the last year, museums in New Jersey have been forced to trim curatorial projects and touring shows. To get through these tough times, many have dipped into the storeroom and assembled shows from their collections. This way they do not pay for shipping and insurance, nor do they have to print catalogs or conduct new scholarship. 
 Collection shows have their virtues. They provide an opportunity to dust off neglected works in storage or explore offbeat themes and subjects. The collection offerings in the museums this fall should excite art fans with eclectic tastes, for languishing in storerooms around the state are treasures large and small, some of which have never seen the light of day. 
 On the schedule are shows of rarely seen artifacts, of recent museum gifts or things presented as gifts in the past and brought out again for another look, and of objects held in sufficient density to warrant attention. In some cases, the curators are trying to say something new.
 If one collection-based show stands out, it is "The Centaur's Smile: The Human Animal in Early Greek Art" at the Princeton University Art Museum. This scholarly exhibition looks at fantastic imagery of humanoid creatures in early Greek art, and is the first exhibition in the United States to focus on this theme. 
 Among touring shows from other museums, the pick of the season is the George Tice retrospective at the New Jersey State Museum. This exhibition spans Mr. Tice's photographic career from the 1960's to the present, giving ample evidence as to why he is widely regarded as among the best photographers of his generation. 
 Meanwhile, many museums are presenting exhibitions to appeal to diverse audiences, or that have a strong educational focus; some, like the Newark Museum, even have shows designed especially for children. This is all good.
 Here is a sampling of what is in store for art lovers this season.

Princeton Art Museum
 Meticulously researched by J. Michael Padgett, curator of ancient art at the museum, "The Centaur's Smile," opening on Oct. 11, features 100 objects in various media. About a quarter come from Princeton's collection, with the rest on loan from public and private collections in France, the United States and Spain.
 Among the booty is a geometric-style bronze of a warrior battling a centaur, from New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, and, from the Bibliotheque National in Paris, an ancient bronze centaur statuette found on the Athenian acropolis in the 19th century. If this is not to taste, then try the engraved gems in rock crystal, jasper and cornelian, or jewelry and metalwork in gold, silver and electrum.

Jersey City Museum
 This museum is the most dynamic contemporary art site in New Jersey. Although its state financing has been cut, and sponsors are scarce, the organizers have still pulled together a mid-career retrospective of the Newark-born and -raised African-American artist Chakaia Booker. Ms. Booker's casual assemblages of twisted, coiling and sometimes painted old tires have much to say about the world in which she grew up. The show opens on Jan. 14.
 The museum has just installed two delicate yet powerful wall drawings by the young Mexican, now Brooklyn-based, artist known as Vargas-Suarez Universal. One piece consists of webby, linear abstractions in red and blue enamel paint, while the other, in permanent marker, references the architectural history of Jersey City. The latter is the museum's first semi-permanent installation in its new Montgomery Street home.

The Newark Museum
 This museum consistently presents exemplary historical shows with a strong educational focus. This fall it is dusting off its numismatic collection for "Once Upon a Dime: The World of Money," an interactive exhibition aimed at children, and opening on Oct. 4. On view are various forms of currency from Africa, China, America, India, and the islands in the South Pacific. 
 Also this fall, 36 quilts from the museum's nationally known collection will be unpacked for "Quilt Masterpieces: From Folk Art to Fine Art." The show, opening on Oct. 17, explores the evolution of quilt making from a domestic activity to one of America's great indigenous folk art forms. As a special addition to the exhibition, an extraordinary modern album quilt by 14 Holocaust survivors has been borrowed from the Jewish Family Service of MetroWest. It will hang in the museum's south wing.

Montclair Art Museum
 Things are more playful over here, where "Connecting Generations: Contemporary American Indian Dolls" explores doll making in modern Native American tribal societies. The exhibition features about 20 dolls from private collections nationwide, with works by Native American artists like s Joyce and Juanita Growing Thunder Fogarty, Rhonda Holy Bear and Jamie Okuma.Alongside this show, the museum will present works from its collection that explore images of children from the 19th century to the present. Among the pieces in the show, "Growing Up: Childhood in American and Native American Art," are some spooky photographs of Native American children by Carl Moon, Winslow Homer's charming wood engravings of children, and contemporary works by Romare Bearden, Faith Ringgold and Janet Taylor Pickett. 
 Both shows open next Sunday.

New Jersey State Museum
 If you missed the much-lauded Tice retrospective at New York's International Center for Photography last year, you are in luck, for it is coming to Trenton. Opening on Oct. 4, "George Tice: Urban Landscapes" presents a selection of Mr. Tice's disquieting black-and-white photographs of New Jersey's suburban and industrial landscapes from the late 1960's to the present. Viewed together, the works amount to one of the most significant and moving photographic studies of place in modern America.

Zimmerli Art Museum
 Like Princeton, the Zimmerli, at Rutgers in New Brunswick, has extensive collections of paintings, sculpture and works on paper. Particularly rich are its reserves of Russian and Soviet era art, which have been tapped for "Soviet Artists, Jewish Imagery: Selections from the Norton and Nancy Dodge Collection of Soviet Non-Conformist Art." The show, which just opened, features a little over 40 works by Jewish artists active in the Russian avant-garde art scene last century. 
 Opening today, the Zimmerli has redeemed around 60 pieces of its American sculpture collection, a few of which have never been shown. In spite of its sleeping pill title, "American Sculpture from the Zimmerli Collection," the show includes important works by Janet Scudder, Herbert Ferber, Leo Amino, Louise Nevelson, Claes Oldenburg, Chaim Gross and George Segal. With this lineup, it will be hard to go wrong.

On the Walls
Here are the telephone numbers and Web addresses for the museums mentioned in the article on the new season:
 Princeton University Art Museum, (609)258-3788, www.princetonartmuseum.org
 Jersey City Museum, (201)413-0303, www.jerseycitymuseum.org
 The Newark Museum, (973)596-6550, www.newarkmuseum.org
 Montclair Art Museum, (973)746-5555, www.montclairartmuseum.org
 New Jersey State Museum, (609)292-6464, www.newjerseystatemuseum.org
 Jane Vorhees Zimmerli Art Museum, (732)932-7237, www.zimmerlimuseum.rutgers.edu

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
A Sense of Optimism In the State's Theaters

BYLINE:  By NEIL GENZLINGER

 BODY:
IF there is a bit more buzz in New Jersey's theatrical air as the fall season begins, it is because there is a lot to anticipate.
 In Princeton, the McCarter's second theater opens this week with Nilo Cruz's "Anna in the Tropics," the play that won this year's Pulitzer Prize for drama without having had a New York-area production. At the Paper Mill in Millburn, Michael Gennaro settles in for his first full season as president and chief executive, having taken over that job in April. 
 Meanwhile, several theaters are trying interesting collaborations, and the Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick, which went dark three years ago and flickered back to life with a limited season last year, is planning four shows. 
Beyond these individual storylines, the season may well be defined by how the theaters collectively regroup after months of preoccupation with a threatened cut in state support.
 When Governor McGreevey proposed eliminating state financing for the arts in February, theaters responded with a lobbying effort that included pre-curtain pleas to audiences, fliers inside programs and celebrity-studded rallies. Financing was partly restored with a hotel and motel tax, but the theaters were left newly appreciative of their vulnerability.
 Now, the theaters seem both encouraged by the show of public support and determined to make sure that support is as broad-based as it can be. 
 "The general feeling is optimistic," said Stephen Fredericks, president of the New Jersey Theater Alliance, a trade group, and executive director of Growing Stage, the lively children's theater in Netcong. But, Mr. Fredericks added, everyone is conscious that the budget situation has not been resolved, and they are considering new ways to find audiences.
 "The reality of when this fight 'will come again' is already here," he said, noting that the new tax is not yet linked to arts financing by constitutional amendment. "If you could even entertain the concept to eliminate, how can anyone not believe that in an even more difficult state economy, as is already being discussed, those funds would not be diverted to another sector of our society?"
 Ultimately, the plays remain the thing. All eyes will certainly be on the McCarter Theater Center this week when the new 360-seat Roger B. Berlind Theater opens with the Cruz play, a portrait of Spanish-Cubans in Florida in 1929, set in a cigar factory. Next year brings what promises to be an intimate "My Fair Lady," a play whose inspiration, "Pygmalion," is now at the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey. 
 The McCarter main stage offers Charles L. Mee's "Wintertime," a co-production with Second Stage in New York. Performances begin on Oct. 14. 
 The leadership change at the Paper Mill came with much talk about whether the theater's tastes would change, but in the selection of shows, the coming season, scheduled before Mr. Gennaro's arrival, stays firmly in the mainstream. "Ain't Misbehavin," the Fats Waller revue, starts things off this week, followed by "The Sound of Music" on Oct. 29.
 The George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick has back-to-back world premieres: "Wilderness of Mirrors" by Charles Evered, about the founding of the C.I.A., opening on Sept. 12, and "Attacks on the Heart" by Arthur Laurents, opening on Oct. 17, about a love affair between a Turkish woman and an American man set against the backdrop of the Sept. 11 attacks.
 The latest reincarnation of the nearby Crossroads, which involves a partnership with the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, includes a revival in December of "The Late Great Ladies of Blues and Jazz," a one-woman musical, and then, in February, a storytelling show featuring Ossie Davis.
 As always, some of the most ambitious work will be at the state's smaller theaters. For example, Passage Theater Company in Trenton is offering "Afghan Women" by William Mastrosimone, about an Afghan-American woman who returns to her homeland to work at an orphanage. Performances begin on Oct. 9.
 Mr. Mastrosimone, a Trenton native, wrote the one-act "Bang Bang, You're Dead," which is about a school shooting and has been performed thousands of times by student actors across the country. 
 The Bickford Theater at the Morris Museum in Morristown offers "Barrymore" on Sept. 26 and "Educating Rita" on Dec. 12. Its most intriguing entry may be "Defying Gravity" by Jane Anderson, scheduled for February. The play, over years old, is about the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, yet could have new resonance because of the more recent shuttle disaster.
 At 12 Miles West Theater Company in Montclair, a lot of comedy is in the offing, including the New Jersey premiere of Nicky Silver's "Fit to Be Tied," opening in January. On the coast, Two River Theater Company in Manasquan is beginning its season on Oct. 2 with a 90-minute adaptation of Bizet's "Tragedy of Carmen." Mamet, Strindberg and Mike Leigh are on the schedule for next year.
 On Oct. 9, New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch is offering the world premiere of "The Good Daughter" by D.W. Gregory, whose drama "Radium Girls" was well received several years ago in its premiere at Playwrights Theater of New Jersey in Madison.
 New Jersey Rep is finishing up a run of "Spain" by Jim Knable, which then transfers to Playwrights, part of an effort by the groups to bring new works to a broader audience.
 At Cape May Stage, the Halloween season will bring "Poe, Deep Into That Darkness Peering." Also in Cape May, the East Lynne Theater Company offers "Tales by Twain," a world premiere based on Twain's writings. Both plays begin performances on Oct. 1.
 Plenty of children's theater is scheduled. At the Forum Theater Company in Metuchen, practically any children's character you can name will make an appearance -- from Snow White to the Velveteen Rabbit -- but the high point may be a Singalong "Wizard of Oz" in March. 
 Growing Stage Theater has the likes of "Harriet the Spy," starting on Sept. 26, and "The Chronicles of Narnia," on Nov. 28. Also, keep an eye out next year for "A Boy Named Cinder."
