HEADLINE: A Battle for Turf Where Threatened Grizzlies Still Roam 

BYLINE:  By JIM ROBBINS

DATELINE: NOXON, Mont. 

 BODY:
Before the Europeans came to North America, the grizzly bear reigned, hunting the plains as far east as Minnesota, south to the deserts of Mexico and along the salmon-choked rivers of the Pacific Coast.
 Two centuries of settlement beat them back, and now just two main populations remain outside of Alaska -- one with 400 to 600 bears in and around Glacier National Park, the other in Yellowstone, with 500 to 600 bears. They are designated as threatened under the Endangered Species Act, but many biologists consider their population levels healthy. 
 Three tiny populations, however, were stranded in the retreat and cut off almost entirely by roads, reservoirs and other development.
Some experts say recent decisions and inaction by federal agencies may doom the most precarious of those, the 15 or so bears of the Cabinet Mountain group north of this small mountain town on the border with northern Idaho. 
A major potential threat, they say, is a copper and silver mine that is planned in the bears' remaining habitat. Nine environmental groups filed a lawsuit in federal court in July to overturn approval for the mine given by the Kootenai National Forest. The federal Fish and Wildlife Service signed off on the mine, saying it would not harm the bears.
Environmentalists say the mine is only the latest action by federal agencies in recent years to jeopardize the bears' survival, prompting speculation that the federal government may be writing off the marooned population.
"It's the dirty little secret of grizzly bear recovery," said Louisa Willcox, director of the Wild Bears Project for the Natural Resources Defense Council, in Livingston, Mont. "They are letting them quietly go extinct."
Fish and Wildlife Service officials dispute that notion, arguing that they have programs to put in place to protect the bears as long as certain budget items are approved.
Some officials claim that the mine, with an estimated cost of $200 million, may not be built for economic reasons, but mining officials say their plans will move forward.
Even if the mine is never built, there are so few bears here that their survival is uncertain, experts say.
Dr. David Mattson, a wildlife biologist with the United States Geological Survey in Flagstaff, Ariz., and a colleague modeled the population trends of the Cabinet Mountain bears and the adjacent but distinct Yaak Mountain population to the north with some 15 to 20 bears.
The bears' decline is caused by an increase in human population in the region, he said, which hastwo main effects. If the human population continues to grow at the rate it has, the number of bear deaths is expected to increase as a result, Dr. Mattson said. "That means they won't be reproducing faster than they are dying, and they will disappear within 20 years," he added.
These isolated bears are especially vulnerable for other reasons, Dr. Mattson said. Climate change may contribute to the decline of the white bark pine nut, a critical source of food, as it has for the Yellowstone grizzlies. If something similar happens in the Cabinet Mountains, the bears may need to move to find food. "If there is an isolated population with a human fence around them and they can't move, they can't survive," Dr. Mattson said.
Mortality among the Cabinet- Yaak bears has been unusually high in the past four years. Of 30 adult bears, 14 have died, 9 from natural causes, mostly in the Yaak. The other five were killed by humans under different circumstances.
Although the Yaak bears may benefit from their connection to Canadian populations, Cabinet bears probably will not. The ranges are adjacent, but there has been no known movement between the groups, largely because of a highway, railroad and river separating them.
Michael Proctor, a Canadian biologist, recently studied the DNA of bears in Canada and in the isolated populations in the United States and found little movement across Highway 3 and into the United States. A few do make the journey, however, and experts are working on ways to encourage more to do so.
The other isolated populations are in the North Cascades in Washington with as few as half a dozen bears and in the Selkirk Mountains in the panhandle of Idaho. The two groups straddle the United States-Canadian border. The American side of the Selkirks has 15 to 30 bears, but the population is roughly doubled when Canada is included. 
While those numbers are still precarious, Wayne Wakkinen, senior wildlife research biologist for the Idaho Department of Fish and Game, said the Selkirk population seemed to be expanding. "They have been isolated for the short term," he said, "but as we see an increase in population we might get over that" as they seek new habitat and encounter bears from other ecosystems.
Environmentalists say that prospect is excessively rosy. They point to the refusal of the Fish and Wildlife Service to elevate the bears from threatened to endangered, for example. While federal officials acknowledge the numbers warrant such a listing, they cite a limited budget and contend that endangered status will still not offer greater protection. 
The Fish and Wildlife Service also ended a long-term program begun in 1994 to bring in more female bears to supplement the population because of opposition from local residents.
Reducing bear deaths caused by humans has not been a priority in the Cabinets, Ms. Willcox of the Wild Bears Project said. "We know how to do this," she said. "This is basic simple stuff that was done in Yellowstone." Using bear-proof garbage containers, ending black bear hunting and increasing law enforcement will reduce their death rate, she said. 
Dr. Chris Servheen, the grizzly bear recovery coordinator for the Fish and Wildlife Service in Missoula, agrees that more protective measures should be taken. "We're very concerned about the Cabinet bears and always have been," he said. Claims that they are being ignored are nonsense, he added.
This fall, if the budget permits, the agency plans to improve protection, adding bear-proof garbage cans and offering education for hunters, among other projects. Eventually more bears are to be brought in. "The tools are in the toolbox," Dr. Servheen said.
He also noted that the Forest Service would require Sterling Resources of Spokane, Wash., the mine's owners, to provide long-term protection of 2,000 other acres for the bear, and to shut down some roads in the area. The company is also to pay for a full-time officer and a bear management specialist to decrease deaths.
If they do all that, Dr. Servheen said, the mine will have a limited effect on the bear.
The mine is to be built on 1,560 acres of publicly owned forest on the western edge of the Cabinet Mountain Wilderness. Some 700 workers will be brought in to extract 10,000 tons of ore per day. It is expected to affect nearly 500 acres, with waste disposal and a mill site to process the ore, and will require nine miles of new roads and road reconstruction.
Officials say they have no choice but to allow the mine, under the General Mining Law of 1872, long a bane of environmentalists. Passed to help settle the West, the law gives private companies publicly owned minerals at no charge. The government receives no royalties. 
Dr. Servheen and others say there are doubts that the mine will go forward because of costs. Noranda Inc., which had planned to open a similar mine nearby, recently abandoned its proposal.
But Frank Duvall, the chief executive of the Sterling Mining Company of Montana, the owner of the mine known as Rock Creek, said it "could be economic at today's prices."
The larger battle in protecting the grizzly is how to keep the separate populations viable. Rather than trying to protect bears in "postage stamp" ecosystems, many experts say the remaining habitats, including those in Canada, should be linked so that bears can move freely, providing additional protections.
If the Cabinet Mountain bears decline or disappear, for example, bears from other ecosystems are able to move in. "They're better equipped to ride out the local disturbances," he said.

HEADLINE: AN UPDATE; 
At Last, a Clean Street, if Not a Clean Slate

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
After a long day going door to door in Queens selling cable television services, Derrick Kallicharran looks forward to coming home to the tranquil embrace of family and friends. 
 But as he bounds up the front stairs, he usually feels just a hint of tension -- the fear that he will find a sanitation summons tucked into the doorjamb, as he did a year ago. 
 "I've been cleaning my driveway and in front of my yard every day," he said. "I don't want to get another summons." 
In an earlier article in this series, which looks at how the people who live, work and do business on a single block are coping with New York's economic straits, Mr. Kallicharran expressed frustration at having to pay a $50 fine because a sanitation inspector found a candy wrapper and a few pieces of paper in front of his house while he was at work. 
At the same time, garbage was piling up in prodigious heaps along practically the length of 94th Avenue, where a factory that Mr. Kallicharran can see from his front steps has stood vacant for several years because the city's budget problems delayed construction of a high school at the site. 
On the day that the article appeared last month, a city sanitation crew swept down 94th and removed all the trash, including an old trailer in which a homeless person had occasionally been sleeping. 
While Mr. Kallicharran was glad the city had finally gotten around to cleaning the street, he was infuriated that it had not acted until the article was published. 
"It shows that if they want to do something good instead of going to innocent people and giving innocent people tickets, they can," he said. "But if they don't do their part and they expect everybody else to do theirs, it doesn't work."
The sudden cleanup was initiated by the mayor's Community Assistance Unit, which brings community issues to his attention. Jonathan Greenspun, commissioner of the unit, said he agreed it was unfortunate that the neighborhood had to put up with the trash for so long. 
"I share in their frustration," he said, "but what I would recommend is for them to recognize the fact that once the city is made aware of problems, we do our very best to go ahead and clean them up." 
After the trailer was towed away and the street swept clean, Mr. Greenspun's office had the ground floor of the factory painted to cover graffiti. At the same time, members of a demolition crew were removing asbestos from the upper floors as they prepared to take down the 80-year-old building. City officials said the building should be demolished by the end of the year so construction can begin on the High School of Architecture and Urban Planning, at least two years behind schedule. 
Mr. Kallicharran said it was a waste of money for the city to paint part of a building being torn down, especially during a budget crisis in which his property taxes had jumped 18.5 percent and the sales tax was increased and extended to the clothing he buys for his family. 
Mr. Greenspun disagreed. "Even if the new paint is there for only two days before the building is torn down, I don't think it's a waste of city resources at all," he said. "It demonstrates our willingness to respond to problems." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Derrick Kallicharran was frustrated at being fined over a wrapper and a few pieces of paper in front of his house. (Photo by Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nizhny Novgorod Journal; 
Men Marry, With and Without a Church Blessing

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: NIZHNY NOVGOROD, Russia, Sept. 5 

 BODY:
Standing at solemn attention with embroidered bridal crowns on their heads, two young men were married here this week by a Russian Orthodox priest, defying both religious and state law in this conservative country.
 Nothing like this had happened in the church's 1,000-year history, said a spokesman for the Moscow Patriarchate, Viktor Malukhin, and it was blasphemy. 
 Newspapers and television reported the event with bemusement. Homosexuality is legal in Russia, but it is mostly hidden, little understood and generally condemned. 
Russian civil law does not recognize same-sex marriage, and the two men were turned away when they tried later to register their union at a government office. The issue is not a subject of debate here as it is in the United States and Canada.
Church officials immediately suspended the priest and issued a statement condemning homosexuality as a mortal sin.
"Under no circumstances can this be considered a church marriage," said Mr. Malukhin, who is deputy director of communications for the patriarchate, in a telephone interview. "The church still views a marriage blessed by God to be a union between a man and a woman."
Before going into seclusion, the priest who performed the ceremony, the Rev. Vladimir of Rozhdenstvensky church, spoke to a local reporter. The priest denied that he had performed a wedding ceremony when he went to a small, empty church with Denis Gogolev, 26, and Mikhail Morozov, 24. 
However, photographs taken by a friend who went with them show the priest blessing the couple, placing the crowns on their heads, slipping a ring onto one of their hands and leading them in a ritual procession in what appears to be an Orthodox wedding ceremony.
Mr. Gogolev, a former military officer with a degree in economics, said he had bribed the priest to perform the clandestine ceremony. The priest muttered, "How shameful" just before he performed the ceremony, Mr. Gogolev said.
"This isn't a joke," he said, pacing his apartment in agitation as he spoke. "This wasn't a registry office, this was the house of God. Open any Bible and there's nothing in there about gender in marriage, only love. I spit on the church when it says our marriage is not valid."
With homosexuality rarely spoken of except in jokes, news of the wedding seemed to cause astonishment and nervousness among some people.
"Well, I'll be darned," said a chauffeur named Slava. "That one's hard to get your mind around. You never know what's coming next."
Another chauffeur, named Oleg, exclaimed: "My goodness, a man kissing a man. What if they've both been smoking? What's that like?"
Most Russian homosexuals hide their sexual identity, and the men's announcement of their wedding on Monday in this ancient city 250 miles east of Moscow was an unusual public assertion of gay rights.
They had already been in the news, though, after Mr. Morozov was accepted as a contestant in the Miss Nizhny Novgorod beauty pageant in June.
Government officials were aghast, and Mr. Morozov was quickly removed from the list of contestants. In a television interview, though, the contest organizer, Dana Borisova, said, "If he changes his sex he can compete next year, because he's a truly beautiful boy."
Since then the two men have appeared on Russian MTV and two talk shows that are pitched to a more tolerant urban youth culture that has been emerging in recent years. This is also the audience for a pop duo called Tatu that has drawn attention with affectations of lesbianism.
But there is even less public understanding of lesbianism than of male homosexuality in Russia, and researchers say many lesbians in this country suffer in ignorance and loneliness.
When Yevgeniya E. Debryanskaya, manager of the gay club 12 Volt in Moscow, was asked whether she was agitating for gay rights, she answered: "No. Russia is not ready for that yet."
When Mr. Gogolev was asked if he met with abuse for his open homosexuality, he said: "Of course. This is Russia."
He did not disclose his homosexuality to his family until he was 20, he said.
"My mother cried and said, 'I love you,' " he said. "My father, after cursing at me, said, 'Don't let anybody know about this.' "
Feeling angry and rejected, he left home to make his own way in the world. "I wanted to prove to my parents that I am a real person," he said. 
Nevertheless, the status of homosexuals has improved in Russia after decades of enforced silence and criminal prosecution.
Among other things, the glasnost -- or openness -- of the last Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, opened the way for public discussion of homosexuality by scientists and journalists at the end of the 1980's.
With the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991, a gay rights movement gained momentum and lobbying groups and gay publications appeared. There is now a small gay subculture in major cities.
In 1993, during a period of nationwide liberalization, homosexuality was decriminalized. But there is a movement in Parliament to restore the criminal penalties, with its supporters fueling their effort with long-held stereotypes.
Gennady Raikov, an author of the proposed law, said it was easy to identify gay men because they speak in high voices. Anti-gay leaflets distributed in Nizhny Novgorod say homosexuals stand out because of their long hair, earrings and behavior.
"Dirt, perversion, stockings and lipstick" is the way Mr. Gogolev characterized the public portrayal of gay men.
"On television," he said, "you won't find your good homosexuals, your attractive homosexuals, your pure homosexuals, your articulate homosexuals. And I would like to add, we are happy homosexuals."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mikhail Morozov, right, and Denis Gogolev were married by a Russian Orthodox priest on Sept. 1 in a clandestine ceremony in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia. Church officials immediately suspended the priest. (Photo by Maria Bulgakova/Komsomolskaya Pravda, via Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Increased by $6 Billion in July 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Consumer debt expanded in July as Americans took out loans to buy more cars, Federal Reserve statistics showed yesterday.
 Borrowing through credit cards, auto loans and other personal debt not secured by real estate increased 4.1 percent, or $6 billion, to $1.77 trillion, the Fed said. 
In June, consumer credit increased by a revised $151.3 million, or 0.1 percent. 
 Consumer spending increased in July even as the economy lost 49,000 jobs. Household purchases, which account for 70 percent of the economy, rose at the fastest pace in four months, led by an increase in sales of cars and other durable goods, the Commerce Department reported earlier.
"If the economy were just made up of consumer expenditures, we could say there has been a full recovery from recession," Chris Rupkey, an economist at the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York, said before the report was released.
Economists expected a $5 billion rise in debt in July. The Fed revised its initial June estimate of a $400 million decline. Revolving credit, which includes credit cards, rose 0.5 percent, or $327.1 million, in July to $726.9 billion, after falling $1.27 billion in June.
Nonrevolving loans for vehicles and mobile homes, which make up almost two-thirds of household nonmortgage debt, jumped 6.6 percent, or $5.7 billion in July, to $1.047 trillion, after rising $1.4 billion in June.
In the first quarter, mortgage and home equity debt totaled $6.219 trillion, up 2.8 percent from the final three months of 2002, the Fed reported earlier. 
After reaching a record in late May, applications to refinance fell 32 percent in July from June, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. Cash from home equity tapped in loan refinancing has helped fuel the economy.

HEADLINE: Quirky Runway Hits Signal a Mood Swing 

BYLINE:  By RUTH LA FERLA

 BODY:
A dozen years ago, Karen Gates dressed to project the kind of muted authority she felt fitted her status as a public relations consultant for the tourism industry. "It was really about keeping up with what you thought was classic -- the Armanis and Chanels," she said. "You spent a lot of money but you didn't have a lot of fun."
 Now in her 50's and retired, Ms. Gates has released her inner Eloise. For fall she invested in items that make her feel adventurous and giddy, shopping to please only herself. Her choices included a Junya Watanabe jacket that is a quirky takeoff on Chanel, its bodice trailing fraying threads. "If I'm going to spend money in an economy that's tight I'm going to buy something that makes me feel good," said Ms. Gates, of New York, "and, definitely, that is not a basic." 
 Marilyn Garcia, who assists her husband in his Miami dental practice, has a closet filled with the requisite trophies from Prada and Gucci. This year Ms. Garcia, 42, opted for the unpredictable -- "pieces not so common, that make more of a statement," she said. Among them is a snug ruffled jacket by Jiwon Park, its price $1,500. The cost was not prohibitive, Ms. Garcia explained, because over all she has spent more judiciously, buying just two or three key items to see her through the season. "I don't have to have everything," she said, "and I know a lot of people in the same frame of mind." 
Her mood, like that of Ms. Gates, appears to reflect a shift in mind-set among the most eager consumers of high fashion, small in numbers but large in influence, since their purchasing habits help determine which looks will seep into the mainstream in the coming months. They are fashion's early adapters, and this season many have zeroed in on some of the quirkiest, most creative -- but also wearable -- offerings designers showed for fall. A year ago, a hobbled economy and echoes of 9/11 haunted those same shoppers. "They were hesitant," said Linda Dresner, who has stores in New York and Birmingham, Mich. "They just didn't want to feel frivolous." But an uptick in sales of her more daring pieces -- deconstructed Watanabe coats and jackets ($800 to $1,500), a silver python bag from Chloe -- show that shoppers are "in a mood to emerge from their shells, to buy something that makes them feel cool," she said.
"Shoppers want what's unique and different," said Dana Telsey, a luxury goods analyst with Bear Stearns. "Money is tighter than it has been, so they want to make sure that what they're getting is of value -- something that's going to differentiate an outfit." 
A case in point is a snug-fitting jacket by Oliver Theyskens for Rochas, embellished at the rear with a crazily billowing panel of lace-covered silk -- a hit at stores like Ikram, on Chicago's Gold Coast. "At $3,500, that jacket is not inexpensive, but we bought six and sold six," said Ikram Goldman, the owner, who caters mostly to an affluent, fashion-literate crowd.
At the same time, fashion itself has opened its arms to the sort of woman who in years past might have dismissed its more extravagant expressions as alien or intimidating. "The profile of the fashion consumer has changed," said Robert Burke, the fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman, where items like a Chanel simulated-crocodile jacket (about $1,950) and an Oscar de la Renta motorcycle jacket embedded with studs have helped boost sales of higher-priced designer wares. The women buying them are "not fashionistas," Mr. Burke asserted. "They're just American women enjoying fashion, or at least the creativity of fashion, more than they have in the past." 
Their embrace of the more inventive, indeed sometimes the flashiest, looks of the runways seems to bode well for the industry, galvanizing sales and spurring designers to pull out all the stops. "It raises the bar creatively," Mr. Burke said, "and puts more pressure on designers to create more and more arresting pieces." 
Not that designers are grousing. "It used to be that what you showed on the runway was always a separate entity from what goes on the selling floor," said Peter Som, who will unveil his spring 2004 collection in the tents at Bryant Park next Tuesday. "Now there is more of a direct correlation from the runways to reality," Mr. Som said. "It's the novelty pieces that are selling." 
One of his current star performers is a $1,495 silver gray sweater with enormous fox cuffs. "The fashion-forward things tend to go first, whatever their price," said Sarah Easley, a part owner of Kirna Zabete, the trendsetting SoHo boutique. "At this point, women have enough black pants, enough brown boots. What they want is a fantastic showstopper." One of the most sought-after items in the store is a blouse from Viktor & Rolf for about $600, its distinguishing feature a multilayered mille-feuille collar. 
In a reversal from past years, the more offbeat the item, the more likely it is to be snapped up as an investment, retailers say. At Jeffrey in New York, best sellers include a cloud-patterned cashmere sweater by Lucien Pellat-Finet ($2,650), pink patent leather pumps by Christian Louboutin ($430) and gold-studded opera gloves from Gucci ($490). "There is nothing frivolous about these pieces," Jeffrey Kalinsky, the owner, said. At Net-a-Porter, which sells high-priced fashions on the Internet, current hits include over-the-knee boots by Marni ($950), a silver knit minidress by Missoni ($870) and a waist-cropped moss green motorcycle jacket from Chloe ($2,000). 
Mellody Hobson, who owns a money management company in Chicago, bought a lacy cocktail outfit by Rochas with a spray of tulle cascading off its back. "You can dress up the jacket with the skirt that goes with it," she said. "But I imagine it with a black turtleneck sweater underneath. You want to be low key, but still original." 
"I don't think everyone gets it," Ms. Hobson conceded. "But that's a good thing."

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Fashion page on Tuesday about the popularity of quirky fall designs misstated the given name of the designer of a jacket embellished at the rear with a billowing panel of lace-covered silk. (An article in The Times Magazine on Sunday about the restaurant 66, where patrons are wearing the designer's clothes, included the same error.) He is Olivier Theyskens, not Oliver.

SECTION: Section A; Column 2; National Desk; Pg. 18

HEADLINE: Poor Workers Finding Modest Housing Unaffordable, Study Says 

BYLINE:  By LYNETTE CLEMETSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 

 BODY:
With the rise in housing costs outpacing that of wages, there is no state where a low-income worker can reasonably afford a modest one- or two-bedroom rental unit, according to a study issued today by the National Low Income Housing Coalition, an advocacy group based in Washington. 
 The study, "Out of Reach 2003," compared wages in each state, large metropolitan area and county in the nation against fair market rents as determined by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
 In 40 states, the study found, renters need to earn more than two times the prevailing minimum wage to afford basic housing. In the most expensive states -- Massachusetts, California, New Jersey, New York, Maryland and Connecticut -- they must earn more than three times the minimum wage. 
The federal minimum wage, last increased in 1997, is $5.15 an hour, though some states put their minimums higher, topped by Alaska, at $7.15. The nation's median hourly wage last year was roughly $12 an hour, according to the Economic Policy Institute, a research organization that advocates on behalf of low- and middle-income workers.
The gap between affordability and housing costs has been increasing, the study found, and researchers and advocates for low-income workers say the implications cut across a variety of social issues. 
"When low-income families are paying so much of their income on housing, they are left to skimp on other necessities like food, medicine, clothes and time spent with children," said Sheila Crowley, president of the National Low Income Housing Coalition. 
For each state and locality, the study determined a "housing wage": the income a full-time worker must earn to afford a modest rental unit. "Affordable" rent was defined as no more than 30 percent of the household income, the standard calculation used by HUD. A "fair market rent" was also based on a HUD standard, typically the 40th percentile in a given housing market (the 50th percentile in the markets that are tightest and most expensive).
The national median housing wage necessary to afford a standard two-bedroom rental unit, the data indicated, is $15.21 an hour, up 37 percent from 1999, when the organization began collecting detailed statistics. 
In Massachusetts, the most expensive state for housing, the housing wage for a modest two-bedroom apartment is $22.40 an hour. In the District of Columbia, whose metropolitan area is one of the most expensive, it is $23.42 an hour. But even in West Virginia, the most affordable state, a worker would need to earn $8.78 an hour to afford basic housing, considerably more than the state's $5.15-an-hour minimum wage. 
Ms. Crowley said more subsidized housing was needed for low-income families. Not all housing experts agree.
"We're not, in this time of rising deficits, going to be able to subsidize our way out of any housing gap," said Howard Husock, director of case studies at the John F. Kennedy School of Government, at Harvard. "We need to find ways to increase wages of low-income families and to create more two-wage-earner households, through programs like those that encourage marriage."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "Renting at Minimum Wage"Workers who make minimum wage $5.15 to $7.15 an hour cannot afford a two-bedroom rental unit at fair market rents, according to a report released yesterday by the National Low Income Housing Coalition. Chart shows the hourly wage a worker must earn to afford a two-bedroom rental unit in each state. Map of the United States.
